story:
After months of composing, tweaking, workshopping, writing and rewriting, SCOUTS is ready to take its next big step. This new musical about gender, inclusivity, and...a giant moth... has brought together an incredible team of actors, directors, designers, and creators to put together its first-ever full industry reading. 

And we need your help to make it happen!

 

It’s the Summer of 1989, and in the small mountain town of Point Pleasant, West Virginia, the rival troops of Brother Scouts and Sister Scouts are at war. Competing for the illustrious title of “Troop of the Year” awarded at the annual Scout Jamboree, the young Scouts only agree on one thing: their troop is better than the other.

Enter our two main characters: Alex, a brave, hotheaded, authority questioning Sister Scout, and Travis, the rule-following, loyal, friendly Brother Scout. Feeling like she doesn’t belong with the Sisters, Alex decides to ask Travis’ Scoutmaster, Scoutmaster Pete, if she can be a Brother Scout. But before she can ask, Pete disappears.

Suddenly, the Scouts’ lives are uprooted when they learn Scoutmaster Pete is searching for the town legend, the infamous Mothman. Gathering their tents, backpacks, and slap bracelets, our eight young scouts venture into woods, alone, to look for their missing Scoutmaster…

…and who knows… someone or SOMETHING might be looking for them too.

 

  • Submit full draft of libretto for Copyright ✔
  • Create Social Media Platforms and Website for Outreach ✔
  • Hire Artists and Create Demos of select songs ✔
  • Produce and Create “Producer’s Package” Presentation (February 28th) ✔
  • Network and Collaborate with Producers to increase outreach and interest ✔
  • Workshop Final edited script before summer reading ✔

  • First Reading/Sing through of SCOUTS by Summer 2021 --> JULY 2ND, 2021

 

We are asking for $5,000 to recoup funds that we have given personally to get SCOUTS to New York City!

Over the past year, we've invested our time, finances, and creative energy to make this show a reality. We have gathered an inspiring team, a glorious cast, and an amazing group of supporters and allies in shaping what we believe will be a truly revolutionary show, and the first step is a private industry reading happening on July 2nd, 2021, at Open Jar Studios, right off Times Square.

Every cent you donate will be used to cover artist pay, the creative team's involvement, and the final production costs that are making it all happen. Any additional funds will go directly into supporting the future development of SCOUTS into the future. Even if we don't reach our goal, every dollar raised will still be directed to cover those costs. SCOUTS is committed to, above all, supporting new work and its artists, and every cent helps.

And by supporting this cause, you join the troop! What's a scout without some badges? There are so many exciting perks that come with each donation amount: from thank yous, to unique, one-of-a-kind merchandise from the show, and even a seat to the private reading on July 2nd!

 

As we begin our transition back to live performances, we believe we have an amazing opportunity to shape a new and different landscape for the performing arts. It's time for new types of shows for a new type of Broadway; and we think SCOUTS is just that. In line with that mission, we have partnered with the remarkable Con Limón Productions, a company committed to advocating for under-represented voices, developing vibrant new works by vibrant new writers, and supporting work with themes that sting, and a crisp and solid "Why?".  With their help, we have gathered an incredibly diverse and talented cast, director, music director, and designers, and your support can make sure they continue to get the recognition they deserve!

For us, this completely original story is what the world needs, right now. We need new, original content as theatre makers that is relatable to all audiences. We need to see stories that explore gender and sexuality. We need producers that prioritize equity and representation in casting and creative teams. 

We all have experiences of feeling like we don't belong because of our gender, who we love, where we came from, or who we were meant to be. But this story changes that. We belong. We are loved. And we will always fight for a better world. And we want to invite you to fight for that world too. 

 

Creating new, ground-breaking work is hard. Creating new, ground-breaking work in this moment of transition is even harder.

SCOUTS has a tough, but exciting journey over this past year. We wrote the libretto, composed the full score, and achieved copyright. We created our website, social media platforms, and fundraisers to shape an online presence. We’ve hired incredible artists to record demos of select songs and participate in online readings. We even self-produced and archived an hour-long producer’s package presentation. And now, we're taking an even bigger step forward: our first full, live reading and sing-through of the whole musical. But it isn't easy: our ambition and dedication to creating a new process and artistic group towards the dream of a new and improved artistic has required a lot of financial and artistic effort, and a particular attention to increasing visibility, spreading the word, and creating a new brand, which is specially grueling in our current moment. We are in a key moment of transition, which has required us to adapt, re-adapt, and be always flexible and on our toes. 

Luckily, we are so lucky to have assembled an incredible team that has risen up to the challenge. These artists were key players during the pandemic, creating opportunities and work for artists of all backgrounds, shapes, and talents. And as things begin to reopen, they are all promising to be even more important figures in shaping what the new artistic landscape of what New York City, and the world, can be.

We know it won't be easy, but we can promise you this: any support you give will be in good, capable, talented, and trustworthy hands. 

 

Can't donate right now?
You can still give us a hand!

Spread the word! Share the campaign! Tell your friends! Make. Some. Noise!Any mention, share, comment, like, or post helps us create visibility, and we need all the visibility we can get! At the very least, take a look at our site and social media, as well as the site and social media of our partner, Con Limón! 

https://www.scoutsmusical.com/
Instagram
 

https://www.con-limon.org/
Instagram

 

And remember... the Mothman is real.

story:
J.B. Waterman (Director, Producer) Brain Kavanaugh (Producer, Trigorin)  have had an obsession with the Seagull for quite awhile, mainly around it's unrealized comedy and it's apt-ness for our lives as actors in Los Angeles.  The characters in "The Seagull" are obsessed with Fame, and how it can (or can’t) make one happy.  Arkadina (an aging actress) returns to her estate, trying to hold on to her younger, more famous writer boyfriend.  Konstantin, (Arkadina’s son) has written a new, revolutionary kind of play that he believes will change the world and needs the approval of his mother and his girlfriend.  Konstantin’s girlfriend, Nina, dreams becoming a famous actress and how it will make her life unimaginably beautiful.  It goes on and on. Every character exists in Los Angeles today and is comically self-involved!

The Seagull shows us farcical versions of ourselves, and invites us to both laugh at and feel compassion towards them.  

Taking this show from thrilling idea to fully realized production has been a monumental and expensive task.  We’ve had to rent a theatre, pay for the rights to the translation (Paul Shmidt’s hilarious work), hire a set designer, a lighting designer, a costume designer, sound designer and a stage manager.  We are also offering our actors a small stipend for their weeks and weeks of inspired work.  This is a serious undertaking, and we’ve had to go deep into the hole to marshall the resources to begin.  

$6000 will not cover the cost of production, not even close, but it should allow us to break even after ticket sales.    

J.B. and Brian have brought Alex Elliott-Funk (playing Dorn) in to help produce this show.  All Three are veterans of over 70 theatrical productions.  J.B. has produced and directed five plays and acted in over 30,  Brian has acted in over 15 productions and Alex has either produced or acted in over 30 plays.  We know what it takes to make a show entertaining and meaningful.  But most importantly, we are passionately committed to making this play, one that changes people’s perspective on Chekhov.

story:
Transcendance Project is a Toronto-based company intent on stretching the boundaries of our dance community.

This show is immersive and interactive, with a contemporary vocabulary as the main narrative. The work is based on a literary classic which will be revealed upon entering the space. Taking place on the venue’s 3 floors, the audience will be free to follow any character or scene within the overlapping narratives. It’s a 'choose your own adventure' kind of show; each person’s experience different from the next.

Costs add up quickly when creating a show of this magnitude. We need your donations to help with the following:

16 dancers, location, composer, set, lighting, props, costumes just to name a few! Your funds will help make this all possible. 

We have numerous contribution levels with exciting perks from social media shout outs, clues to our concealed show, Transcen|Dance project tshirts, invites to our closed rehearsals and more!

There are many ways to help us meet our goals. If you aren't able to donate, a simple share helps us get our word out!

To buy tickets to 'Eve of St. George' visit: 

https://www.eventbrite.ca/e/eve-of-st-george-ti...

story:
Short Summary

I remember very vividly the day my mom told me that we couldn't afford dance classes anymore. I felt like she was stifling my dream to dance professionally in New York and I was just getting started. I was so heartbroken. Looking back now, I know that she was doing the best she could. Luckily, I had grandparents that helped transport me and pay for my dance classes. 

It is a part of my mission for P.O.M. Squad to make dance education fun, filled with life's little lessons and affordable for all families. Because even if the girls don't go on to dance as pros, they will make life-long friends and learn lessons about leadership, determination and persistance through dance. And I think stuff like this should honestly be free - and maybe one day it will be! 

Help us empower young ladies through our mentoring and dance program. About 40% of the families we work with have the opportunity to participate in our program on financial aid. It is our mission to offer affordable programs for every economic background because we believe every girl should be in a positive program and afforded the opportunity to dance. 

Please help us continue to empower these young ladies!

What We Need & What You Get

Here's how the funds will be used:

  • $4,000 - This will cover all of our rental expenses for the Fall Season.
  • $1,350 - This will cover the costs of Parade Jackets for over 60 girls
  • $1,250 - This will cover the costs of Poms for over 60 girls
  • $1,700 - This will cover the costs of Uniforms for our Competition girls
  • $500 - Administrative fees
Extra Fees:
  • $2,245 - Competition fees for 25 girls (2 competitions)

The Impact

With your contribution, you will ensure that P.O.M. Squad can continue to offer dance and mentoring programs at minimal costs and continue offering full and partial scholarships to over 40% of our families.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute financially or just want to know how you can get involved:

  • You can become a Volunteer Board Member.
  • You can volunteer to help with our Saturday classes.

story:
What is Poetic License?

Poetic Theater Productions is raising funds for Poetic License, our fifth annual festival of new poetic theater, which will take place March 16-April 10, 2016 at Wild Project in NYC's East Village.  Poetic Theater Productions is a community driven organization and Poetic License is both a space and stage to celebrate and give a platform to the diverse voices and breadth of experience found within New York City. Poetic License features full-length plays, devised theater, developmental and new play readings and special events that highlight themes including love, war, mental health, identity and politics from a diverse array of social and cultural backgrounds.

We need your help to raise the final $10,000 to make this festival happen. 

Please watch the video and share this page via Facebook, Twitter and email to friends and individuals who you feel would like to support social justice through art, poetry and theater.

Why should you support us?

Poetic Theater Productions and our annual Poetic License festival have become essential spaces for some of New York's most talented artists to develop and premiere new powerful works of poetic theater telling their stories and giving needed artistic voice to today's social justice movements.  Your support helps us continue to offer and build this artistic space and make more powerful and immediate poetic theater.  Producing theater in New York is expensive - especially while trying to make our art accessible to a diverse community of different fiscal means by keeping ticket prices at an affordable rate.  That means ticket sales only cover a portion of our full production costs.  This is why your donations are so important.  We literally can't do this festival without your support.

What do we need money for?

  • Four week theater rental in the East Village
  • Our wonderful production team (production manager, festival lighting & video designer, audio engineer and stage managers) to help us run the theater throughout the month-long festival. 
  • A producer and an associate producer to help us coordinate all of the artists & performances, marketing and production for the festival
  • Our actors, directors, playwrights and designers
  • Travel stipends for our interns who help run everything from our front of house, to our marketing, to the shows themselves
  • Marketing and Outreach to get the word out about all of the incredible shows and a coordinator to enhance those efforts
  • Rehearsal & workshop space for the various shows in the weeks leading up to the festival
  • Program printing for 28 shows

The Festival Line-Up

This year's festival will include...
  • Devised Poetic Theater
  • Generation Now! (poetic theater with youth)
  • Breaking Our Silence (celebrating LGBT voices)
  • Love Redefined (social justice remixes & re-imaginings of traditional love poems)
  • Special Events with award winning poet and activist Mahogany L Browne
  • Play Readings
  • New Collaborations
And much more to be announced soon!

Photo from Underground by Edward McWilliams as part of Poetic License 2012. Directed by Axel Avin Jr., choreography by Ezra Ezzard. Lighting Design by Brad Peterson. Photo by Adrian del Valle Rodriguez. 

What Your Gift Means

$2000 - covers half a week's rent of performance space

$1000 - covers almost all of the expenses for one day of the festival

$750 - sponsors half of the overall expenses to develop a new devised poetic theater piece which will be presented in the festival (rehearsal space, fees for actors, designers, a director and a stage manager)

$500 – underwrites our printing costs

$250 – helps cover artist fees and stipends 

$50 –  the cost of needed food and coffee for the artists and designers during tech

$35 – covers the cost of renting a rehearsal room for one hour

$18 – sponsor a ticket for someone who can’t otherwise afford one

$10 – covers the cost of scripts for one of our new play readings

Poetic Theater Productions is a sponsored artist with Performance Zone Inc (dba The Field), a not-for-profit, tax-exempt, 501(c)(3) organization serving the performing arts community. Contributions to The Field earmarked for Poetic Theater Productions are tax-deductible to the extent allowed by law. For more information about The Field contact: The Field, 75 Maiden Lane, Suite 906 New York, NY 10038, phone: 212-691-6969 or fax: 212-255-2053 or for our national charities registration, see details. A copy of our latest financial report may be obtained from The Field or from the Office of Attorney General, Charities Bureau, 120 Broadway, New York, NY 10271.

story:
Short Summary

 My name is Mark Robinson and I am a freelance writer and musical theatre historian who has written three books The World of Musicals, The Disney Song Encyclopedia and The Television Theme Song Encyclopedia. I also am the writer of the popular musical theatre blog "The Music that Makes Me Dance" and a regular contributing writer for Playbill . The books I have had published and assisted with have been predominantly reference and now I want to narrow in on one specific topic that I feel passionately about: The musical INTO THE WOODS.


What Will Be Accomplished Through This Book?:

1. An in-depth exploration of the creation of the musical as told through interviews with creators, cast members, critics and theatre historians who can share stories on the importance and impact of the piece.

2. The securing of photographs, both behind the scenes and of various productions of Into the Woods.

3. A detailed look at the themes and messages of the musical, how they grow out of human psychology and also challenge our concepts of right and wrong, good and evil, and blame vs. responsibility.

4. A dissection of the songs, their purpose, their place within the musical and how they establish character development.  

5. A look at why audiences and theatre enthusiasts gravitate toward this musical.

It is important to document theatre history so that future generations can truly comprehend the impact and artistic value of the great works. INTO THE WOODS is a great work and I want to dedicate myself to documenting its creation and impact for posterity.

To Explain My Passion for the Project:

I happened upon INTO THE WOODS when I was 15-years old and my parents were going through a particularly ugly divorce. I gravitated instantly toward this musical about parents and their children, the legacies we leave behind (good and bad), and the powers of forgiveness and togetherness. The musical continues to intrigue me as it has resonated differently with me as different points in my life. I have learned that there is a large community of fans who love this musical and who have been equally changed and empowered by INTO THE WOODS.

What We Need & What You Get

Books like the one I am trying to write rarely make a lot of money, but require money and a great deal of personal investment to make happen. I am attempting to raise the money that will allow me to spend six-months traveling, researching, and securing the photos that will make this book the most informative and entertaining it can be for readers. Your investment will help me tell a great artistic story.  We also have some wonderful perks depending on your investment level donated by some wonderful people who already believe in this project!

The Impact

What will your donations do?

  •  Preserve the story of a beloved musical for posterity.
  • Help spread the important messages and themes of INTO THE WOODS
  • Help inspire future generations of musical theatre creators.
  • Help me, an avid theatre historian and devoted writer of the genre, to create a uniquely special book about a show that has moved and shaped several generations of fans and audiences.  

Risks & Challenges

 I have managed with great success to bring every project I have proposed to fruition. All three of the books I have already written have been well-received and eagerly scooped up by publishers. This project always risks the slim chance that a publisher might not be interested. I am confident, however, that this book will be published and will be a success for all those who take part.
story_txt:
Short Summary My name is Mark Robinson and I am a freelance writer and musical theatre historian who has written three books The World of Musicals, The Disney Song Encyclopedia and The Television Theme Song Encyclopedia. I also am the writer of the popular musical theatre blog "The Music that Makes Me Dance" and a regular contributing writer for Playbill . The books I have had published and assisted with have been predominantly reference and now I want to narrow in on one specific topic that I feel passionately about: The musical INTO THE WOODS. 
What Will Be Accomplished Through This Book?:1. An in-depth exploration of the creation of the musical as told through interviews with creators, cast members, critics and theatre historians who can share stories on the importance and impact of the piece. 2. The securing of photographs, both behind the scenes and of various productions of Into the Woods. 3. A detailed look at the themes and messages of the musical, how they grow out of human psychology and also challenge our concepts of right and wrong, good and evil, and blame vs. responsibility. 4. A dissection of the songs, their purpose, their place within the musical and how they establish character development.  5. A look at why audiences and theatre enthusiasts gravitate toward this musical. 
It is important to document theatre history so that future generations can truly comprehend the impact and artistic value of the great works. INTO THE WOODS is a great work and I want to dedicate myself to documenting its creation and impact for posterity.To Explain My Passion for the Project:I happened upon INTO THE WOODS when I was 15-years old and my parents were going through a particularly ugly divorce. story:
Why This? Why Now?

Aging women often feel ignored or marginalized by the world, despite the stories and wisdom and laughter we have to share. Developing our play "Dancing With Crow's Feet©" allowed us to collect stories from women whose voices aren't often heard including women in nursing homes and community centers.

This work is groundbreaking - no one else is sharing aging women's stories in this way. We see this as an important way to honor aging women and dispel myths and stereotypes about aging. The play is meant to raise awareness about ageism.

We premiered "Dancing With Crow's Feet" at the 2016 KC Fringe Festival, where we won 'Best of Show' for our venue. Now, we have the opportunity to take our show to a much bigger and more important stage - the IAGG World Congress of Gerontology and Geriatrics in San Francisco. This event only occurs every four years and hasn't been in the U. S. in decades. The focus is Global Aging and Health: Bridging Science, Policy, and Practice and addresses the latest approaches to improving the quality of life of the world's older adults. This is our chance to share real women's stories and experiences with an audience of influential aging professionals.

What We Need & What You Get

We are aiming to take a core cast of six to San Francisco. Our budget includes:

Round-trip air fare for six cast members = $535 x 6 = $3,210

Cost of transportation in San Francisco (airport to hotel / hotel to conference site) = $620

Hotel accommodations for six cast members = $320 (per room) x 4 rooms x 4 nights = $5,120

Food for Cast - 25 x 6 x 4 = $600

TOTAL = $9,550

What do you get? Besides knowing that YOU are part of the creative aging movement, you will also be supporting a groundbreaking project that combats ageism.  At various levels of sponsorship, you will hear directly from members of the cast and might even get to meet them in person, so that you can enjoy their wit and wisdom for yourself.

We are determined to meet our goal of taking the  core cast of six to perform at the Global Aging and Health Conference.  Should we miss our goal, we will use the funds to send as many cast members as we can and to support the performances of this show in the Kansas City area.

The Impact

With this play, we're sharing stories that beg to be heard, from women whose stories are often missed. Already, "Dancing with Crow's Feet©" has made an impact by challenging expectations about women and aging for cast/crew and audience members alike.

Just imagine what it will be like to take these stories and this experience to the people who have major influence in the world of aging! Perhaps more than anyone else, the people attending the IAGG World Congress of Gerontology and Geriatrics need to understand the impact of ageism on women, and they need to see the beautiful, witty, poignant work of art that we have created together.

Many of these aging experts will never come to Kansas City to see our play, but at the IAGG conference, we will be able to bring our message to over 6,000 influential professionals who can then  take it back home to their universities and hospitals and their communities across the world.

Risks & Challenges

We acknowledge that taking a cast of this size across the country is a huge challenge for an organization of our size. We are small, but we are growing, with new volunteers signing on to help with our important mission all the time.

Other Ways You Can Help

We appreciate your support for our campaign. Want to help us in other ways?

  • Share this campaign on your Facebook feed and across social media to encourage other people to contribute.
  • Encourage the senior care organizations in your life to check out our campaign, too!

story:
When we were kids, we loved Roald Dahl.  His books were macabre and funny and weird and sweet, all at the same time.  At the time, we didn't know anything about the man behind the books.  Writing is a solitary pursuit, which makes the lives of writers often rather dull.  Not so with Roald!  When we discovered his early life as a fighter pilot, spy, and propaganda author, we knew we'd found the raw materials for a play.  One detail that especially stuck out to us was the affair he had had with sitting Congresswoman, Clare Luce.  The more we learned about Clare, the more we knew their relationship would be the centerpiece of the play.  Clare was a playwright whose work had been wildly successful on Broadway, a journalist who traveled to the front lines of World War Two, and a politician who never compromised her fierce intelligence for party loyalty.  And yet, even after all of that, she still endured sexist jokes by men who assumed she had slept her way to the top.  Her story is obviously relevant to our current political climate while being fascinating in its own right.  The play that we wrote is now less a literary biography and more a sex comedy trapped in a spy thriller.  It's a story of love, lies, and children's books from Blythe Roberson and Andy Boyd.

We hope that you will help our production by donating to our fund, and in doing so support a group of passionate, enthusiastic, and devoted writers, actors, producers, and designers. We are incredibly honored to be a part of the New York City Fringe Festival, which celebrates the steps of new and expanding artists such as ourselves.

Our show will debut on Sunday, August 16, at 5:45 p.m., with performances on Wednesday 8/19 at 8:15 p.m, Friday 8/21 at 2:00pm, Wednesday 8/26 at 4:30pm, and Friday 8/28 at 7:45pm. All shows will be at the Robert Moss Theater at 440 Studios, 440 Lafayette Street, New York.

Please show your support by donating to our campaign, and please join us at our performances to enjoy a story about everyone's favorite childhood storyteller!

story:
What is O.REX?

O.REX is a brand new translation of Sophocles' Oedipus Rex, re-envisioned as a Greek-Noir Classic. (Greek-Noir: a mash-up of Greek Tragedy & American Film Noir.) Translated from the Original Greek by Classics' Scholar Mark Buchan and Gia Forakis, this production will take place in a nightclub. The audience will be seated at the nightclub tables, where Sophocles' Choral Odes become acts on the nightclub stage, as the entire performance space is transformed into a black & white world of 1940-50’s film noir with cinematic underscoring, video projection and the gripping drama of the ultimate murder mystery!    

What's Next for O.REX?

With our new script in place, now IT'S TIME TO MAKE THE MUSIC!    

This August, GF&CO was invited to The Putney School in Putney Vermont, for a Residency with our Grammy-Award Winning Composer, Jeremy Mage, and the O.Rex creative team to begin work on the five jazz-ballad Choral Odes-Night Club Songs. Here is a SNEAK PEEK of the work we've done so far!:

(Music: Jeremy Mage, Lyrics: Mark Buchan, Residency Participants: Maria Deasy, Katrina Foy, Randolph Curtis Rand, Stephanie Regina)


What is Your Role in O.REX?

Your contributions will play an essential role in the REALIZATION OF THE MUSIC, bringing us one step closer to our Fall 2014 production of O.REX. Here is how your generous contributions will play out...

$429 pays for composing, producing & recording of one Choral Ode-Nightclub Song

$2,144 pays for producing & recording of all Choral Odes-Nightclub Songs

$4,288 pays for composing, producing & recording of the Cinematic Underscore

$6,432 pays for all of the above

$12,432 pays for all of the above plus the Composer's Fee

$Overfunding will not go to waste!

Every extra penny will be applied to the production budget for the Fall 2014 Production

Reaching Our Goal:
One Thought & One Action at a Time!

GF&CO applies the principles of One-Thought-One-Action (content-driven thought and action) to everything we do. The smallest step, when taken with clear, incremental intention, brings us closer to all our goals and to the realization of this highly original theatrical event.

Become a part of our Greek-Noir Odyssey by giving to the creation of the music!

Spread the word about this campaign. Every incremental step counts!

With Joy & SONG,
Gia Forakis
Artistic Director of GF&CO


The O.REX Artistic Team:

Director & Co-Translator: Gia Forakis
Lyricist, Greek Scholar & Co-Translator: Mark Buchan
Composer: Jeremy Mage
Video & Projection Design: S. Katy Tucker
Dramaturg & Creative Strategist: Greg Taubman


What is GIA FORAKIS & COMPANY (GF&CO)?

GF&CO is an ensemble of professional theater artists trained and committed to the exploration, experimentation and application of One-Thought-One-Action(OTOA)™ under the Artistic Direction of Auteur Stage Director and Theater Artist, Gia Forakis. OTOA is a rehearsal and performance technique for performers, directors and public speakers, founded and taught by Master Teacher, Forakis, as a method for identifying smaller increments of thought as smaller moments of physical action. GF&CO’s Mission is to put One-Thought-One-Action™ into Action by producing vivid, highly detailed, physically engaging events for the stage through the re-envisioning of classic texts, company-driven original work, the experimentation of form and style, and by continuing to ask the question: How do we keep live theater relevant and vital in the 21st century? For more information visit: www.giaforakisandcompany.com

story:
Let's get a JIBO family robot for the San Francisco office! I reserved one for us while the original campaign was still live.

Think of all the great uses for our JIBO! Once we get our hands on a developer edition, we could make all of these dreams come true:

Telepresence from the NY office

Dialing in for standup? Show your face standing among your SF teammates!

Blueline Judge

Finally, an impartial way to determine winners on Fridays. We can use image-recognition and analysis to see exactly whose bubbles are closest to the sacred marking.

Bell-ringer

The JIBO will alert us by playing a "bell" sound when Random Acts of Awesome occur! 

If the build breaks, the JIBO starts crying.

Stretch Goals

Put a JIBO on it!

Ava, iRobot's Mobile Robotics platform, could allow our JIBO to roam the office. http://www.irobot.com/For-Business/Platform-Opp...


=)

story:
Opinions vary as to what makes a great American president. What qualities separate Thomas Jefferson from Warren G. Harding? Was it simply his cool during a crisis that put Teddy Roosevelt ahead of Chester A. Arthur? Debate rages about who was the greatest president in U.S. history.

Next spring, that debate will be settled once and for all. What's more, the debate will be settled hilariously and melodically. In M.V.P., the best of all the men who have led the United States gather in Las Vegas, the most American of cities, to compete in a pageant. Using only their records, their accomplishments, and their wits, these great American presidents all have one goal - to win the title of "Most Valuable President".

Who will take the crown? Will it be:

Abraham Lincoln - the heavy favorite, the man whose exaltation by the nation has become almost too much of a burden to bear?

George Washington - the one who started it all, the "Father of His Country" who chafes against his newfound status as the also-ran?

Thomas Jefferson - the intellectual who looks back upon his contributions to American History as complicated, and not without a large measure of regret?

Or will a long shot ("Jackson!? TR!? JFK?!") emerge from nowhere to disrupt the proceedings and snatch the title?

As the curtain to this unprecedented event draws near, the presidents realize that their quest for glory comes with unexpected trials and tribulations that will put their leadership abilities to the test. With beautiful music by David P. Johnson, and a witty script full of twists and turns by Matthew Hoffman & William Norrett, M.V.P. deals with the idea of what it means to be an American president, the value of glory, and the question of what one sacrifices to obtain both."

Who We Are:

Three men who have been creating, producing, and performing theater in New York and Los Angeles for over two decades.

William Norrett is the author of several plays, including The Sophisticated Rogue, The Dealer Was Showing Six, and Brendan O'Lenihan Leaves Three Daughters, as well as the writer/director/star of the short film collection, You Know What This Song's About? He recently published The Vanilla Gigolo Prescription, his first novel, and maintains the Sophisticated Rogue Media website, a blog devoted to his humor pieces and creative endeavors (www.sophisticatedrogue.com). His homemade macaroni & cheese has no equal. 

Matthew Hoffman - co-wrote the indie hit documentary What the Bleep Do We Know? and as a twice-published author brought to print the first biography of jazz crooner Tony Bennett.  In addition to having written the prize winning short play, “A Dose of Family,” Matthew worked as part of Joel Hodgson’s (visionary creator of MSTK3) creative team for many years. He has also worked writing commercials for the European theatrical market and as a script doctor for a number of feature scripts.  As an actor, Matthew has appeared in film, television and radio.  His cast-iron stomach led to the launch of his own hot sauce company.  Ask him nice and he’ll share his ever handy supply of ghost pepper flakes with you… they go well with Norrett’s world-class mac & cheese.

David P. Johnson is most often recognized as the creator of Sally Spectre the Musical, (Book, Music and Lyrics). This unique musical about the ghost of a little girl stuck in a Victorian mansion in New Orleans was a finalist for the prestigious 2012 Richard Rodgers Award, won a 2009 Ellen Idelson Award, the 2009 Grand Prize in the Hurricane Season Playwriting Festival, and garnered three Scenie awards from Stage Scene LA in 2011. Other awards include a 2012 Alaska Film Award, and a 2012 Oregon Film Award for his screenplay Ganymede Pan, and an 2010 Ellen Idelson Comedy Playwriting Award for his short Bump? What Bump? He has also received a Valley League Theatrical Award for his efforts as one of three producers of A Very Brady Musical.  He wrote and produced Deli Cats and currently has other scripts in progress, namely musicals including an upcoming public reading of his newest musical piece – Alternating Currents: The Nikola Tesla Story. David does not cook anything well.

What we need & How will we spend the money?

M.V.P. is a grand, enthusiastic musical. Your pledges will help procure the rental of a 99-seat venue big enough to hold it. M.V.P. includes all of the most iconic American presidents. Your pledges will ensure we can cast the best actors, and pay them commensurate to their talents. We feel the huge potential of the play, and your pledges will help us promote, publicize, and push this premiere production, so that potential is fulfilled.

Once we are fully funded, we will be able to pay for: venue rental (including all technical aspects, such as lighting and sound), rehearsal space, musical arrangements and orchestrations, fifteen actors, three musicians, one production stage manager, publicity, promotion. We plan to make this production as visible as possible, to help ensure further life for M.V.P. We’re very proud of our work here, and feel it has a bright future.

Thanks very much,

David, Matthew & Bill

Other ways you can help:

-visit our page on Facebook - www.facebook.com/MVPthemusical

-visit our website - www.sophisticatedrogue.com

-follow our Twitter feed - @MVP_the_Musical

Who We Are:
Three men who have been creating, producing, and performing theater in New York and Los Angeles for over two decades.
William Norrett is the author of several plays, including The Sophisticated Rogue, The Dealer Was Showing Six, and Brendan O'Lenihan Leaves Three Daughters, as well as the writer/director/star of the short film collection, You Know What This Song's About? He recently published The Vanilla Gigolo Prescription, his first novel, and maintains the Sophisticated Rogue Media website, a blog devoted to his humor pieces and creative endeavors (www.sophisticatedrogue.com). His homemade macaroni & cheese has no equal. 
Matthew Hoffman - co-wrote the indie hit documentary What the Bleep Do We Know? and as a twice-published author brought to print the first biography of jazz crooner Tony Bennett.  In addition to having written the prize winning short play, “A Dose of Family,” Matthew worked as part of Joel Hodgson’s (visionary creator of MSTK3) creative team for many years. He has also worked writing commercials for the European theatrical market and as a script doctor for a number of feature scripts.  As an actor, Matthew has appeared in film, television and radio.  His cast-iron stomach led to the launch of his own hot sauce company.  Ask him nice and he’ll share his ever handy supply of ghost pepper flakes with you… they go well with Norrett’s world-class mac & cheese.
David P. Johnson is most often recognized as the creator of Sally Spectre the Musical, (Book, Music and Lyrics). This unique musical about the ghost of a little girl stuck in a Victorian mansion in New Orleans was a finalist for the prestigious 2012 Richard Rodgers Award, won a 2009 Ellen Idelson Award, the 2009 Grand Prize in the Hurricane Season Playwriting Festival, and garnered three Scenie awards from Stage Scene LA in 2011. Other awards include a 2012 Alaska Film Award, and a 2012 Oregon Film Award for his screenplay Ganymede Pan, and an 2010 Ellen Idelson Comedy Playwriting Award for his short Bump? What Bump? He has also received a Valley League Theatrical Award for his efforts as one of three producers of A Very Brady Musical.  He wrote and produced Deli Cats and currently has other scripts in progress, namely musicals including an upcoming public reading of his newest musical piece – Alternating Currents: The Nikola Tesla Story. David does not cook anything well.
What we need & How will we spend the money?
M.V.P. is a grand, enthusiastic musical. Your pledges will help procure the rental of a 99-seat venue big enough to hold it. M.V.P. includes all of the most iconic American presidents. Your pledges will ensure we can cast the best actors, and pay them commensurate to their talents. We feel the huge potential of the play, and your pledges will help us promote, publicize, and push this premiere production, so that potential is fulfilled.
Once we are fully funded, we will be able to pay for: venue rental (including all technical aspects, such as lighting and sound), rehearsal space, musical arrangements and orchestrations, fifteen actors, three musicians, one production stage manager, publicity, promotion. We plan to make this production as visible as possible, to help ensure further life for M.V.P. We’re very proud of our work here, and feel it has a bright future.
Thanks very much,
David, Matthew & Bill
Other ways you can help:
-visit our page on Facebook - www.facebook.com/MVPthemusical
-visit our website - www.sophisticatedrogue.com
-follow our Twitter feed - @MVP_the_Musical

story:
What It Is

“Of the woman came the beginning of sin and through her we all die” is a dynamic new play about the dangers of commercializing millennial femininity, written by Lily Houghton and directed by Kylie Brown, and co-produced with Leigh Honigman and Normal Ave at the Medicine Show Theatre in October 2019.

We seek to continue the conversation around privilege, capitalism, and the social codes and messaging a woman+ receives living in today's world.

We hope to inspire others to create and produce their own work through the production of this play, and your donations will encourage and support the uplifting of young, femme-identifying voices.

What We Need & What You Get

We need to raise $22,000 dollars to pay our artists and collaborators on this world premiere production, implement production design, engage with our audience through extra programming and activities, and spread the word about this femme led world premiere production!

Paying artists a reasonable wage is immensely important to us, and we need to give them the budget to create the design of our dreams. We also need to pay our actors respectfully, and make sure nobody is juggling three jobs at once!

We've got discounts at femme & nonbinary led businesses, merch, advance tickets, personal perks like a monologue from our playwright or a coaching session from our director, and more!

The Impact

Your donations will help pay our artistic and production team, implement our production design, create programming opportunities around the play for our audience, and increase engagement around this world premiere play.

As a group of emerging women theater-makers, we want to encourage others in our position to create and produce their own work.

We want to pay our artists in money, not exposure!

The themes this play explores could not be more relevant today, and we're honored to have the opportunity to contribute to the conversation.

Who We Are

Lily Houghton (Playwright)​ ​is a twenty-three year old playwright born and raised in Manhattan. She wrote her first play at age seventeen before completing her B.A. in theater and clinical psychology with a minor in literature at Bennington College. Her plays have been developed at MCC Theater Company, The Flea, EST/Youngblood, NYU, 20% Theater Company Chicago, Yale University’s Writers’ Conference, Bennington College, University of Michigan Theater Conservatory, and the Jermyn Street Theatre in London. Shorts include NEXT (Serials, The Flea) Be Gentle with my Heart (Asking for Trouble, EST/Youngblood), The Interesting Girl (EST/Youngblood), and someone/something/someone/something (EST/ Youngblood) which just won a Sloan Foundation Grant. Lily's play, Dear, received a PlayLab with MCC Theater in the fall of 2017. This Spring she received the Elizabeth George Grant through a new play commission from Seattle Repertory Theater. She is a proud member of the Obie winning Youngblood writers group and the Flea Theater writers group.
 

Kylie M. Brown (Director)​ ​is a Brooklyn-based director of new work and literary manager for Normal Ave. She is currently curating the NAPseries of new work for Normal Ave. Recent directing projects: Dead Meat by Paige Zubel, little lives by Shara Feit (Furnace Festival, G45 Lightbulb series), Of the Woman Came the Beginning of Sin and through her we all die by Lily Houghton (EST Bloodworks), What We Made: Gone Missing Lobby Project (The Civilians/City Center Encores! Off-Center), and Painting Faye Salvez by Rachel Covey (NYMF, Northwestern). Short plays and readings with EST/Youngblood, 7x7, Two Headed Rep. As an assistant/associate director, she has worked with Liesl Tommy, Leigh Silverman, and Lear Debessonet, among others. Notable projects include Eclipsed, Privacy, and most recently assisted Leigh Silverman for the first fully female/non-binary creative team on Broadway for Lifespan of a Fact.

Leigh Honigman (Producer)​ is a multidisciplinary Brooklyn-based producer interested in breaking down social taboos and mental health stigma. She received her B.S. in psychology from Fordham University. Recent theatre productions include American Juggalo (Vital Joint), The Ugly Kids (2018 Fresh Fruit Festival at The Wild Project), Gain! (Sportslab NYC) and Phantom of the Paradise in Concert (The Secret Loft). Recent film credits include ANNIVERSARY (dir. Tina Makharadze), the upcoming Saltines! (dir. Alley Leinweber), and SLUT - The Web Series (dir. Madi Van Dam).
 

Normal Ave (Producer) exists as a shared desire to bring theatre to New York audiences that is socially relevant and emotionally stimulating. In New York City, we are gifted with an array of source material: the many different lives that coexist on 13 miles of an island. Normal Ave provides fresh, accessible, high-caliber programming that reflects the drive of the New York Community that we are rooted in. We are here to create to an artistic hub for up-and-coming, likeminded artists in the early stages of their careers. By giving them a space to work, we encourage and empower our actors, playwrights, directors and designers to discover their unique voice, collaborate with new storytellers, and explore what it means to break molds and redefine normal.

Other Ways You Can Help

Can't contribute right now? That's okay! Getting the word out about this brand new production helps us immensely. Share us on facebook or follow us on Instagram!

Interested in working with us, or providing an in-kind donation? Please reach out to ofthewomanplay@gmail.com.

story:
STORY

When a grandmother, Evelyn, prepares lunch she tries to find the cause of her quirky grandson’s anger at a visiting doe. At the same time he wants to know what mysterious illness she has. And while they both cope with the reality that they are the only family left, Fabian is even more determined to banish the lingering deer.

That Kid explores the courage of this unlikely pair in the face of #adversity, #bullying and #mortality.

WHAT

We are producing our 10-minute play called That Kid for a one-night performance at The 41st Samuel French Off Off Broadway Short Play Festival where 30 shortlisted plays are presented in six nights by the world's most renown play publisher. Six plays will be chosen for publication.

WHEN

That Kid will be presented Tuesday, August 9th at 8:30PM.

(Tickets here: https://www.artful.ly/store/events/9443)

If our play advances, we present as Semifinalists on Saturday, August 13th. The final six winning plays will be presented Sunday, August 14th.

WHO

Jane Willis, Playwright: (Dramatists Guild, Writers Guild of America East)

Jane returns to playwriting after a long hiatus, during which she taught public school. Prior to her career as a middle and high school English teacher, she is best known for “Slam!” and “Men Without Dates” (Ensemble Studio Theater) Available through Dramatists Play Service. Slam! also available in Ramon Delgado’s Best Short Plays of 1986. “As The World Turns”, “The It Girl” (Martin Poll Productions/HBO) (November 2015) “What She Wished For” (a full-length dark comedy) Staged reading directed by Melissa Skirboll:  The Barrow Group Theatre Company, NYC.

A Brooklyn resident, Jane likes to write about restless youth on the crest of making drastic life-changing decisions. She has three children, and a loving partner who kindly reads her first drafts. Jane would also like to thank Arlene Hutton and The Barrow Group Theatre Company workshop, for her support as “That Kid” developed.

Juanita Howard, Evelyn: (SAG-AFTRA, Actors Equity, Hadley Players)

Juanita Howard comes to theater, film and television as a singer and cabaret entertainer. Theater includes: Medea (Nurse) for The Classical Theatre of Harlem, Laundry and Bourban (Amy Lee) for The Sledge Project, Jar the Floor (MaDear) at The Black Spectrum Theatre and With Grit and Grace for The Hadley Players. Films include: Chasing Taste (Paulette), Fades with Age(Janet), Couples(Constance), Stutter, and The Rodnees Movie(Mrs. Barnette).  Television includes: Nurse Jackie, Army Wives, Law and Order. Juanita  dedicates this performance to her mother Margaret.

Tyasia Velines, Fabian:

Tyasia is an acting student at the University of Maryland who is thankful for theater’s powerful ability to teach and transform both audience and self.

Edward Shieh, Director: (Writers Guild of America East)

Eddie is an award-winning filmmaker and screenwriter, a 2015 NBCUniversal Directing Fellowship and 2014 Fox Global Directors Initiative Fellowship nominee, and alumnus of The Barrow Group Theatre Company Directing Program under Seth Barrish. Eddie also predicts weather with his surgically repaired joints.

HOW

We're asking for $800 in donations to cover our expected costs including:

  • $360: Rehearsal Space and Time at The Barrow Group Theatre Company for at least 20 hours ($18/hr).
  • $250: Kitchen and Food Props that includes a used Baker's Rack, Dining Table with Chairs and table top foods like apples, bread, condiments and Skittles!
  • $150: Travel Stipends for both our actors to get around town with Unlimited Metrocards - particularly to and from rehearsals.
  • $40: Miscellaneous items

All additional donations beyond our needs will go directly to our actors, Juanita Howard and Tyasia Velines, who have dedicated their talent and time in the making of this play.

It's as simple as 80 people giving $10, 40 people giving $20, or 20 people giving $40 - that's all it takes.

AND

If you can't contribute, we hope you spread the word and even see our show! 

  • Please share our campaign.
  • And buy tickets at https://www.artful.ly/store/events/9443

Please come support and celebrate #diversity #women #peopleofcolor #LGBTQ #elders #youth #actors and the other plays.

Thank you again. We're grateful for your support!

story:
Short Summary

"Summer of Stories" is produced by hereandnow theatre company in association with the Rosenthal Theater at Inner City Arts.  Since 1989, hereandnow theatre company has been committed to the idea that "Everybody has a story to tell,"  and this summer we will be presenting new work for our company along with continuing our tradition of providing a venue for playwrights to share their works-in-progress.  "Summer of Stories" brings together over 50 artists - actors, writers, and directors to bring these pieces to life.

 

What We Need & What You Get

To make this festival a success, we need to raise $5,000 for rehearsal and theater rental, marketing, and production costs (equipment, lighting, sound, video, etc.).  With your contribution, we would like to raise more than $5,000 so that we can compensate all of the artists involved with more than just the Equity minimum in the hopes of starting a trend of paying artists an actual living wage for their talents and their time.

 

The Impact

Since we began this project in 2016, we have involved the community in the process of creating theatre by having showcased 17 pieces, some of which have gone on to be produced elsewhere and developed into films,  and brought over 100 artists together.  With your support, our mission is to continue bringing new, diverse voices to the stage, as well as offering a creative forum for both artists and audience.  

 

Other Ways You Can Help

We value any acts of generosity, whether it be monetary, or by helping to spread the word!  Thank you so much for your time!

story:
An original show about love, women's rights and climate change

We are researching and developing a beautiful original production and sharing it in New York free of entry on March 28th at 7:30pm at lower Manhattan's Dixon Place theatre.

 "A young couple living in a world ravaged by climate change is faced with a terrifying prospect. An unplanned pregnancy. Together they must decide whether they can bring a defenceless child into a seemingly hopeless world."

Maite Jauregui and Danny Horn, London Scratch Performance at Bathway theatre December 2019, photos by Richard Mockler

This new original play by Australian playwright Melissa-Kelly Franklin was written as a response to climate change and the attack against women's reproductive rights in 2019.

It is still in development and this performance sharing relies on audience feedback before the next draft of the script and its translation to other languages, and to reach our future goals of creating a fully realised full length production of this beautiful, original and intimate story between a young couple that is afraid of their future in a world they feel they have little control over. 

Danny Horn, London Scratch Performance at Bathway theatre December 2019, photos by Richard Mockler

The play is a call to action through a love of humanity, hope against the odds and a passion to act now against global warming to create the future we desire.

The artists

Léerin Campbell - Young Woman

Léerin recently moved to New York after graduating from The Bristol Old Vic Theatre School with her MFA in Acting. She's received additional acting training from RADA and Shakespeare & Co. Prior to moving to England to pursue her Masters, Léerin was living and acting professionally in the Midwest, primarily in St. Louis. Besides theater, Léerin is also a climate activist with Extinction Rebellion.

Chris Nester - Young Man 

Chris is a New York based actor appearing on stage and screen. He has honed and developed his craft with Anthony Abeson and at the Freeman Studio, MN Acting Studio, and Upright Citizens Brigade Theatre. He’s currently studying with Terry Knickerbocker at his studio in Brooklyn. 

Sólveig Eva Magnúsdóttir - Director

Sólveig is a Brooklyn based actress, director and illustrator and one of the founding members of Spindrift. She believes in the power of storytelling when it comes to advocating the needs of the individual and their communities. Her physical theatre workshops seek to reconnect the performer to rejected aspects of their identities and physical instrument. She has worked as a producer and director in Europe and North America since her graduation in 2013, but her training includes: Rose Bruford College (BA), LAMDA, Estonian Academy of Music and Theatre, Meyerhold’s Biomechanics in Italy, Gardzienice Theatre in Poland, Stella Adler, T.Schreiber Studios and UCB in New York. As an actress she has appeared as a series regular on TruTV and guest starred on HBO. As an illustrator she focuses on nature, portraiture, femininity and female-identifying experiences such as bodily autonomy, pleasure and healing. Sólveig is an activist and a canvasser for charities and an avid nature lover.

Anne Windsland - Assistant Director

Anne is a Norwegian Director, Actress and Writer based in NYC. She is a graduate of the American Musical and Dramatic Academy (AMDA) in New York, and has also received training from the London Academy of Music and Dramatic Arts. Since starting acting at a young age, she has appeared in film, TV and theatre productions around the world. Some of her credits include; Originating the part of Maggie in Mr. Splitfoot at the Edinburgh Fringe Festival, High Maintenance on HBO and The Iliza Shlesinger Sketch Show on Netflix.

With her production company New Winds Production, she wrote and directed her debut short film The Clarinet, which premiered at The Williamsburg Independent Film Festival. With her storytelling, she wishes that people will begin questioning the society they live in, and challenge their own contentment. 

Melissa-Kelly Franklin - Playwright

Melissa-Kelly’s short film, Portrait, inspired by Poe's short story The Oval Portrait and pre-raphaelite muse Elizabeth Siddal, screened in official selection at Wollongong Film Festival and Feel the Reel International Film Festival, and was highly commended by Experimental Forum for ‘vision and contribution to cinema’. She was nominated for Best Director at the Largo Film Awards for her short film, Embrace Me, and was recently invited to contribute both films to the international short film streaming platform Sofy.tv as part of Switzerland’s Largo Film Talent Program.

Melissa-Kelly graduated with first class honours in Advanced Arts from the University of Sydney, with majors in English Literature and History.  She followed her academic study with training in screen acting at NIDA and classical acting at LAMDA, all of which have been formative in shaping her writing and directing style.  Her recently completed short, darkly comic romance Only the Lonely is currently nominated for best short film at Melbourne Short Film Festival. She has several other projects in development, including upcoming short exploring women’s reproductive rights, The Quickening, Australian Gothic period short Wild Flower and LGBT French Language short The Vow.  She is currently an Artist in Residence at the Bathway Theatre in Greenwich, UK.

We have already covered the expenses for our basic rehearsal space and the most important props. We are hoping to compensate our artists: actors, musician, composer, playwright and directors for all their hard work they are giving these two months to ensure this production makes it further. We already have meetings with large theatres we are hoping to bring a fully formed production to through the success of this research and development performance, and will be showing at Reykjavík Fringe Festival summer 2020.

Besides theater, Léerin is also a climate activist with Extinction Rebellion.Chris Nester - Young Man Chris is a New York based actor appearing on stage and screen. He has honed and developed his craft with Anthony Abeson and at the Freeman Studio, MN Acting Studio, and Upright Citizens Brigade Theatre. He’s currently studying with Terry Knickerbocker at his studio in Brooklyn. Sólveig Eva Magnúsdóttir - DirectorSólveig is a Brooklyn based actress, director and illustrator and one of the founding members of Spindrift. She believes in the power of storytelling when it comes to advocating the needs of the individual and their communities. Her physical theatre workshops seek to reconnect the performer to rejected aspects of their identities and physical instrument. She has worked as a producer and director in Europe and North America since her graduation in 2013, but her training includes: Rose Bruford College (BA), LAMDA, Estonian Academy of Music and Theatre, Meyerhold’s Biomechanics in Italy, Gardzienice Theatre in Poland, Stella Adler, T.Schreiber Studios and UCB in New York. As an actress she has appeared as a series regular on TruTV and guest starred on HBO. As an illustrator she focuses on nature, portraiture, femininity and female-identifying experiences such as bodily autonomy, pleasure and healing. Sólveig is an activist and a canvasser for charities and an avid nature lover.Anne Windsland - Assistant DirectorAnne is a Norwegian Director, Actress and Writer based in NYC. She is a graduate of the American Musical and Dramatic Academy (AMDA) in New York, and has also received training from the London Academy of Music and Dramatic Arts. Since starting acting at a young age, she has appeared in film, TV and theatre productions around the world. Some of her credits include; Originating the part of Maggie in Mr. Splitfoot at the Edinburgh Fringe Festival, High Maintenance on HBO and The Iliza Shlesinger Sketch Show on Netflix.With her production company New Winds Production, she wrote and directed her debut short film The Clarinet, which premiered at The Williamsburg Independent Film Festival. With her storytelling, she wishes that people will begin questioning the society they live in, and challenge their own contentment. Melissa-Kelly Franklin - PlaywrightMelissa-Kelly’s short film, Portrait, inspired by Poe's short story The Oval Portrait and pre-raphaelite muse Elizabeth Siddal, screened in official selection at Wollongong Film Festival and Feel the Reel International Film Festival, and was highly commended by Experimental Forum for ‘vision and contribution to cinema’. She was nominated for Best Director at the Largo Film Awards for her short film, Embrace Me, and was recently invited to contribute both films to the international short film streaming platform Sofy.tv as part of Switzerland’s Largo Film Talent Program.Melissa-Kelly graduated with first class honours in Advanced Arts from the University of Sydney, with majors in English Literature and History.  She followed her academic study with training in screen acting at NIDA and classical acting at LAMDA, all of which have been formative in shaping her writing and directing style.  Her recently completed short, darkly comic romance Only the Lonely is currently nominated for best short film at Melbourne Short Film Festival. She has several other projects in development, including upcoming short exploring women’s reproductive rights, The Quickening, Australian Gothic period short Wild Flower and LGBT French Language short The Vow.  She is currently an Artist in Residence at the Bathway Theatre in Greenwich, UK.We have already covered the expenses for our basic rehearsal space and the most important props. We are hoping to compensate our artists: actors, musician, composer, playwright and directors for all their hard work they are giving these two months to ensure this production makes it further. We already have meetings with large theatres we are hoping to bring a fully formed production to through the success of this research and development performance, and will be showing at Reykjavík Fringe Festival summer 2020.

story:
GRUESOME PLAYGROUND INJURIES

JUNE 27-JULY 1, 2018—San Diego, CA

    The Story

    • Gruesome Playground Injuries, follows childhood friends, Doug and Kayleen over the course of 30 years, from ages 8 to 38, as their lives intersect and they compare emotional and physical scars. 

    Mission

    • After a relentless pursuit for the rights for Gruesome Playground Injuries, a play by Rajiv Joseph, we were finally able to obtain them for San Diego, and will be mounting the play June 27-July 1st. 
    • Allowing us to tell this story, may not solve world peace or hunger, but I do believe it’s beauty, and searing truth around what it is to carry both emotional and physical wounds into relationships, will definitely leave a mark you’ll not soon forget.  And ultimately I feel like that’s something of value to take out into the world—an understanding that scars come in all shapes and sizes, and perhaps if we share with each other, how we ache, hurt, and bleed, and do so openly, we just might see each other more clearly. Okay, so maybe it is about world peace. 

    Meet the Cast & Crew

    Victoria Van Winkle (KAYLEEN)—Victoria Van Winkle was born and raised in Chattanooga, Tennessee until moving to Los Angeles for College. After attending the University of Southern California, earning a Bachelor of Arts in Acting, she is now developing her career full-time as a filmmaker, and actor.
    She has been cast in several theatrical plays, musicals, short films and independent feature films, wearing the hat of actor, producer, and writer. Shortly after graduating from USC, Victoria's life shifted when her childhood best friend committed suicide. After the 2014 passing of her friend, she knew she needed to tell the story of her friend and the thousand others who struggle with depression. Her critically praised short film, "Dear Harley," premiered at multiple film festivals across the world, bringing more light to these issues and opening up much needed conversations on mental health.
    Victoria continues to expand her awareness around such topics, exploring also themes of grief, loss, addictions, and human intimacy and connection. She is currently studying at The Imagined Life Studio under the care of Diana Castle and Faline England.

    A note from Victoria: I have been chasing down this play since 2014, and am so beyond excited and pumped to finally share this story, in all it's gruesome glory! I think there's something so beautifully painful about this story and yet brutally honest in that pain and beauty, scars and healing are very rarely experienced separately—where one starts, another one usually begins.  

    A special thank you to Jared, Darius, Rals, and Susan for saying yes to this journey—getting to do this with some of my best friends is the most wonderful and joyous thing!  And thank you Faline England for lending arms, voice, poetry, and belief—immensely grateful for your guidance always! And thank you Diana Castle for the gift of The Imagined Life, and to all the insanely wild hearts I've grown to know and love within that space. 

     

    Jared Bergenstal (DOUG)—Jared Bergenstal is an actor, writer and musician. Recently his independent film Take Care Brother (co-writer, actor, producer) was chosen to be screened at the Burbank International Film Festival. He is currently writing his first screenplay, a coming-of-age family-drama which takes place in the 80s. He is so grateful to tell this beautiful story with Victoria and to have Darius and Raleigh on-board.  Jared thanks his creative mentor Faline England for all her passion and energy and the gift of receiving this story under her teaching. Jared is also grateful for the support of his community of artists at the Imagined Life.

     

    Darius De La Cruz (Director)—Darius De La Cruz directed Broad Street last November, a Wild Mountain Features production including work by Edward Allen Baker, Bekah Brunstetter, and Audrey Cefaly. He has acted at The Garry Marshall Theatre, The Odyssey, Atwater Village Theatre, Rogue Machine and most recently with Pop-Up Theatre as Martin in Seminar. Favorite screen credits include NCIS, The Comeback, Jimmy Kimmel, NCIS: LA, and Criminal Minds. An independent film he starred in, Paula and Jeff,screened at the 2017 Glendale Film Festival, and Wait Crimes, which he co-wrote & produced, won “Best Web Series” at Independent Filmmakers Showcase last year as well. He is grateful to his mentors and colleagues at Carleton College and The Imagined Life who have helped make this possibility a reality.

    A note from the director Darius De La Cruz: 

    It’s so wonderful to work on a passion project. I’ve had the pleasure of knowing Jared and Victoria for a couple years now and they are both so alive when working on this play; it’s exciting to collaborate like that. I’ve seen a few other artists work on this story and Victoria and Jared have something new to say about it which has driven me to re-imagine whole aspects of its telling.

     

    Raleigh West (Producer)—Raleigh West is an actress/writer/producer, California native and storytelling enthusiast. She is very excited to be working on Gruesome Playground Injuries helping make Victoria and Jared’s passion a reality. While producing Gruesome, she is also serving as the dramaturg on Pop Up Theatre’s production of Seminar by Theresa Rebeck. She also recently acted with Pop-up Theatre, in Darlene Craviotto’s Pizza Man, in which she received excellent reviews for her portrayal of Alice. In 2016, she was Becky Shaw in Pop Up’s production of Becky Shaw. Her production company, Wild Mountain Features, most recently produced Broad Street, a show of 3 one acts in which Raleigh played Dolores in Edward Allan Baker’s Dolores. Her on screen accolades include Best Actress Winner at The Broad Humor Film Festival for her web series Vageniuses and Best Actress in a Web Series Winner at the Chicago Comedy Film Festival for her web series Or the Burrito Gets It! Raleigh wants everyone to know that she loves these 3 beautiful artists that have created this production, that her mom is the best person, and her acting teacher, Faline, is a poetic genius.

    Susan Donner (Set Design/Art Dept.)—Susan grew up surrounded by her parents obsession with Broadway musicals, so the moment Wicked came onto the circuit, she was hooked. Since she couldn’t sing or dance or even act, she did whatever she could to learn about the art of Production Design. After moving to LA, she quickly moved up from working on Lifetime movies, to Hallmark movies, to hit cult classic Syfy movies— all of which eventually led way to working in Television. She spent the last 5 years working on TNT’s The Last Ship, and currently is an Art Department Coordinator for the new highly anticipated Amazon show, Homecoming. 

    SPECIAL THANK YOU TO OUR VIDEO/IMAGE TEAM: MEGHAN MEIER & MIKE SYLVESTER

    What We Need & What You Get

    • Our overall budget is $7,000. These costs cover mostly our theatre rental, housing, director’s pay, producer’s pay, the rights for the play, and set/costume/props. Below is a chart with all of our projected expenses and costs. 
    • We are offering various perks, including signed posters, VIP Seating, Thank You’s/ Shout Outs, Producer Credits, BTS footage/interviews, and high fives! 
    • All of our funds will go towards meeting these specific expenses, and whatever costs are not covered by our campaign will be paid out of pocket. Below is a chart of our budget's breakdown:

    The Impact

    • Our marketing will largely focus on reaching out and targeting the theatre community in San Diego, including local schools, universities, and theatre companies. Our hope is to open conversation around topics such as sexual abuse, self-harm, broken families, relationships, and living life to the fullest.

    Risks & Challenges

    • Making art always costs. But we’re willing to take the risk and rise to the occasion. 
    • Producing in San Diego, is likely the biggest risk, being what we will be away from our home base and Los Angeles Community. However we are confident and enthusiastic about convincing you, bribing you, doing whatever it takes to get you and all your friends to come down and enjoy the day or weekend in San Diego!

    • We are also exploring outreach strategies for the surrounding San Diego Theatre Community, as well as working the San Diego International Fringe Festival Circuit, which will also be going on during our run.  

    Other Ways You Can Help

    • Maybe you aren’t able to donate—that’s okay! Commit to coming to the show! Put the dates in your calendar now. Buy your ticket now! Say yes! And bring friends!   

    • Sharing our campaign is another amazing way you can help us. Invite all your friends to share as well. In my experience, a word of mouth is one of the greatest acts of service one can give to art. Support us by spreading the word about our campaign and production!

    • If you have a relative or contact in San Diego who would be willing to house a handful of story-tellers (4 of us to be exact), that's another way to support us. It would help us to cut down some of our costs. This is obviously an unusual ask, but we’re open to all possibilities, should it be a good fit, and location.

story:
Our Story

Because dancing is awesome; whether it be adding some chilli to your salsa moves, filling google maps with your street dance moves or just rocking the Zumba dance party.  NYC Dance Week, your favorite festival, is back on June 20-29, 2013.  For 10 days, you, your family and friends can enjoy free dance, fitness and wellness classes provided by our awesome NYC studios (over 30 are already on board!).  To get so much free dance you’d usually have to stick a fork in the toaster.  Our staff is working hard to get more studios to offer free classes this year and sponsors to provide freebies to you, all being well there’ll be dancing in the streets (providing the NYPD agree).  But in order to make this a successful festival, we need your help.

We need to raise $2,000 by June 16, 2013 which will cover office supplies, printing, flyers, fees, designer diamante studded dance leggings, and other miscellaneous expenses (just kidding about the leggings unless Lady Gaga donates some).  You may choose to fund us for as low as $1 but you might want to donate at least $10 to get some cool rewards (sorry no diamante leggings).

 

WE NEED TO RAISE $2,000 by JUNE 16, 2013 - Please help us spread the word!

 

What We Need & What You Get

We need $2,000 to make this 10 day festival a success.

* Office supplies, printing, flyers & other basic administrative costs

* Freebies for class participants, i.e. t-shirts

* Fees to keep our website and e-blast services up

You may donate as low as $1 but to get a reward, you must donate at least $10. 

 

What's in it for YOU

Awesome rewards! Tax-deductible!*

Your donation supports the most awesome event since tap dancing moved out of the sink, benefiting you and your friends trying out dance, fitness and wellness classes for free; new styles and studios; make friends build networks; it’s more fun than breakdancing with panda bears (and more legal). 

 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can’t help with cash today, there are tons of other ways to be a part of Dance Week!

- Spread the word by asking your studios to participate and telling your friends & family about our event and telling people you don’t like. Dance is for everyone!

- Donate your expertise and time. If you’re an awesome dancer then your moves are worth more than money (although we still like money)

 

The absolute best way to support us is by embracing Dance Week and spreading the word.

Tell your friends about this Indiegogo campaign.  Please use the share buttons to tell people - on facebook, on twitter, on your blog...


Check out our website:  http://nycdanceweek.org

"Like" and share us on facebook : NYC Dance Week

Follow us on twitter & tweet about us! @nycdanceweek

 

And most importantly...please come and participate in the free classes.  Register now at 

https://nycdanceweek2013.eventbrite.com/.

 

If you want to know more about this festival and have ideas and want to share your thoughts, please e-mail us at dance@nycdanceweek.org

 

                       Thank you, from the bottom of our hearts.

 

*Amount after deduction of reward's value.

story:
This all began when I opened an e mail a few weeks back and saw this:

"Thank you for submitting for Manhattan Repertory Theatre's FALL ONE ACT PLAY COMPETITION 2012. We loved your play and we would be thrilled if you would participate in our competition with your production."

So, as you can see, I've written a one act play that will be staged in New York City, September 27th, 28th, and 29th, and possibly October if it advances that far in the competition. But we need to have the entire production packaged and ready to go for them. I could have sent it to some friends of mine in NYC and allowed them to run with it, but instead I have chosen to create it here with Maine actors, a Maine director, and a Maine stage manager. Why? Because I loved going there as an actor back in May and, in turn, the director of the theater loved our professionalism.  We, our community, can be represented again by a new set of actors and a new director and stage manager. And they should be paid for their professionalism.

But I need help. I simply can't do this by myself. I need to cover the expenses of the theater rental for our pre shows and I need help with the significant travel expenses for cast and crew. And, finally, I need to pay everyone. The more we raise, the more THEY get.

Dominion is set in the world of Christian stage plays. Each and every day people either become more deeply religious or they leave their faith entirely. This is about one of those days.
