story:
Support Jen & Peter’s New Show at the Vancouver Fringe!

 

We are Jennifer Pielak and Peter Abando, two of Canada’s musical improv trailblazers and long time artist friends. We have come together as a duo and will be performing at the 2018 Vancouver Fringe Festival!

We have created a brand new show - Inside Voices. This is the scariest show we will ever perform, because we will be sharing the thoughts, judgements, and impulses that come up for us moment to moment  - in musical form. You know the stuff you think about that you’d rather other people not know? Yeah, those versions of yourself. Haaaaa…

Why in the hell are we doing something so terrifying? Because it is honest and vulnerable, and we hope that through sharing our inner weirdness, our audiences will learn that the things they think about themselves and try to tuck away can hold a lot of power (in more ways than one). To put it simply, the world could use a whole lot more acceptance of self and other.

But, here’s the thing: we need your financial support! You can see more on production costs below, but to summarize, even if we sell 100% of our tickets (and in Vancouver the average attendance rate for theatre is 30%), we will barely make a profit. We are paying to produce this show out of our own pockets and relying on our team to generously volunteer most of their time (that includes us too). Why? Because we believe deeply that this show needs to be seen.

So we’re asking for your help! Artists like us need outside financial support to keep making important, meaningful, and high quality work. We know this show is one of those works. We know there are people like you out there who want to support artists like us and who also believe in our work - and we are so grateful for it. SO GRATEFUL!!!

We couldn’t do it without you. Thank you!

 

What We Need

 

We are hoping to raise at least $1500 to help us pay for production costs. If we meet this goal, we will continue to fundraise, because we actually need around $2300 to cover everything. Anything above and beyond this goes to the artists involved!

Our Budget Costs:

  • Festival/Venue (Space Costs & Fringe Fees): $1445
  • Personnel ($200 Honorariums for Team Members): $1600
  • Production (Piano Rental, Costumes, Rehearsal Space, Program Printing, etc.): $900
  • Marketing (Online & Print Advertising, Distribution, Photo/Video Production) : $955
  • Contingency Fund (there’s always that extra thing to pay for): $200

TOTAL: $5100

Estimated Revenue from Tickets: $2790*

Amount We Need To Break Even: $2310

*This number comes from calculating a 30% fill rate, which is the average attendance rate for Vancouver Theatre shows. It is also Fringe, which means there are dozens of shows happening at the same time. $12 from every full ticket sold will go back to us, however with Fringe passes, comps and a 1/2 price show, a more accurate guess is $10/ticket.

 

Perks For You!

 

For Friends, Fans and Followers:

We're artists and we love to share our talents with you!

  • Want to learn? We've got some voice & musical improv educational options (online and in person).
  • Just want something silly? We've got some make-your-day-awesome things for you!

 

For Artists, Entrepreneurs, and Companies (Big & Small):

Whether an artist, solo entrepreneur, or big company - we’ve got some advertising options for you if you want to get word out about your work/company/product.

  • Small Sponsor* - we'll promote you on our Instagram Stories, Facebook Pages & Website
  • Big Sponsor* - we'll promote you on our Video Content, Instagram Stories, Facebook Pages, Website, and in our printed Show Program
  • Presenting Sponsor* - your logo will be on all of our posters & flyers we will spread around town. You'll be in our printed program (on the front and inside). We'll promote you on ALL* our Video Content, in our Instagram Stories, Facebook Pages, and Website. You will also get access to our all of our educational & silly perks.

*Some of the sponsorship perks are subject to WHEN you purchase this - so the sooner the better! (ie. we can't include your info/logos in our marketing content if it's already been created/printed & released to the world)

Helpful Info About Us:

  • Our Instagram Account (@jenniferpielak) has 1000+ followers (organically grown)

  • Our Facebook Accounts (@jenniferpielak & @jenniferpielakofficial) have 1500+ followers (organically grown)

  • Our Audience: 

    • up to 930 people will see our show. There are 6 shows at the Firehall, which will bring in up to 6000 people during Fringe. 

    • adults (mostly in 19-45 age range) of all backgrounds

    • we anticipate our show will attract creatives, actors/singers/directors/musicians/theatre-makers, artists, mindfulness & mental health professionals, people interested in personal development, entrepreneurs, people interested in seeing unconventional/experimental theatre, people looking for a new experience, adventure-seekers

  • ​Our Show Themes: psychology, mindfulness, self-acceptance, inner voices/personas/critics, art making & creative process, spontaneity, mental health, acting process, music composition, musical theatre, experimental theatre, improvisation

 

Other Ways You Can Help

 

If you can't support us financially, there are other ways you can help!

  • Tell your friends about us!
  • Share our campaign on your social media accounts.
  • Follow Us Online! We will be sharing behind the scenes about the process for the weeks leading up to the show. Feel free to comment and ask questions!
    • Instagram: @jenniferpielak and @peterabando
    • Facebook: @jenniferpielakofficial
    • Website: www.jenniferpielak.com
    • Hashtags: #InsideVoicesFringe #KeyOfP

 

More About Us

 

Who We Are

We (Jen and Peter) are extremely good pals and musical improvisers. Or, as we are saying lately - because it feels more accurate - experimental musical theatre artists.

We love working with each other. We have special chemistry. This comes from developing shows, teaching classes, performing together, and experimenting with this unusual art form for 8 years. We know each other really well. We created the musical improv group Off Key Improv. We wrote Connected: The Musical (alongside Alison Chisholm) which got nominated for an Ovation Award. We’ve trained and performed together in Chicago and New York. We both keep ourselves busy as artists (Jen as a working actor & acting/improv coach and Peter as a music teacher, music director & composer), but manage to keep coming back to one another to work together. It’s a special thing and it’s rare and we know it.

Now it is just the two of us. We’ve never performed as a duo before - it’s scary and exciting. We have to really trust and challenge each other. It’s like doing doubles figure skating - except in musical improv form.

 

The Inside Voices Team

We are so damn lucky to have this crazy talented team. 

Jennifer Pielak - Creator, Actor/Singer, Producer

Peter Abando - Creator, Musician/Music Director, Producer

Alison Chisholm - Co-Creator, Production Manager & Admin

Eleanor Felton - Director

Sharon Rose Wu - Stage Manager

Mauro Fernandez - Videographer

Rae MacEachern-Eastwood - Graphic Design

Andrea Loewen - Marketing & Publicity Advisor

 

Coaches: Raina von Waldenburg & Avyen von Waldenburg

 

Developing The Show

Inside Voices got it’s start as as passion project as part of the The Anvil Centre Artist In Residency Program in June 2017. We got a month of free workshop space to figure out the show concept and held a few workshop performances to get audience feedback. We loved what we discovered and have continued to develop the show over this past year. When we started, we had no idea what this show was going to be. Thanks to the help of many creative collaborators (special shout outs to Alison Chisholm and Raina von Waldenburg), audience feedback, extra training and many creative workshops shooting around in the dark, we’ve discovered a show that is very uniquely ours. It’s only something Jen and Peter can do. We can’t wait to share it with you.

story:
Create. Collaborate. Detonate.

About the Project

Coriolanus [Russian Shakespeare Roulette]

a PassionProject by Lesley Berkowitz of Reject Theatre Project

Coriolanus is a Roulette Reading of Shakespeare's text. On the night of each performance the audience will enter the space, have a drink and witness the Roulette Ritual as the actors choose their track for the evening... five minutes before 'curtain.'

Each actor will have several tracks that they may be familiar with, but not polished. This selection will be a surprise to them, as well as the audience.

Part of the fun of this production is going to be the element of the unpredictable and unknown while still performing a 400 year old play!  As an emerging artist collective we are also inviting some more established actors to join inthe fun. These guest artists will be a part of the reading for one night a piece and play the role of the distinguished Menenius.

LESLEY:

"This project is going to give the actors opportunities that they might not otherwise get in terms of casting. Men will play women, women will play men and it is no big deal. It will also inevitably lead the audience to hear the text in a different way than they would for another production. I believe audiences will jump into the reality that we present to them. My goal is for it to feel improvisational and for the atmosphere to be party-like."


About the Rejects

Reject Theatre Project (RTP) is an emerging artist collective dedicated to creating and producing each member’s PassionProject before disbanding.

We are eight emerging theatre artists based in Philadelphia. We have created a collective that is dedicated to the creation and production of one PassionProject per member. We believe that there are a lack of entry-level jobs in Philadelphia for the amount of young theatre artists that the city is producing. The opportunities available don’t provide an outlet for artistic expression and leadership. Reject Theatre Project will provide fulfilling artistic opportunities to a variety of emerging theatre artists throughout Philadelphia. 

Each of us posess a different artistic focus, aesthetic and skill-set. We have created a mission that will embrace each of these artistic voices and an environment that will nurture creative freedom, risk and collaboration. In exchange for each of our PassionProjects being produced, we will provide each other with mutual support until each vision is fulfilled. It is our goal to complete all eight productions before the end of three years. When our final PassionProject closes, we will detonate and document our journey for future theatre artists. 


What We Need & What You Get

We at Reject Theatre Project feel strongly that artists deserve to be paid for the work they do.  Our payment will simply be seeing our PassionProjects alive on the stage, but we have many artists helping us to achieve this goal who we want to compensate.  We also have various technical and practical needs that will be costing us.  So, we are asking for:
  • $1,100 for artist pay.  Coriolanus will feature 11 emerging actors.
  • $2,500 for space rental.  We will need to rent a space for one week of rehearsal and two weeks of performances.
  • $400 for various marketing and production supplies.  This will include programs, postcards, scripts, possible props, etc.

Other Ways You Can Help

Can't give today?  That's okay! Here are a few other ways you can help:

  • Like us on Facebook
  • Check out the other projects on our website.
  • Volunteer your time!  We're always looking for ushers, house managers, people to distribute flyers, or anything you can think of!  Let us know how you'd like to help or find more information by emailing us at rejecttheatreproject@gmail.com
story_txt:
Create. Collaborate. Detonate.

About the Project
Coriolanus [Russian Shakespeare Roulette]
a PassionProject by Lesley Berkowitz of Reject Theatre Project
Coriolanus is a Roulette Reading of Shakespeare's text. On the night of each performance the audience will enter the space, have a drink and witness the Roulette Ritual as the actors choose their track for the evening... five minutes before 'curtain.'
Each actor will have several tracks that they may be familiar with, but not polished. This selection will be a surprise to them, as well as the audience.
Part of the fun of this production is going to be the element of the unpredictable and unknown while still performing a 400 year old play!  As an emerging artist collective we are also inviting some more established actors to join inthe fun. These guest artists will be a part of the reading for one night a piece and play the role of the distinguished Menenius. 
LESLEY:
"This project is going to give the actors opportunities that they might not otherwise get in terms of casting. Men will play women, women will play men and it is no big deal. It will also inevitably lead the audience to hear the text in a different way than they would for another production. I believe audiences will jump into the reality that we present to them. My goal is for it to feel improvisational and for the atmosphere to be party-like."
About the Rejects
Reject Theatre Project (RTP) is an emerging artist collective dedicated to creating and producing each member’s PassionProject before disbanding.
We are eight emerging theatre artists based in Philadelphia. We have created a collective that is dedicated to the creation and production of one PassionProject per member. We believe that there are a lack of entry-level jobs in Philadelphia for the amount of young theatre artists that the city is producing. The opportunities available don’t provide an outlet for artistic expression and leadership. Reject Theatre Project will provide fulfilling artistic opportunities to a variety of emerging theatre artists throughout Philadelphia. 
Each of us posess a different artistic focus, aesthetic and skill-set. We have created a mission that will embrace each of these artistic voices and an environment that will nurture creative freedom, risk and collaboration. In exchange for each of our PassionProjects being produced, we will provide each other with mutual support until each vision is fulfilled. It is our goal to complete all eight productions before the end of three years. When our final PassionProject closes, we will detonate and document our journey for future theatre artists. 

What We Need & What You Get
We at Reject Theatre Project feel strongly that artists deserve to be paid for the work they do.  Our payment will simply be seeing our PassionProjects alive on the stage, but we have many artists helping us to achieve this goal who we want to compensate.  We also have various technical and practical needs that will be costing us.  So, we are asking for:


$1,100 for artist pay.  Coriolanus will feature 11 emerging actors.
$2,500 for space rental.  We will need to rent a space for one week of rehearsal and two weeks of performances.
$400 for various marketing and production supplies.  This will include programs, postcards, scripts, possible props, etc.





Other Ways You Can Help
Can't give today?  That's okay! Here are a few other ways you can help:

Like us on Facebook

Check out the other projects on our website.
Volunteer your time!  We're always looking for ushers, house managers, people to distribute flyers, or anything you can think of!  Let us know how you'd like to help or find more information by emailing us at rejecttheatreproject@gmail.com

story:
Maine Playwrights Festival  April 23 - May 4

St. Lawrence Center for the Arts, Portland

Short Summary

Now in its 13th year, Acorn Productions started the Maine Playwrights Festival as part of our mission to nurture theater artists. Over the years we have been proud to present hundreds of world premiere plays, some of which have gone on to be produced at Festivals in New York and elsewhere. For playwrights, this is an invaluable opportunity to see their words interpreted by directors and actors and see how audiences react. For the actors it is a unique chance to originate characters that will set the standard for future productions of the work. For the audience it is an introduction to emerging and established playwrights who live and write here in Maine. Who knows...some day one of these playwrights could be accepting a prestigious award for one of their plays and you can say "I was there when they got their start at the Maine Playwrights Festival!"

Your contribution toward our $3,000 goal helps make it possible for Acorn to provide this important service to our community by helping with overhead costs for this vibrant and exciting new works festival.

The Impact

Your contribution is essential  to bridge the gap between what it costs to put the Maine Playwrights Festival on and what we bring in from ticket sales. Donations of all sizes matter:

Your $25 donation prints ~50 playbills to tell our audience about the plays and playwrights.

Your $50 donation purchases ~5 sheets of lighting gel to paint the stage with color.

Your $100 donation purchases an ad to spread the word about the Festival and fill the house.

Your $300 donation covers the rental cost for one performance.

Your $500 donation covers much of the cost to design and print publicity materials for the festival.

Every donation at every level makes a big difference.

Our 2014 Festival Selection:

  • Josh Brassard - God Visits Lucifer on the Occasion of the Anniversary of the Fall
    "Omniscient mystical being gets drunk and seeks out their former lover, who just happens to be the yin to their yang, on the anniversary of their split, hoping for resolution, but proving that even gods can't do anything when their drunk."

  • ​Sybill Baker​ - The Church of the Divine Potluck
    "The church's fundraising committee discusses everything- except fundraising."

  • Linda Britt - What If...
    "An after-dinner game turns dangerous as alcohol flows freely and the participants reveal closely-held secrets, leading to betrayal and an unexpected resolution."

  • Lynn Cullen - To Whom It May Concern
    "When an angry young convict shares his dream with his good-natured cellmate, he learns that exercising power without compassion is an empty experience."
  • Stephen Dennis - Finish It
    "This play is about how people keep going, despite the puzzles of living."

  • Kathy Hooke - The Sign
    "An elderly, set-in-his-ways man grieving for his wife must decide whether to entrust her beloved car to a stranger from a completely different culture, learning in the process that dislocation and loss can take many forms."

  • Michael  Kimball - Dissagreement at the Dead Boot Saloon
    "Gun control in the wild, wild west "

  • John Manderino​ - Carl
    "Carl tries to justify having murdered his "girlfriend."

  • Jody McColman​ - Schrodinger's Roulette
    "Two brothers are faced with an impossible, life-or-death choice."

  • Laurie Mederios - Incidentally
    "Three agitated characters overcome confusion, trauma, and incessant smart phone use to discover their real roles in each other's lives. "

  • Patricia Mew - The Hurricane
    "Two old friends meet, by chance, at a bar, and have a chat with unintended results."

  • Jefferson Navicky​ - The Purchases
    "A younger brother puts a hex on his older brother in order to steal his wife and his farm, but is the older brother's revenge beyond reason? "
  • Jennifer Reck - Before the Curtain
    "It turns out the real action is in the audience as passive aggressive theatre-goers attempt to gain the upper hand against rivals while waiting for a play to begin."

  • Howard Rosenfield - A Storybook Romance
    "A young man must wrest a book away from his love in order to propose marriage."

  • Shirly Sargeant​ - An Absence of Grey
    "    A devoted professor's wife of thirty-five years must either assign her husband's care to a his twelve-year-mistress from past years, or kill him."

  • Ryan William Shephard - Brinner with Cindy
    "College freshman, Nick Caldwell, returns home for a long weekend with his new girlfriend, Cindy. Nick's already anxiety-ridden weekend takes an unexpected turn when he's forced to face all of his fears in one surreal evening."
  • David Sussmann - Stuck
    "A husband and wife decide to expand their sexual repertoire - and encounter unforseen problems."
    |
  • Erica Thompson - Battle Faire
    "Winter has overstayed her welcome and May has arrived to claim her rightful place. Yet, as we know, Winter never gives up without a fight!"

  • Jo-Anne Walton - The Abyss
    "Steve's been working up the courage to make a declaration to Lauren and it's not going as he intended."

Other Ways You Can Help:

Contributions of all kinds are needed to get us to our fundraising goal and make the Maine Playwrights Festival a success.

Tell all your friends! Pass along the information about this campaign and the Festival. Encourage them to get involved.

Volunteer! Contact Megan Tripaldi at acornacting@gmail.com if you would like to usher, help with publicity, or volunteer in some other way.

Share this fundraising campaign using the Indiegogo share tools!

story:
Short Summary

35 years ago, Kathryn and Kenneth Fredgren started a small arts organization with a big mission, to bring dance to as many in the community as possible. BalletNova continues that tradition today by offering exceptional classes to all ages and abilities and very affordable performances to thousands in our region.

Every spring, BalletNova delights audiences with classical and contemporary repertory in our annual Spring Performance. This year will be no different. We are mounting Act III from La Bayadere - the Kingdom of the Shades. 

La Bayadere is an iconic ballet best known for its serpentine entrance by 24 beautiful ballerinas donning classical white tutus. Our dancers are rehearsing, the lighting designer is creating plots and the set is being built, but we are in need of additional tutus to complete this endeavor. 

What We Need & What You Get

Donations will go directly toward the purchase of tutus for this ballet. The best part is that these costumes can be used long after our performances of La Bayadere have come to a close. Our talented costume mistress can modify these tutus for many more ballets in our future. Your donation will have a long lasting impact!
One generous donor has already donated $1000 to kick off this campaign. Can you join them? All donors receive our eternal gratitude, but some will get to see the tutus in action with free tickets to the show - check out our perks and see what level makes the most sense for you. 
If we don't reach our entire goal, we will still purchase tutus with what we have and keep searching for funders to make up the difference. 

The Impact

BalletNova is the only organization in our immediate area presenting classical ballet productions that the whole family can enjoy. Besides this yearly Spring Performance, we also produce the Nutcracker every December to sold-out houses. Our free ticket program allows numerous school children and their families to see professionally produced dance concerts - often serving as an introduction to live theatrical performances!

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand that not everyone is in a position to donate right now, but there are still ways to help this campaign! 

  • Please get the word out and make some noise about this campaign!
  • Indiegogo share tools make it easy. Post to Facebook, Twitter or Instagram and spread the word!

Thank you for your support.

story:
Our Story

We are Perpetro Independent Color Guard, a new competition color guard based out of Vallejo, CA. More importantly, we're a group of friends who have been spinning and teaching color guard together for years and it's always been a dream of ours to start an Independent Guard here in Vallejo. The rest of our dream consists of becoming a WORLD class guard and competing in WGI FINALS in Dayton, Ohio. Yes, extremely ambitious, but we're really hungry to perform and we've been working hard to get to this point. We have a crazy talented set of spinners/ dancers from all over Northern California as well as a top notch, world class staff and we're all really excited to show you what we can do! 


Perpetro: To complete, accomplish, and perform.


The Impact

By getting the funding we need to exist, we wouldn't just be making many of our own dreams come true, we'd also be providing our home town and the many talented performers here in Northern California with another place to continue their passion for color guard, dance, and the performing arts after high school and for years to come. 


What We Need & What You Get

We've listed our need for a MINIMUM of $600 so anything and everything will help! And if we exceed this goal, we will be even more grateful for your kindness and support. With the funds we raise, we'd be able to put it toward paying off insurance and competition fees, purchasing a performance floor (mat), poles and flags, uniforms, and plane tickets for our trip to WGI FINALS in Ohio. Please take a look at the sidebar for more information on donation amounts and their corresponding fun incentives for helping us out! :) And to make some of these incentives more affordable, we suggest splitting the cost with a group of friends!


Other Ways You Can Help

Please add us as a friend on Facebook (http://www.facebook.com/#!/perpetro.independent) so that you can stay up-to-date with our other fundraisers (if you're local) and with how our season is going! We'd also really appreciate it if you shared our campaign link on your social networking pages as well so that we can reach as many people as possible. Thank you so so sooooo much for your help!

story:
Short Summary

Border control, housing crises, racism, riots- London's East End frequently makes headlines. But what are the everyday stories of those affected by these forces? And  if these forces continue unchecked, what will become of the East End?

Acrylick, a new multimedia collective, shed light  on these questions with our debut show, Jagged Edge. 

The show brings the details of real people's experiences to the stage through dance, film, audio and theatre - opening up grand issues of border control, housing crises and grassroots resistance. 

We've done the work of gathering these details - doing interviews, archive research, film and undercover sabotage.

Our expertise across the arts - from dance to web code, means we can thread them together to make a world class show that does justice to stories.

Now we just need your support to make it happen!  

Tweets, donations, blogs - whatever you can give - your contribution will help us fund essentials, promote the show, and make Jagged Edge's premiere a success. 

Who are we?

Acrylick is a new multimedia collective made up of old friends. We are dancers, theatremakers, artists, coders, designers, anthropologists and radicals. We are mostly women and our family backgrounds stretch from Brasil to India, Finland, Palestine, Eritrea and New Zealand.
To find out all about us click here. 

What We Need:

We have been selected to perform as part of Rich Mix's Radical Ideas season, a programme of radical performances to celebrate the venue's 10 year anniversary. 

This is a huge honour for us, but to do justice to the residents of East London whose voices make our show, to our audience and to our cast and crew, we need extra support. 

Any money you give will be used to:

  • Materials: Support with materials for set building and costumes for this hi-tech, dystopian yet distinctly East London stage. 
  • Technical time: Editing suite time to prepare films and digital designs used in the show. 
  • Outreach: Transport and food expenses so we can reach people whose stories are neglected by the stage, who have been evicted from London, face deportation or are living in poverty and need support to be included in the show. 
  • Essentials: Our cast is made up of young people, many of whom are in poorly paid work. Your contributions can help us to pay for food and travel expenses, and to pay decent wages to these skilled actors and dancers for their time and labour.

What you get:

Check out the perks listed on the side of this page. 

Depending on the size of the donation, we are offering shout outs, show credits, open day invitations, free workshops, free premiere tickets and one of a kind show items to keep forever. 

Other Ways You Can Help

There's plenty of other ways to support us if you aren't able to make a donation, or even if you have but would like to do more:

Share this campaign. 

  • Spread word about this campaign
  • Follow us and make noise about us and our show on social media. 
  • Put us in touch with any reviewers, listings or journalists who might be interested in our work. 
  • E-mail us and we can send you posters and flyers to hand out.
  • Get in touch to let us know if you have an idea on we could collaborate: acrylick@outlook.com
Whatever you can manage will be gratefully received. Knowing we have the interest and support of others is the best motivator to put on a mind-blowing, world-class show. 

Thank you!

story:
Short Summary

Boogaloo is what his father started calling him after a mommy and me class proved that Joe was destined to dance. At 18 months old he broke loose from a circle dance, went to the center of the circle and started to boogie. At that moment I knew what his calling was. At 2 1/2 years old, the earliest anyone would take him,  he began his dance training in tap. Forced to make a decision at age 5 if he would rather continue dance or tennis lessons he chose dance--the rest is history. Tap never really got into his soul--so at age 6 we added hip hop and jazz but it wasn't until he was introduced to ballet at age 8 that he found a true passion for dance. Despite many financial hardships we continued funding his dance career and eventually got him into the academy of arts in Hartford where he also became passionate about modern and choreography.

What We Need & What You Get

Here's where you come in - Joe would very much like to graduate from his arts high school next year while also continuing his training at night. I am a single mother on disability and his father is a shut in on social security battling cancer. I have always struggled to give the best to my son--but can no longer afford the transportation to the bus stop everyday. We estimate the mileage for next school year to be 20,550 and the gas cost to be 2850.00, car maintanance to be 1,200 and replacing his worn out dance clothes and shoes to be 850.00 (he has been dancing in the same tights for almost 4 years).If the goal I have set is not reached then the money will be used to get Joe to his night classes only.

In return for your genorosity you will receive an autographed photo of Joseph during a performance. Should he ever be a famous dancer you will have an exclusive autographed photo potentially worth a considerable amount. For a greater donation you will receive tickets to a show so that you can see the effects of your efforts.

The Impact

Joe has been a key dancer at the Academy of Arts. He is the only person that has danced in a show his freshman year, he has been in dance classes above his grade level and this year he was elected by the staff to be the dance representative for the senior class. Joe needs to graduate from the Academy to have a better chance of getting into college for dance. He already has a few colleges selected but needs your help to get through next year.

His Dedication

It is obvious to me that Joe takes refuge in his dance, it is his life, his therapy, his companion, his passion.Though he talks to his father several times a week he hasn't seen him in almost 2 years --dance somehow lightens the burden of not having a father present in your life. Every day Joe gets up at 5:00--we leave for the bus stop at 5:45 which he catches for 6:30 to arrive at school for 7:30 classes. Academics  end at 1:00 and arts classes begin and go until 4:15. He has 3 hours of dance classes at school. He then takes the bus to Southington where I pick him up at 5:30 and rush him to Woodbury Ballet where he has 2 more hours of ballet. He finally gets home around 9 pm to eat dinner and do homework. On Saturdays he dances at either New England Ballet in Orange or Woodbury Ballet in Woodbury. During Nutcracker season we estimate he dances approximately 30 hours per week. Joe does all of this while maintaing A's and B's in his honor and advanced placement academic classes. His dedication to his craft is limited only by financial and time constraints.

Other Ways You Can Help

Spread the word on Facebook, Youtube, Twitter or any other social networking site available.
story_txt:
Short Summary
Boogaloo is what his father started calling him after a mommy and me class proved that Joe was destined to dance. At 18 months old he broke loose from a circle dance, went to the center of the circle and started to boogie. At that moment I knew what his calling was. At 2 1/2 years old, the earliest anyone would take him,  he began his dance training in tap. Forced to make a decision at age 5 if he would rather continue dance or tennis lessons he chose dance--the rest is history. Tap never really got into his soul--so at age 6 we added hip hop and jazz but it wasn't until he was introduced to ballet at age 8 that he found a true passion for dance. Despite many financial hardships we continued funding his dance career and eventually got him into the academy of arts in Hartford where he also became passionate about modern and choreography.


What We Need & What You Get
Here's where you come in - Joe would very much like to graduate from his arts high school next year while also continuing his training at night. I am a single mother on disability and his father is a shut in on social security battling cancer. I have always struggled to give the best to my son--but can no longer afford the transportation to the bus stop everyday. We estimate the mileage for next school year to be 20,550 and the gas cost to be 2850.00, car maintanance to be 1,200 and replacing his worn out dance clothes and shoes to be 850.00 (he has been dancing in the same tights for almost 4 years).If the goal I have set is not reached then the money will be used to get Joe to his night classes only.
In return for your genorosity you will receive an autographed photo of Joseph during a performance. Should he ever be a famous dancer you will have an exclusive autographed photo potentially worth a considerable amount. For a greater donation you will receive tickets to a show so that you can see the effects of your efforts.


The Impact
Joe has been a key dancer at the Academy of Arts. He is the only person that has danced in a show his freshman year, he has been in dance classes above his grade level and this year he was elected by the staff to be the dance representative for the senior class. Joe needs to graduate from the Academy to have a better chance of getting into college for dance. He already has a few colleges selected but needs your help to get through next year.
His Dedication
It is obvious to me that Joe takes refuge in his dance, it is his life, his therapy, his companion, his passion.Though he talks to his father several times a week he hasn't seen him in almost 2 years --dance somehow lightens the burden of not having a father present in your life. Every day Joe gets up at 5:00--we leave for the bus stop at 5:45 which he catches for 6:30 to arrive at school for 7:30 classes. Academics  end at 1:00 and arts classes begin and go until 4:15. He has 3 hours of dance classes at school. He then takes the bus to Southington where I pick him up at 5:30 and rush him to Woodbury Ballet where he has 2 more hours of ballet. He finally gets home around 9 pm to eat dinner and do homework. On Saturdays he dances at either New England Ballet in Orange or Woodbury Ballet in Woodbury. During Nutcracker season we estimate he dances approximately 30 hours per week. Joe does all of this while maintaing A's and B's in his honor and advanced placement academic classes. His dedication to his craft is limited only by financial and time constraints.


Other Ways You Can Help
Spread the word on Facebook, Youtube, Twitter or any other social networking site available.

story:
About Prison Production

In an economically driven society, whose lives do we choose to value?

“Prison Production” will use theater to teach young people about the US prison system through an exploration of its expansion from the late 70’s to the late 90’s. As the number of young people of color who are affected by the prison system continues to soar, students in this Theater-in-Education experience will explore the effects the economic-based prison industry has on this country and their own communities. As a team of five actor-teachers, we will implement the piece in two 12th grade economics classrooms at Wadleigh High School for the Performing and Visual Arts in Harlem (New York, NY) this spring.

Wadleigh is a performing arts school located in a community whose struggle with racial justice has earned historic attention, and whose pioneering spirit in the arts has captured the imaginations of generations of US performers. Today, Harlem faces problems of over-policing, racially-targeted stop-and-frisk policies, and high rates of incarceration. Despite a lack of difference in drug use between racial groups in New York, people of color, and especially black men, are more frequently arrested for drug crimes, and convicted more harshly, than their white counterparts. Meanwhile, prisons that house these folks are built to alleviate poverty in largely white upstate communities. Educators and academics have tended to ignore this history, which has been decades in the making.

What is Theater-in-Education (TIE)? Theatre-in-Education asks students to utilize various dramatic skills for learning goals outside of the art form itself. TIE utilizes techniques that are particularly useful for learning about history:

  • Group role play to explore the decisions made by people and communities in a particular historical context.
  • Short prepared performances by the Actor Teachers to deliver historical information
  • Interaction with the characters in the story to give advice, ask questions, and understand why and how their situations occur
  • Scene creation by students to reflect contextually and emotionally on what they have learned and draw connections to previous knowledge, and their own lives.

Prison Production

“Prison Production” concerns itself with stories in two New York communities, Harlem (in Manhattan) and Malone (in upstate New York).

In the first class session, students will meet characters in Harlem who are affected by the prison system, interacting with them and their community to understand the economic factors at play.

In the second session, students will step into role as residents of the town of Malone in rural upstate New York in 1998, where plans to build the Upstate Correctional Facility are in the works. The students will attend a town hall meeting in which various residents and policy-makers will speak about the pros and cons of bringing the prison to their town. The students will vote on whether or not to bring the prison to Malone as well as learn about how the real building of the prison affected Malone.

In the third session, students will be able to reflect on the previous two sessions and make connections between them, looking directly at how they are economically tied and what policies in history led to the dramatic increase in prison building in rural upstate communities in the 1990’s.

As actor-teachers, we are trained to not only perform theater, but lead students in critical reflection on the historical situations so that they may develop their own understanding of why and how choices were made, and how those choices have impacted their communities.

Why support this project?

Your donations will help support the development stages of this project, which include:

  • Five professional actor-teachers - each one of us will receive a stipend, not a salary, for the project. We’re in it because we are passionate about the topic and about exploring it with young people. Yet getting paid will help us legitimize this work in the field and allow us to devote the time and energy to the project that it deserves.
  • Our expenses - we’ve kept our budget low, but we still have a few expenses, such a props for the theater, and printing and copying.

After we implement the project in late May, we'll reflect on how it went and hopefully be able to pitch it to more schools from there!

As independent artists on this project, we are working without institutional support. We’re exploring what it takes to create work on our own, in partnership with a school, without the structure of an organization backing us up.


The Impact

When we met the students at Wadleigh last winter, they were eager to get up out of their seats and interact with themes such as power in an embodied way. Performed theater engages young people in learning about the historical and economic details of the topic through individual stories. Interactive techniques like role-play not only deepen this learning, but allow young people to contextualize what they have learned. TIE can both teach facts and involve students in empathic learning that positions history as a living topic, instead of a series of fixed truths. In doing so, students will develop an understanding of how political and economic choices were made and how they might engage with similar choices as they navigate their world. In a neighborhood directly concerned with issues of mass incarceration, the students will critically reflect on their own lives and communities and raise questions for their futures. 

For our team, this piece builds on our previous TIE and applied theater work implemented around the world. We have created pieces about the Japanese Internment Camps, the Congo, and the war in Afghanistan. We have collaborated with teachers and students all over New York City, leading applied theater workshops and residencies. Additionally, members of the team have led theater workshops in prisons and jails. Through all of these experiences, we continue to build our capacity to critically engage students and communities in issues relevant to them and in pursuit of social justice.

There are other ways you can help

  • Post the link to this campaign page on your facebook, twitter, blog, or website. Help us increase visibility! Share with others who may be interested.
  • Talk with your friends and family about the prison system - Who is in prison in our country? Why? How is your community affected by incarceration? What role can theater have in exploring the impact of the prison system?

Any contribution will go a long way toward helping us implement this piece. Thank you and check back with us for updates!

story:
After a highly-successful run in St Andrews, students from the Mermaids Theatre Fund are taking Angels in America to the world's largest arts festival: the Edinburgh Festival Fringe 2013.

Considered by many to be one of the greatest American plays of the 20th century, Angels in America is a work of epic proportions in two parts, of which this is the first. Millennium Approaches spans the years of 1985-1986, during the Reagan Administration and the beginning of the AIDS epidemic in New York City. Through his characters and their conflicts Kushner artfully conveys the changing psychological state of America in the years leading up to the dawn of the millennium. With a cast of eight actors playing multiple characters, Kushner toys with our perceptions of life, death, dreams, reality, spirituality, hope, faith, love, and loyalty in this ‘Gay Fantasia on National Themes’.

***** (The Saint, www.thesaint-online.com)
**** "The entire cast was so in tune with each other, as well as their own characters, that the whole thing resembled a master class in ‘how it should be done.'" (The Stand, www.stand-news.co.uk)

We will be performing August 11-17 at 10:20pm at C Venues, C Aquila Temple.  For tickets, directions, and more information go to: https://www.edfringe.com/whats-on/theatre/angels-in-america-part-one-millennium-approaches

We were very lucky to be one of the two shows chosen by the Mermaids Performing Arts Fund to go the Fringe, and we couldn't have been happier when we were accepted to perform at the fabulous C Venues!  However, Angels has a lengthy run-time (especially for a Fringe show) and with higher venue prices we found we still needed additional funds to cover all our costs in Edinburgh.  

That's where you come in.  With your donation of whatever you can give you will help us cover the various costs involved in putting on a production of this magnitude. These include:

  • The fee for our beautiful performance space, C Aquila Temple.
  • The cost of our publicity (posters, flyers, etc.) so we can bring in the best audiences possible to see our show.
  • Additional props, set, and costumes to help us put on a production that truly represents the calibre of student theatre from the University of St Andrews. 

Putting on a production of Tony Kushner's Angels in America is a daunting task for any company, but taking it to the Edinburgh Fringe Festival is another matter entirely.  We will be the first production of Millennium Approaches to go to the Edinburgh Fringe Festival (ever) precisely because this is such an ambitious production to stage in a festival setting.

But that's what makes this show so special.  Our production of Angels in America will have a pared-down style, thereby making the epic elements of the play all the more spectacular by contrast.  As in our St Andrews run, this will be a fundamentally actor-driven event, with an attention to the text as our main focus.  Above all, we want this production to tell the stories of Kushner's characters, stories that – while firmly rooted in the culture of the late 1980s – remain universally relatable in the 21st century.  Angels deals with issues ranging from illness and disease (mental as well as physical) to how we construct our identities within a culture that is a melting pot of political, racial, religious, and sexual beliefs.  

Angels in America is not only a masterful piece of theatre, it tells a timeless story about how we choose to live our lives in a multi-faceted and constantly changing world.  Please help us tell that story by giving us your support!  

In the words of the Angel: The Great Work Begins...

 

Share this page with as many of your friends as you can, and be sure to come see the show in August!

You can get your tickets here:  https://www.edfringe.com/whats-on/theatre/angels-in-america-part-one-millennium-approaches

Like us on our Facebook page:  https://www.facebook.com/AngelsInEdinburgh

And follow us on Twitter:  https://twitter.com/AngelsinEdi

For more information on the Mermaids Performing Arts Fund go to: www.mermaidstheatre.com

story:
It is with great excitement and anticipation that I announce the launching of the "60 Dance Lovers for $100" in 60 Days Campaign" to open the Tannery World Dance & Cultural Center in Santa Cruz, CA! Every donation you give, no matter the amount, will help our nonprofit launch into the community. So if you can't give $100, do what you can! Your support and your spreading the word will grow our campaign and help us reach our goal to secure a permanent home for our organization!

About Us

I have been living in the Santa Cruz community and involved in the dance arts, international and cultural studies, and children’s dance education for nearly two decades, and hold a BA in Dance. After observing a need for more accessible opportunities for at- risk youth in our community, I wanted to create a dance and cultural center that would enable world and contemporary dance artists to thrive and teach, while also providing access for these youth to study with dance professionals under full scholarship. The dance arts empower youth, build confidence, and encourage leadership through training and dedication. The Tannery World Dance & Cultural Center will provide this opportunity through our classes, enrichment programs, and cultural events right here in Santa Cruz!


The Hub

Tannery World Dance & Cultural Center is getting ready to launch into the Santa Cruz community, but we still need your help! Our fundraising campaign, "60 Dance Lovers for $100 in 60 days” will secure funding necessary for us to open Tannery World Dance & Cultural Center as a permanent and stable dance arts organization! The Tannery World Dance & Cultural Center will provide a dance hub for world and contemporary dance artists to teach, create, collaborate, and perform, while linking them with at-risk youth in the community who benefit from scholarship study, artistic mentor-ship, and the discipline of dance study. Our organization is founded on the principle of providing sustainability around the artistic field of dance, as a “working home” for the development of the artist and for the community they live, teach, and are informed by. Directly linking at-risk youth to this “hub,” and the professional dance artists working through it, Tannery World Dance & Cultural Center will act as an advocate and purveyor of cultural awareness, artistic development, and community outreach though the dance arts.

 

Become a Community Founder

Donating to our campaign means we will get our doors open! Plain and simple.We specifically need YOUR donation to help our organization get up and running in our permanent space. Your donation will directly fund the cost of securing the lease, dance equipment like ballet barres, sound equipment, internet, phone, lights, and insurance. Our community support has been crucial up until this point. A private donor has fully funded the cost for our essential, sprung dance floor. Our affiliate, Artspace, has committed $15,000 towards our electrical improvements, and since August we have raised over $4,300.in online donations. Join our Community of Founder's and help make the biggest impact towards our launch.


My love for the dance arts has given me great opportunity, knowledge, and joy throughout my life. Launching the Tannery World Dance & Cultural Center means that dance artists can THRIVE and youth in the community will forever be impacted by the gift of the dance arts, and in turn, broaden our community’s awareness, success, and cultural understanding. I can’t begin this work without you!

With Gratitude,

Cat Willis

story:
Help build the fundraiser of fundraisers to welcome our soldiers home!

Our mission is to celebrate the returning soldiers with a music, film and television event involving as many people, from as many walks of life, as possible.  This fresh incarnation of music with film is part of that.


“I fear they do not know us. I fear they do not comprehend the full weight of the burden we carry or the price we pay when we return from battle.”  

Those are the words of the nation’s highest-ranking officer, Admiral Mike Mullen, addressing the corps of cadets at West Point earlier this summer.  He was talking about us, the American people, the very people those men and women, in the name of freedom, risked their lives for.   I want “us” to know “them” -- their selflessness, courage, honor, loyalty, sense of humor.  Because all that they are is the heart of who we are as a nation.  And we’re forgetting that.

“The best way to find yourself is to loose yourself in the service of others.”  Mahatma Gandhi

story:
Here's our story:

Same Planet Different World Dance Theatre was founded in 1997; since then, SPDW Dance has become a prominent presence within the Chicago dance community. Focusing on dance that is evocative and enjoyable, SPDW showcases a diverse repertoire that consists of works from nationally renowned choreographers while incorporating the styles of classical and contemporary modern dance, jazz, and improvisational experimentation.

 

Now the time has come to spread the passion of dance to the rest of the country, and hopefully one day, the rest of the world! SPDW Dance has received a once-in-a-lifetime opportunity to travel to New York City to perform their A.W.A.R.D. Show! 2010 finalist piece, Grey Noise, at the A.W.A.R.D. Show showcase at The Joyce Theater June 2nd & 3rd, 2011!

 

Grey Noise is a work for five dancers choreographed by SPDW Artistic Director, Joanna Rosenthal, and inspired by film noir of the 1940's and 1950's. With its intense physicality and emotionality, Grey Noise depicts an environment where people are on edge, unpredictable, and hard to control.

 

Why is this important?

SPDW Dance has a goal to inspire their audiences, both big and small. We realize that the audience is just as important as the moves themselves; without our audiences we would not have the opportunity to perform- ever!

 

This exciting venture will offer a chance to inspire a new audience in a new place; we will reach another outlet to express how exhilarating modern dance truly is while generating a greater appreciation for the arts!

 

Let's Break it Down!

We need $2,000 to get us to New York City to perform in the A.W.A.R.D. Show showcase! Here's exactly where your generous donations will go:


 ($2,000) Plane Tickets for our dancers to get to the show so we can perform!

 

This is the ONLY place your donations will go! We really appreciate every penny, no matter how small the contribution because it will still bring us one step closer to getting on that plane!

 

 To show how much we appreciate your contribution we have set up a few perks that are waiting to be claimed!

 

 *Meteorite*

Donate at least $25 and you will receive a Same Planet Different World Dance Theatre T-SHIRT! This is the same T-shirt worn by our company members, so you are now a part of our organization!

 

*Moon* 

Contribute $100 or more and you will get two tickets to an upcoming SPDW performance! We will make sure we get you some of the best seats in the house! You take care of us and we'll take care of you!

 

*Star*

Donate $250 or more and you are welcome to attend company classes with Same Planet Different World! You will be able to learn from award winning Artistic Director, Joanna Rosenthal, and dance with our company members!

 

*Constellation*

A $350 or more contribution will take you behind-the-scenes with Same Planet Different World; you will get to attend a rehearsal before an upcoming performance! You will get an inside look at the intense physicality of our dancers but also have the opportunity to hang out with them! Don't worry- they are pretty entertaining!

 

HELP US OUT!

Share the news with your family, friends, co-workers, and even those random people you meet on the street! Help us bring the joy of SPDW's modern dance to a new city so we can generate even more appreciation of the performing arts!
 
Simply share this link via your facebook, myspace, twitter, tumblr, linked-in, e-mail, and whatever other social media outlets/blogs there are! We really appreciate your help and cannot do this without you!
 
If you want to learn a little bit more about us, check out spdwdance.org to see our promotional video!

& MOST OF ALL,
THANK YOU!

story:
"Congratulations, you've won second place..."

The Young Playwright's Urban Retreat is an annual program in New York City, where teenagers who want to write for the stage meet and are immersed in the New York theater experience, from work shops and seminars, to seeing actual shows. As someone who has entered the Philadelphia Young Playwright's Competition numerous times, I would love to go on this retreat. I'm a junior in highschool now. Writing is what I really want to do in life and I've always loved working in theater. This trip would help me with my goals in life, and prepare me for the
 road ahead.


And I can't afford it.


The deadline for submissions is May 2, 2011. Between now and then, I need to raise $1750. I don't have many ways to get that sort of money. And time is running out. If you donate, you're helping a girl realize some portion of her dreams in life. And for that, I thank you.

story:
Lesser America

Way back in 2010 a playwright by the name of Jonathan Blistein and actors Daniel Abeles, Nate Miller and Laura Ramadei worked together on a play: Keep Your Baggage With You (at all times). The sold out houses and critical response boded well for the collaboration, to say the least:

"The Holy-Grail of adventurous theatregoing" - NYPress

"Thrillingly austere, provocatively perplexing...Blitstein has an ear for honest dialogue...the whole cast should pack for Hollywood soon." - The Advocate

Following the success of the production, the team decided to officially join forces and form Lesser America.  Soon thereafter the company was offered an unprecedented residency by the iconic Theater for the New City and set in motion plans for their 2011-2012, inaugural season. The company will present its first official show, the world premiere of Squealer, opening May 5. Written by Jonathan Blitstein, Directed by Daniel Talbott:

Squealer follows an ambitious pork farmer with a roving eye who moves in with a widowed single mother and her teenaged daughter. When he can't get what he wants, things get bloody. A full-on taste of America's poverty-soaked obsession with consumerism and our unquenchable thirst for more, whether it's meat, or love, or both.

Find out more about the production by visiting www.lesseramerica.com.

Where You Come In

When they joined forces, the Lesser Americans decided that they would commit their energies to producing highly entertaining, accessible, affordable theater.  This means insanely cheap tickets relative to the quality work we have coming your way. We've pulled off a few miracles already to make this happen but there's still some spare change necessary to make ends meet. Despite the invaluable blessing of residency at Theater for the New City and incredible generosity of the many individuals working with and supporting this young production, we need your help to get this thing off the ground and get it to the public. Programs need printing, costumes don't buy themselves, and lighting equipment don't come cheap neither...and though many of our members and incredible colleagues would work for free, we're committed to compensating, at least in some small way, every artist involved in our productions.

YOUR DOLLARS KEEP THE DREAM ALIVE, AND THE DREAMERS FED. And even if you count yourself among those who needs the ticket to stay cheap, throwing us literally a few bucks now means a few bucks you save later. We mean it when we say every little bit counts. Check out our perks to see what we can offer you in return for your most generous giveage.

ALSO: ALL DONATIONS TO THIS INDIEGOGO CAMPAIGN ARE TAX DEDUCTIBLE. You will receive an email confirmation from Fractured Atlas, saying you donated to our partnered, sponsoring company: Red Elevator Productions.

Other Ways You Can Help

Like us on facebook: facebook.com/lesseramerica

Follow us on twitter: twitter.com/lesseramerica

Share our links, pages, and website with EVERYONE YOU KNOW.

COME SEE OUR SHOW: www.lesseramerica.com

story:
Trees for the Wood

Written by Nic Adams and Anna Lauren

-Workshop Premiere

-The Red Room (85 E. 4th St., NY, NY)

-August 6, 7, 13, 14 and 15, 2012

-Buy tickets here: http://www.brownpapertickets.com/event/261115

The play centers on 16-year-old Rochelle Acker and her family. Her mother, Regina is an eternal-adolescent, her father, Alton: curt and commanding, and her grandmother: mysteriously estranged. When Rochelle learns that Alton is gravely ill, she seizes the opportunity to reunite her father and grandmother.

Full of poetry, folk songs, movement, and magic, Trees for the Wood is a dark and gymnastic coming-of-age drama that reveals the power of sacrifice, honesty, and love.

What We Need

In order to make this production a reality we need $3,000 by August 2012. Projected costs include four weeks of rehearsal space, a performance venue in New York, actor and director stipends, lighting, scenic, and costume design.

The Impact of Your Donation

When writing this play we were inspired by the question, "how do you heal a family?" Many experience conflict within a family; a black sheep, an estranged relative, an unnamable betrayal.

It is in moments of great conflict when the power of the human spirit is revealed. Those journeys that seem most daunting are often the ones that give birth to heroes. At the heart of this play is the journey of our hero, Rochelle Acker. She must reach deep within, overcome the obstacles that are her dark family secrets, and revive love and acceptance within her family.

You may be in a position like Rochelle yourself. Are you equipped to become a hero? Are you fighting for honesty and love? Together, Nic and I believe in the power of the human spirit, which is why we wrote this play and decided to produce it in New York City, an epicenter of theatre.

We need your help to share this story of personal power. It is only through your contribution that we can make this production possible. Donate now and become a hero to this play!

What YOU Get!

We can't wait for you to get involved. Feel free to browse the perks we offer in thanks for your donation. Come August, we will share this piece with you and with the world! It will be a big moment in all our lives. We thank you in advance for your support and donations.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you're interested in the development of Trees for the Wood, check out our webstie at: http://treesforthewood.squarespace.com/. We will be posting exclusive media, artwork, interviews with the design team and cast, songs from the show, as well as more practical information, such as production and ticket info when it becomes available.

Share this story with your family and friends by inviting them to view this campaign using your social media platforms! It's fast and simple, and you'll be a part of a community that shares a commitment to the powers of sacrifice, honesty, and love.

Contact us:
Nic Adams: nic.treesforthewood@gmail.com
Anna Lauren: anna.treesforthewood@gmail.com

If you're interested in making a larger, tax-deductible donation, visit our website at http://treesforthewood.squarespace.com/.

Interested in learning more about our show? Check out our promo video, here.

For a sneak peek at the music of The Lost Shores click here.
 
"Only she can save your body. Only love can save your soul." - Rochelle Acker, Trees for the Wood

story:
What is HUDSON THEATRE WORKS?

Started in 2011, Hudson Theatre Works has been buliding a reputation as a theatre company with great artists, high production values, and a dedication to quality, professional theatre. 
Hudson Theatre Works believes that the only way to build a professional theatre is to help to develop and produce new works.
To that end Hudson Theatre Works is producing its second premier production of plays that were first presented in it's annual PLAYWORKS festival.

THE PLAY

In “Jackson is Gone,” Natalie and Sam Grayson are out for a quiet Sunday morning walk when they find themselves embroiled in an argument with a stranger who kidnaps their dog, Jackson. They report the incident to the police, and their case is assigned to a friendly but vaguely threatening sergeant who insinuates himself into the most hidden parts of their lives. The play examines the nature of irreparable loss, the consequences for our lives, and the slow disappearance from the world of the ancient touchstones we have always relied on for comfort and sustenance.

JOANNE HOERSCH (Playwright) is a recipient of a 2012 grant from the NJ State Council on the Arts for her play, Jackson is Gone, which was also selected for a roundtable reading at the Lark Theatre. Her play Starring Elizabeth was part of Hudson Theater Works 2013 PlayWorks series and was also part of New Jersey Playwrights Theater 2014 reading series. Her one act Bunnies, based on her experiences as a Playboy Bunny, was part of the 2015 PlayWorks series.  Prior to becoming a playwright, she was a fiction writer. She received a Woolrich fellowship for fiction from Columbia University, was a semi-finalist in the Heekin Foundation’s national short story contest, and was a 1998 grantee from the NJ State Council on the Arts for her short story, Josie Going Places.  She is a 2014 honorable mention in Glimmertrain for her short story Lilacs.  She is currently working on a new play about the Romantic poet Percy Shelley.

WE NEED YOUR HELP!!

Hey, you've heard the expression freedom isn't free?
Well neither is theatre! We love to produce great theatre, and if you didn't know already, it generally costs more to produce shows than ticket sales alone can cover. 
That's not just us, some of the biggest theatres in the country
That's why we depend of the generosity of our patrons....YEAH YOU!!! :)
We're hoping to raise $7500.00 to help offset the costs for this production.
Your contributions will help pay for costumes, lighting rentals, advertising, scenery, props, and dare I say PAYING OUR ARTISTS!

Making a difference

Making professional theatre isn't easy, but HTW has solid experienced people steering the ship.
HTW'S founders and Board of directors are dedicated people who volunteer their time and professional skill to bring a quality product to the people of north Jersey and surrounding communities. Our Director, Frank Licato has been working for over 30 years as an actor, director, producer and teacher. He has collaborated with such theatre luminaries as Joseph Chaiken and Peter Brook and he was named best actor in Boston for his performance as Lt. Vukov in the American premiere of Barry Collin’s Judgment.  He was nominated for an Obie award for his performance in “Deathwatch” by Jean Genet, which the New York Times called a ‘performance on another plane’.  He acted at the American Repertory Theatre, the Delaware Theatre Company and the Boston Shakespeare Company. He has appeared on TV in Third Watch, Sidney Lumet’s 100 Centre Streetand with Frank Sinatra in First Deadly Sin. 

As a director his production of Neil LaBute’s The Shape of Things was selected as a regional finalist in theKennedy Center’s American College Theatre Festival.

Producing Director Gregory Erbach, grew up in Hudson County and has been working on and off the stage in professional theatre for over 30 years. Currently the Assistant Electrical Construction Boss at the Metropolitan Opera House, he has been an actor, stage manager, producer, carpenter, electrician and technical director for hundreds of productions at venues such as the American Place Theatre, Steppenwolf Theatre, The Weston Playhouse, The American Jewish Theatre, The John Houseman and The Equity Library Theatre. He was the technical director for John Leguizamo's first two Broadway Video productions Mambo Mouth and Spic-O-Rama for HBO. 

Every little bit helps

If all our friends send in 10 bucks, we'd reach our goal easy.
(Yeah, we have a lot of friends) You know who you are!!! :)
That's not to say we wouldn't appreciate some larger contributions, We put in a lot of hours, more money allows us to further AMP UP the quality.
HUDSON THEATRE WORKS is a 501 (c) 3 not for profit theatre, so any amount you donate above the value of any perks are tax deductible.

Other Ways You Can Help

Whether or not you can afford a donation, if you've read this far, you're probably up to help us in some way, so help us MAKE SOME NOISE! Please share the link to this campaign with your friends on social media. Believe us, it helps!

Thank you and we'll see you at the theatre!

story:
Vous cherchez une cause à laquelle donner pour bien débuter l’année 2016 et ainsi faire une Bonne Action dans le confort de votre salon? Nous vous en offrons l’occasion! Encouragez une compagnie de théâtre francophone d’Ottawa! Par ce don en argent, vous témoignez de votre grand cœur et de votre amour de l’art, tout en  contribuant à l’essor d’une jeune compagnie théâtrale.

Le projet

Le Théâtre de Dehors en collaboration avec l’artiste Sasha Dominique est fier de présenter à Ottawa la première mondiale francophone de la pièce Le lilas africain, traduction de la pièce The Syringa Tree de Pamela Gien

En 2009, Sasha Dominique a assisté à une représentation en anglais de cette pièce et elle est tombée sous le charme du texte et du défi que cela représente pour une comédienne : seule en scène pendant 1h40 à interpréter une vingtaine de personnages âgés de 3 à 82 ans, par la versatilité de la voix et du corps.

Ça y était : elle venait de trouver son prochain projet artistique. Avec l'appui incontestable de toute l'équipe du Théâtre de la Vieille 17, qui a à l'époque pris le projet sous son aile, Sasha a pu présenter deux étapes de sa traduction en mises en lecture, qui ont toutes deux été dirigées par André Perrier, également metteur en scène actuel du spectacle.   

Voici enfin venu le moment tant attendu, 7 ans plus tard,  de la production. Nous sommes fébriles et enthousiastes à l’idée de vous présenter ce morceau d’anthologie portant sur l’Afrique du Sud.


Représentations

Les représentations à Ottawa en février 2016 sont présentées au Studio Léonard-Beaulne (135, rue Séraphin-Marion) aux dates et heures suivantes :

mercredi 10 au samedi 13 février: 20h00

dimanche 14 février : 14h00

Ce dont nous avons besoin &
Ce que vous obtenez en retour

Notre équipe administrative ainsi que les concepteurs impliqués dans ce projet travaillent avec cœur et acharnement afin de vous offrir une pièce d’une grande qualité artistique. Bien entendu, une production théâtrale ne peut pas se concrétiser sans apport financier : nous avons déjà obtenu une partie des fonds provenant des trois paliers du gouvernement (municipal, provincial et fédéral) mais ceci ne couvre pas tous nos frais de production.

C’est là où VOUS « entrez en scène » chers parents et amis. Nous avons besoin de votre appui afin de rendre ce rêve réalisable.

Votre contribution (de 10$ à 100$) nous aidera à couvrir les frais suivants :

·  Le matériel publicitaire (cartons promotionnels, affiches, programmes)

·  Le matériel pour la construction du décor (sans oublier la balançoire!)

·  Le matériel promotionnel (captation vidéo, vidéos promotionnelles ponctuelles, photos)

·  La mise en marché (relations médias, recherche de commanditaires, frais d’inscription à des événements de promotion auprès des diffuseurs)

·  Le salaire des personnes assignées à ces diverses tâches

En guise de gratitude pour votre générosité, voici ce que vous obtenez de notre part afin de vous remercier pour votre don :

Don de :

10$ - 25$  - un courriel de remerciement personnalisé;

50$ - mention sur les médias sociaux

70$ - mention sur les médias sociaux et 10$ de rabais sur le prix de votre billet

100$ - mention sur les médias sociaux et une paire de billets gratuite pour la représentation de votre choix

L'impact

Votre contribution témoigne de votre soutien apporté à la vitalité des arts de notre région tout en encourageant les artistes locaux à continuer d’aller de l’avant dans la concrétisation de leurs projets, afin que ceux-ci passent du rêve à la réalité.

D'autres façons de nous aider

Vous n’êtes pas en mesure de nous aider financièrement mais souhaitez tout de même nous encourager? Voici d’autres façons de contribuer :

·  PASSER LE MOT

·  PARTAGER et TWEETER notre campagne Indiegogo sur les médias sociaux

·  Soyez BÉNÉVOLE lors de nos représentations! Vous assisterez GRATUITEMENT à la représentation! Intéressé? Envoyez un courriel à Sariana à l'adresse suivante : infodehors@gmail.com

story:
Brief history of the project

My name is Liliya Lifanova and I am a multidisciplinary artist based in New York. 

Three years ago I picked up a copy of The Waste Land by T. S. Eliot and it resonated in a truly meaningful manner. It was clear to me that Eliot's work reflected my fragmented life experience within the labyrinth of antiquity in generative form that produced a vision that was unexpected, exciting - uniquely my own. 

Since then, the poem has accompanied me through 5 residencies across the country and 7 different studios in NYC. During these paths, I have been patiently and persistently writing the score, hand-crafting the sculptures, performative objects, paintings, drawings, and garments that will 'frame' Flight Over Wasteland, a sculptural installation, performance, and film. 

Hiroya Miura, a composer of Japanese origin, joined me on this journey in 2015. His thoughtful work and ideas on the text gave me the energy to press on in creating this project and to see it through to the end. 

Earlier this year my proposal was accepted at the Knockdown Center to take place in April 2017. This is a tremendous opportunity. Knockdown Center has an exceptional art program and was recently described as one of the most exciting art venues in New York City by Roberta Smith of the New York Times. I am thrilled to present this work in such a breathtaking space and exploit the cinematic possibilities of this venue in the film version of the piece. 

Timeline

The plan is as follows:

During one week in April 2017 my sculptural installation and Hiroya's sound installation  will be on view and open to the public at the Knockdown Center.

Elements of FOW sculptural installation (img. John Curry Studio courtesy of Rooster Gallery)

During the same week we will be shooting Flight Over Wasteland, amidst the aforementioned sculptural and sound installation and in other parts of Knockdown Center, with the talented Chicago filmmaker Yoni Goldstein, with whom I've had the privilege to collaborate on this project in the past.

On April 15, 2017, we will debut the performance of Flight Over Wasteland. This will be followed by Q&A with curator Jodi Waynberg  and the presentation of a specially designed cocktail (Mud Flight).

 

What We Need 

Our total budget is $21,300.

- Knockdown Center is generously covering the production costs of the live performance

- Other committed funding

= $15,700 still to raise

3/4 of this amount will be spent on the production of the film. This includes the cost of 1 week rental of audiovisual equipment, such as cameras, lenses, lighting, microphones, gear, etc. This money will also be used to pay the cinematographer, the film crew, project manager, the cast (16 actors), as well as the editor's fee.

1/4 of this amount will cover the expenses of producing the remaining sculptural and sound elements of the installation, effect props, as well as to cover the Lighting Designer fee. 

I am asking for your support for the following expenditures:

FILM PRODUCTION 

Camera Rental & Gear

Lighting

Cinematographer Fee

Drone / Operator Cost

Gaffer Fee

Lodging for crew

Actors fees

POST PRODUCTION

Video Editor Fee

SCULPTURAL / SOUND INSTALLATION

Microphones

2 Large Sculptures / Effect Props

 

What You Get

Every dollar of your contribution will go toward the production of the performance and the film. Those that contribute to the project will receive recognition in the program and in film credits, tickets to the live event, artworks, or project ephemera.

 

$10 - Thank You, Talc!

Thank you for your support! And for spreading the word. Your name will be on the program and in the film credits.

 

$25 - Gypsum

 + MP3

Thank you! Your name will be on the program and in the film credits. We will send you a link to download the mp3 file from Hiroya in May 2017.

 

$50 - Calcite

 

1 tote bag that you can pick up at the Knockdown Center on April 15. Your name will be on the program and in the film credits.

 

$100 - Fluorite

 + 

 

1 ticket to Flight Over Wasteland performance at the Knockdown Center and 1 specially designed drink (Mud Flight). Your name will be on the program and in the film credits.

 

$300 - Apatite

 + 3 

1 ticket to Flight Over Wasteland performance and 1 set of 3 signed Limited Edition Photographs (edition of 20) of Flight Over Wasteland (will ship in May 2017).Your name will be on the program and in the film credits.

 

$500 - Orthoclase

1 double sided Character study painting on paper by Liliya, 17 1/4 x 8 1/2 inches to 18 x 14 inches (ideally will ship in May, 2017, but if this is a holiday gift, 8 are ready to ship now). Each painting is unique. Pictured here is 1 of 8 currently available pieces. Your name will be on the program and in the film credits.

 

$750 - Quartz

1 double sided Fragment Painting on canvas by Liliya, size ranges between 10 3/4 x 14 inches to 11 x 27 1/2 inches (ideally will ship in May, 2017, but if this is a holiday gift, 10 are ready to ship now). Each painting is unique. Pictured here is 1 of 10 currently available pieces. Your name will be on the program and in the film credits.

 

$1000 - Topaz

 2+ 2 

+

2 VIP ticket to the dress rehearsal of Flight Over Wasteland Performance, 2 Mud Flight drink with the cast, 1 Garment by Liliya from FOW project (available in May 2017). Your name will be on the program and in the film credits.

 

$3000 - Corundum

STUDIO VISIT  +  + 2 

 + ASSOCIATE PRODUCER CREDIT

Studio Visit with Liliya, Mud Flight drinks for you and your +1, 2 VIP Tickets to Flight Over Wasteland, and the title of "Associate Producer" in Flight Over Wasteland film. Your name will be on the program and in the film credits.

 

$5000 - Diamond

STUDIO VISIT + 1 ARTWORK

+ 2 

+ EXECUTIVE PRODUCER CREDIT

Studio visit with Liliya in which you can select 1 artwork of your choice within 2k price range, 2 VIP tickets to the performance of Flight Over Wasteland at the Knockdown Center, and the title of "Executive Producer" in Flight Over Wasteland Film. Your name will be on the program and in the film credits.

 

I am excited about the pieces I am offering in order to raise the money for Flight Over Wasteland. Every piece has been single handedly created by me (except for Hiroya Miura's spectacular music, and the tote, which only bares my design), and represents a small victory toward the complete vision of this project. Each of you who donate will have beautiful drawing, painting, garment, music, or tickets to the live event by April/May 2017, credits for your contributions, and my heartfelt gratitude. To view more of my work and previous projects please visit my website www.liliyalifanova.com

 

The Impact

This is the most ambitious project I have ever set out to do in NYC. Your contribution will help realize its successful completion.

Please note, your contribution to this project also supports a diverse community of creatives in NYC.

 

Risks & Challenges

After this project receives funding, we certainly still have some challenges to face. However, I know that with your support, we’ll have the momentum and support to overcome these challenges as they arise.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Please share my campaign with your network and follow me on Facebook and Instagram.

Are you super organized and great with people? Be our Production Intern January - May!?

 

Flight Over Wasteland is a sponsored project of Fractured Atlas, a non­profit arts service organization. Contributions for the charitable purposes of Flight Over Wasteland project must be made payable to “Fractured Atlas” only. Any contribution above the value of the goods and services received by the donor is tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law.
