We need lodging for Bettie, Deedee and Janet from July 13th through August 30th.  Can you be our host??
For investments at a certain level, we will offer contracts with interest in future commercial productions.
For angels who love us, we will offer fun perks along with our eternal love and gratitude!


The Impact

It is our mission in life to uplift and inspire people.  Although our audiences laugh out loud during WAITING FOR JOHNNY DEPP, they also walk away feeling hopeful and inspired.  It is our goal to reach people everywhere with our message of love and hope. 
As we mentioned above, we've had 3 successful productions in the past. But this is our chance to take it to the next level and beyond!! 

Other Ways You Can Help
Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

Please get the word out and make some noise about our campaign!!
Don't forget to use the Indiegogo share tools!

We love you and Rita loves you!!  Deedee, Janet and Bettie

story:
Buy a Ticket, Launch a Season

River & Rail Theatre Company is a professional, non-profit theatre company producing relevant stories for diverse audiences in Knoxville, TN. Through the power and beauty of theatre, River & Rail seeks to unite people from all backgrounds to experience and participate in stories that embody our shared humanity. 

This December, River & Rail will launch its first season of shows as we open our new downtown home: The Old City Performing Arts Center. We are inviting our community to launch us into this next big chapter by purchasing season tickets now. 

Our 2019-2020 Inaugural Season will include three productions: THE UNUSUAL TALE OF MARY & JOSEPH'S BABY music and lyrics by Don & Lori Chaffer, book by Chris Cragin Day (December 11 - 22, 2019); CONSTELLATIONS by Nick Payne (March 4 - 15, 2020); SWEAT by Lynn Nottage (April 22 - May 3, 2020). 

Get 'em While They're Cheap

Take a look at our donor perks. When you donate to this campaign and select a ticket perk, you'll actually be reserving your ticket(s) at a discounted rate. Every ticket available here is discounted by at least $5. If you don't want to miss out, here's what we suggest:

  • Donate here at the Season Subscriber level, and be sure to select the ticket perk.
  • When the campaign ends, we will reach out to you to book your exact dates.
  • Then invite your friends to join you when you come see three killer shows at our new 225-seat performing arts center.
  • Be sure to check out all the perks. You may want to give in bigger ways.

The Impact

When you donate here, not only will you be investing in Knoxville's burgeoning arts scene, but you'll be among the first to see theatre in the Old City Performing Arts Center, a 225 seat black box performing arts space in the heart of Downtown Knoxville. River & Rail is proud to call this promising new space our home; however, we are even more excited about opening this space up to other performing arts groups in Knoxville. Can you imagine what a hub of music, theatre, poetry and dance this space could be some day? Come check out a show and catch the vision with us.

Catch the Vision

Here's the thing: opening a new performing arts space in a historic downtown neighborhood sure can take a lot of time, money, and energy, and thats just where we've been for the last year and a half. Now that the building is done with Phase 1 of our renovations, we can open it to the public and invite you all in to dream with us. When casting a vision, it is always better to show than to tell, right? What better way to "show" than to produce three of them! And that's the plan with UNUSUAL TALE, CONSTELLATIONS, and SWEAT.

Regardless of where we land at the end of this campaign, we will be producing these three gorgeous shows, but when you purchase your tickets now, you help build up the reserves we've lost while investing in our building over the past year. Your donation reminds us that what we do has value in our city, that it matters to you, and that when the time comes to show up in the audience and experience the magic with us, you'll be there.

Other Ways You Can Help

Share, share, share! If you aren't able to donate right now, you can still help us in big ways by sharing! 

  • Share our campaign on your social media platforms.
  • Text or email your friends directly and share what we are doing with them.
  • Make a good old-fashioned phone call and tell your friends about our first season and the Old City Performing Arts Center.

Thank you!!

story:
What's the BIG Deal?

THE BIG COUNTRY is a BIG new play by Chris Barlow, Premiering this July at T. Schreiber Studios!

In Short

Written by Chris Barlow and Directed by Morgan Gould, THE BIG COUNTRY combines the Great American Play with the Great American PowerPoint Presentation to finally explain those bizarre alien creatures known colloquially as Human Beings.

Here at THE BIG COUNTRY, our mission is to explain the bizarre behavior of the beings known as Homo Sapiens Sapiens, in an effort to ensure that any extra-terrestrial visitors are thoroughly prepared to handle our species' complex emotional responses to such common events as:

- CRISIS

- LOVE

- STRESS

- and, BREAKFAST


The Mission

As the winner of T. Schreiber's New Works Project, we've received a generous grant of $1,000 to cover production costs and help pay our out-of-this-world designers, but that money stops short of covering our EXTENSIVE video and projection related costs (have you ever shopped for a projector?? I'd rather get abducted!).

That's why we're looking to YOU to help make "Austin Babbish's Landfill Lecture Series" a reality! Our goal is to raise matching funds (another $1,000) to cover all our projection-related costs and complete the vision of this wild, technically-ambitious new play.

We've got lots of great perks, including many that will let you secure your tickets to the production now!


Who's Involved

- There's AUSTIN BABBISH (Todd Woodard): An eldest son, an older brother, a former fiancé, and also a former gay lover (coincidentally to the former fiancé’s brother).

- His mother, CAROL BABBISH (Ellen Tobin): The widowed-then-jilted matriarch of the Babbish clan, struggling to understand her apparent failures as both a mother and a lover.

- His younger brother, JACKSON (Matthew Ballinger): The kid brother who abandoned his family in their darkest hour and ran away with the girl of his dreams (who may or may not be a terrorist).

- And the ever-mysterious DANA GREGORY (Mary Monahan): Jackson's "fiancé", who's just trying to get back to her freedom fighting after suffering a crushing defeat in the jungles of Sri Lanka.


More Info at thebigcountry.us!

Plus you can Like us on Facebook! And follow Austin on Twitter!

story:
Our Story

(Introduce yourself and tell your campaign's story. Make sure to cover the who, what, where, when and how of your campaign.)


We are extremely grateful to all who will help us reach the $1000 benchmark in our ANDROMAC campaign!

Thanks you so much for your help on this journey, and please continue to contribute generously and to spread the word far and wide all the way from the rubble of Troy, to the green plains of Attica, to the beautiful land of Epirus, to the magnificent Chicagoland !! With your help and trust, we the European director NoÃ©mi Schlosser and a team of wonderful Chicago actors can create an extraordinary show!


The Play

ANDROMAC was written by the French Classisist RACINE in 1667. First performed in the Queen's appartements at the Royal palace in Paris, NDROMAC was a huge succes from the start. Over the centuries, many great actors have graced the stage in productions of ANDROMAC. The part of Hermione was one of Sarah Bernhard's favorite roles.


Plot Synopsis

Shortly after the violent fall of Troy, Andromac, widow of Hector, becomes the slave of the Greek King Pyrrhus. She is pregnant with the next heir of Troy, a fateful birth that could threaten all the Greeks have fought for in the war.

Orestes demands the death of this unborn baby on behalf of the Greeks as this child might one day avenge fallen Troy. Pyrrhus refuses but only because this refusal might win him the heart of Andromac.

Meanwhile, Princess Hermione, that once loved Orestes, has been sent to wed Pyrrhus as a peace offering  by her father, but she is still waiting.

Everybody is loving and waiting for someone who doesn't love them back....

Love , Politics, Passion, Jealousy...Tragedy ...Theater....


The Present

We are very happy to be able to rehearse daytimes for FREE at the ACT ONE studios in Chicago! We will hold daily rehearsals whenever the actors are available and not at their dayjobs.At night and on weekends we are using our own living rooms until tech week. We are gratefull to our girlfriends and roommates for letting us invade the private home space to create this show.


The Promise

We promise to create a show you will not forget and each of you contributors will be a part of our journey! 

A show that is cutting edge, takes risks, raises questions.
A show that will mix media's, be bold and of artistic quality.

A show that might have been written in 1667 but that is actual, engaged and engaging!


We Ask You

Please help us make this vision a reality. In exchange for your contribution, you will receive some fun, one-of-a -kind perks, listed in the sidebar, as well as our promise to bring this work to the stage with all of our passion, dedication, craft and knowledge. Below is a brief breakdown of how the money will be spent.


Every gift is deeply appreciated. 

Every gift makes a difference. 

Every gift is tax- deductible.

Thanks for helping us reach our goal!


The Team

NoÃ©mi Schlosser DIRECTOR

European director who has recently chosen Chicago as her new artistic home, NoÃ©mi Schlosser founded her company Salomee Speelt in Belgium in 2004 ( www.salomeespeelt.be) and since then, has performed, directed and produced theatre successfully throughout Europe and in Morocco, New York and Chicago. 


Victor Allen aka ORESTES:

Mr. Allen is from Sulphur Springs, Texas.  He has numerous credits all over the city ranging from stage to screen.  Most recently he was seen at Red Tape's presentation of "Five Flights" and his critically acclaimed sketch revue "Oh Brother, the Rent was Due" with The Dancing Pig, the sketch group formed from his time at the Conservatory at Second City.  A devout Texan, Mr. Allen would like to thank his wonderful family, and the pretty little Mouse that helps keep him warm at night.


Kelsey Jorissen aka HERMIONE:

Kelsey Jorissen hails from Cottage Grove, Minnesota. Her most recent roles include Sarah in Life Separates Us at the Oracle Theatre, Fraulein Kost in Cabaret dir. Barry Brunnetti at the Merle Reskin, Hermia in A Midsummer Night's Dream dir. by Catherine Weidner, and Cherie in Bus Stop dir. Dan Kerr-Hobert at The Theatre School. Kelsey graduated from The Theatre School at DePaul University with a BFA in Acting.


Candice Johnson aka ANDROMAC:

As a 2011 graduate of the Act One Studios Conservatory Program, Candice has been seen recently in Children of a Lesser God (Footlik Theatre), Life Separates Us (The Oracle) and Wilma Rudolph: an American Hero (Historical Perspectives for Children) in the fall of 2011.  While performing all these roles she was preparing herself for the role of a lifetime, new mom, to the bouncing baby boy she is carrying during this production.  She is please to have on more opportunity to stage a production with an amazingly talented cast before taking her maternity leave.  Both mom and baby would like to thank all the cast, friends and family for their encouragement, support and watchful eye during the process that is pregnancy.  Maximus and Mommy make their last pregnant performances before what is sure to be a stage worthy entrance in May!


Daniel Behrendt aka Phyrrus

was too busy learning his lines to sent his resume...


Eli Taylor ASSISTANT DIRECTOR

Eli hails from Niles, Illinois and is the Artistic Associate for New Initiatives and Outreach and an ensemble member for ShPIeL-Performing Identity. He is a recent graduate from the Theatre School at DePaul University where he received a BFA in TheatreArts. Assistant Directing Credits included, Cabaret (Directed by Barry Brunetti) and Puss in Boots (Directed by Julia Neary). Local Acting credits included: Isaac in North Bank, Suzhou Creek (Directed by David Chack), Old Deuteronomy in Cats, Joseph in Joseph and theâ€¦, and Albert Peterson in Bye Bye Birdie (Directed by Karen Hall), Eli also serves on the board of the Association for Jewish Theatre.


Performances

Opens March 16th at 7.30 PM

Other shows March 17-23-24-30-31

@ ThinkTank Theatre, 1770 W Berteau, Suite 207 ( near Montrose Brown line CTA) Chicago


Tickets     $ 12

Call          646.469.7992 begin_of_the_skype_highlighting            646.469.7992      end_of_the_skype_highlighting

Online      www.brownpapertickets.com/event/226746


What We Need & What You Get

(Break it down for folks - how much money do you need and where is it going? Be transparent and specific and be sure to address where the money goes if you don't reach your entire goal. For example, do you have other funding sources? Does part of the campaign still happen? Ensure people they are not just buying you dinner. Use this area to tell people about your unique perks, too!)


What is the money for?

Like often in Chicago, the artists come last... even if they are the ones without whom there simply would not be a show...so if they are not being paid even if we reach 1000 dollars, where does the money go?

- the rental of the performing space ThinkTank

- the front of house people

- a small budget for costume, set and props


If we raise more than $1000, every dime would go towards

- a small marketing campaign and a person to help promote our shows

- the possibility to print a minimum amount of posters and flyers to be hung in selected places

- pay a stipend to all the good people who are otherwise helping out with their crafts for free and out of the  kindness of their hearts: the light and sound person, the poster designer, the marketing person, the press release person...

- a stipend to compensate the sweat, blood and tears of the actors and the creative team


What are we prepared to do?

Our special perks include beauty packages from Arbonne, all organic ( while supplies last)

But also for gifts of $250 you can choose all different very personal perks offered by our team, including the choice of a three course Belgian homecooked meal, a photoshoot session/headshot or a workshop in sign language to name just a couple.


Other ways YOU CAN HELP

So even if you donate just a dollar, you can still help by spreading the word and inviting your friends, family and colleagues to participate in this ANDROMAC fundraiser through Indiegogo!

And off course we do invite you to come and be an audience member during our shows!

Thanks so much, a million times!


NoÃ©mi Schlosser and the whole ANDROMAC team!

story:
Our Story

The Urban Arts Institute (UAI) activates young minds, nurtures creative expression, provides a sense of real purpose in life, and weaves together community through art, creativity, mentoring and the joy of self-expression.

 

The UAI is a free youth program that gives at-risk youth in the under-served African-American communities of Asheville an opportunity to collaborate, mentor one another, and be part of meaningful performance experiences that unite the community. UAI is lead by founder and creative director, Michael Hayes, and offers dance, drama, video and music classes, mentoring, and essential after-school cultural programming.

 

The after school and Summer Enrichment classes at the UAI provide youth with the focus they need to achieve their dreams while limiting potential susceptibility to gang activity. The UAI serves 200-300 students from the most under-served communities in Asheville, NC on a daily basis. Youth meet for three hours a day, five nights a week, and are required to maintain good grades. The UAI is a way to rearrange the way our young people view their lives by activating them in a creative way.


Hey! My name is Shy Underwood, and before I started dancing with the Urban Arts Institute, I wasn't really doing nothing but, just sitting at home watching TV, and sometimes hanging out with friends. Now that I have joined the Eternity dance group, it has been a blessing. It helped me out, because it keeps me out of trouble, and stop me from being around negative people/things. Eternity to me is not just a dance group, its like a second family. Mr.Hayes is like a father figure to me.The IndieGoGo project, is helping us raise money so that we can get vans, etc. and we really appreciate everything that you guys are doing to help us out. Thanks everyone for supporting us, and helping us raise money. God Bless.


UAI's Impact & This Campaign

The space where these young people meet serves as both a safe haven and a creative studio.

 

By having a consistent, reliable and inspiring place to go, the young people who need this program and the creative outlet that it provides are able to maintain the supportive and positive forward movement that it instills in them.


We have signed a lease on a space in downtown Asheville that is perfect for our needs. Now we need your help to transform this space into a welcoming, fully-equipped rehearsal, performance and study home.


As programming for The UAI is free to participants, generous donations and support go a long way towards providing positive opportunities. The purpose of this campaign is to raise the funds to help us establish and fit out the new home for the kids of the UAI. The funds raised will match a generous donation of $10,000 from within the Asheville community.

 

Please help provide these students with the opportunity to both express themselves creatively and learn a set of skills that will empower them to become community leaders and active participants in creating a better society. Let these young people know that you value their creative expression and continued growth.

What We Need & What You Get

Funds received will go towards:

  • Rent for our permanent space
  • Completion of necessary up-fit to make the space permit ready and operable as a rehearsal space, classroom, dance studio, music studio, audio-visual editing studio, and performance space (i.e. mirrors, lighting, flooring, any permit specific compliance to meet building codes)
  • Purchasing a van for transporting youth to rehearsals and performances
  • Purchasing necessary equipment (i.e. desks, chairs, kitchen equipment, music equipment, computers, software, etc.)

 

Any and all funds raised will go towards meeting the most urgent, prioritized needs. Regardless of funds raised, this campaign will make every effort to move forward.  

 

For your contributions, the greatest thing we have to offer is our gratitude. As extra incentive, we have established some perks to express our appreciation including:

  •  Live as Art Bumper Stickers
  • Limited Edition UAI t-shirts
  • VIP passes to the UAI performance of your choice and private hip-hop dance class for 4 with the students. 
  • Private Performance by the UAI dance troupe Eternity at a special event hosted by UAI in Asheville NC.

Other Ways You Can Help

Stay connected to us. Join our Facebook page, have a look at the videos and pictures in our Gallery, and PLEASE spread the word and pass on this information with anyone you think might want to participate in supporting this program's future.
story_txt:
Our Story

The Urban Arts Institute
(UAI) activates young minds, nurtures creative expression, provides a sense of
real purpose in life, and weaves together community through art, creativity,
mentoring and the joy of self-expression. 
 
The UAI is a free youth
program that gives at-risk youth in the under-served African-American
communities of Asheville an opportunity to collaborate, mentor one another, and
be part of meaningful performance experiences that unite the community. UAI is
lead by founder and creative director, Michael Hayes, and offers dance, drama,
video and music classes, mentoring, and essential after-school cultural
programming.
 
The after school and
Summer Enrichment classes at the UAI provide youth with the focus they need to
achieve their dreams while limiting potential susceptibility to gang activity.
The UAI serves 200-300 students from the most under-served communities in
Asheville, NC on a daily basis. Youth meet for three hours a day, five nights a
week, and are required to maintain good grades. The UAI is a way to rearrange
the way our young people view their lives by activating them in a creative way.


Hey! My name is Shy Underwood, and before I started dancing with the Urban Arts Institute, I wasn't really doing nothing but, just sitting at home watching TV, and sometimes hanging out with friends. Now that I have joined the Eternity dance group, it has been a blessing. It helped me out, because it keeps me out of trouble, and stop me from being around negative people/things. Eternity to me is not just a dance group, its like a second family. Mr.Hayes is like a father figure to me.The IndieGoGo project, is helping us raise money so that we can get vans, etc. and we really appreciate everything that you guys are doing to help us out. Thanks everyone for supporting us, and helping us raise money. God Bless.


UAI's Impact & This Campaign

The space where these
young people meet serves as both a safe haven and a creative studio.
 
By having a consistent,
reliable and inspiring place to go, the young people who need this program and
the creative outlet that it provides are able to maintain the supportive and
positive forward movement that it instills in them.

We have signed a lease
on a space in downtown Asheville that is perfect for our needs. Now we need
your help to transform this space into a welcoming, fully-equipped rehearsal,
performance and study home.

As programming for The
UAI is free to participants, generous donations and support go a long way
towards providing positive opportunities. The purpose of this campaign is to
raise the funds to help us establish and fit out the new home for the kids of
the UAI. The funds raised will match a generous donation of $10,000 from within
the Asheville community.
 
Please help provide
these students with the opportunity to both express themselves creatively and
learn a set of skills that will empower them to become community leaders and
active participants in creating a better society. Let these young people
know that you value their creative expression and continued growth.


What We Need & What You Get

Funds received will go
towards:


Rent for our
permanent space
Completion of
necessary up-fit to make the space permit ready and operable as a rehearsal
space, classroom, dance studio, music studio, audio-visual editing studio, and
performance space (i.e. mirrors, lighting, flooring, any permit specific
compliance to meet building codes)
Purchasing a van for transporting youth to rehearsals and performances
Purchasing necessary equipment (i.e.
desks, chairs, kitchen equipment, music equipment, computers, software, etc.)


 
Any and all funds raised
will go towards meeting the most urgent, prioritized needs. Regardless of funds
raised, this campaign will make every effort to move forward.  
 
For your contributions,
the greatest thing we have to offer is our gratitude. As extra incentive, we
have established some perks to express our appreciation including:



 Live as Art Bumper
Stickers

Limited Edition UAI
t-shirts
VIP passes to the
UAI performance of your choice and private hip-hop dance class for 4 with the
students. 
Private Performance
by the UAI dance troupe Eternity at a special event hosted by UAI in Asheville
NC.




Other Ways You Can Help
Stay connected to us. Join our Facebook page, have a look at the videos and pictures in our Gallery, and PLEASE spread the word and pass on this information with anyone you think might want to participate in supporting this program's future.

story:
Our Story

In 2008, eight friends gathered in a loft and decided to start a company focusing on creating and producing collaborative events that ignite celebration. We've now grown to 15 members and are producing events all over the city of Chicago.

We are a multidisciplinary company that is committed to cross-pollinating the arts in innovative ways. Our structure functions in four departments that are deeply collaborative: Dance, Art, Music and Theater.  The Inconvenience creates, produces, and curates works that challenges perspectives and ignites social dialogue.

In our three year existence we have produced two music series, two short-play festivals, three variety events, a new play development series, an original dance/rock concert, and co-produced theatre with such diverse theatrical companies as A Red Orchid , Aboutface, Mary-Arrchie and Steppenwolf. 

The Inconvenience is committed to staking its claim in the cultural landscape of Chicago. We have worked with over 250 different artists and companies throughout Chicago and hope to continue this work in 2012, with your support.


The Impact

We are raising funds for our 4th season- 1 full year of programming, beginning in January 2012 with our Art show "The Little Things" and a world-premiere play by company member Ike Holter, "Hit the Wall" at the Steppenwolf Garage. Come spring, The Inconvenience will produce a kick-ass music festival, and a dance show that will excite all five of your senses!


But it is impossible without your support. The Inconvenience must raise $5,000 in order to begin the year with these two exciting events and build momentum to finish out our year right.


Please help us create these extraordinary events by donating today.


What We Need & What You Get

We need your support- whether its $5, $15 or $50, it means a great deal to us, and we want to thank you for it! Besides everything you see on your right (for what amount you donate) you get to be a part of our community, and a collaborator to our mission.


This means a great deal to us, and we hope it means a lot to you!

Other Ways You Can Help

Unable to throw us $$$$ right now? Share on your social network of choice, email, text message,or phone call-- we'd very much appreciate it!

story:
Terre Unité Parker and her interdisciplinary team of collaborators present...

The Honey Land

The Honey Land is part installation, part performance, using video, soundscape and organic art forms to create a place out of time that inspires new ways of being together and experiencing the environment.
 
Artistic Director Terre Unité Parker (a former company member and production manager for Anna Halprin) leads our interdisciplinary team of collaborators from New England, Canada, and California. Since October 2011 we have performed two invitational showings and at Parker's MFA graduation from Goddard College (Plainfield, VT) in February 2012.
 
On June 23rd we will present this work to the public for the first time! Please consider a donation to support production costs, video documentation, and artist stipends for our public premiere.
 
The Honey Land is a rare opportunity to dip into the world of the senses. The installation explores utopian visions of connection between people and the natural enviornment.
 
This project is supported in part by a grant from the Northampton Arts Council, Inc. and donation of materials from Southworth Paper Company, Turners Falls, MA. All artists have donated their time, talent, equipment, and production support!

Any support you can imagine is appreciated!

Please help us get the word out by joining our Facebook event (https://www.facebook.com/events/322401107832293/) and forwarding this video to your community (link to the video at https://www.indiegogo.com/thehoneyland). Buy your ticket today by contacting terreunite@gmail.com.

Thank you!

We hope to see you in The Honey Land.

Sincerely,
 
Terre Unité Parker, Artistic Director
Collaborators: Patrick Brennan, Iu-Hui Chua, Sarah Coates, Sky Elizabeth Halm, Meara McGinniss, Rachel Rhein, Sakura Shimada, Kristen Stake, Nyx Zierhut

story:
Gutenberg! The Musical!

Doug Simon and Bud Davenport are authors of a big, splashy new musical about printing press inventor Johann Gutenberg. In need of support they perform a backers’ audition for some of the biggest producers in New York. They have no actors, no sets, and no costumes. But Bud & Doug can sing, dance and most importantly, they have HATS!

Developed by Scott Brown and Anthony King at the Upright Citizens Brigade Theatre in NYC, this two-man musical spoof puts you right in the action of these two aspiring playwrights trying to get their show to Broadway.

Our Story

We are 2 seniors in the Entertainment and Arts Management program at Drexel University in Philadelphia. We have to complete a senior project that pertains to our field of study and that uses the tools taught to us over our last 4 years.

We decided to combine our individual focuses of study and produce a show. Gutenberg was introduced to us in a contemporary musical theatre class the beginning of our Sophomore year and we have fallen in love with it ever since. Last winter we decided that we were gonna take that our love for the show and produce it! 

What We Need & What You Get

To help fund Gutenberg! The Musical! we're looking to raise $1250 which will go towards costs for production and marketing.

Marketing Costs include:

- Printing of materials (Posters, Flyers, Programs)

- Design Costs

- Advertising Costs

 
Production Costs include:
 
- A few Props
 
- Hats
 
- Furniture
 
- Venue Fees
 
Contributions start at just $10 and go all the way up to $250. This is not a one-way street. If you look over to the right part of this page you can see some perks that you’ll get by helping us out, named after some fonts that would not exist without, Johann Gutenberg.
 
**You will be contacted via email to reserve your tickets**
 
*** Cameo is on first come first serve basis. There are 2 available for the 3 performance run. If you would like to donate on that level, but do not want to make the cameo, you can opt out***

Other Ways You Can Help

Word of mouth is one of the most useful marketing tactics around. We would be forever gratefull if you could help spread word of this campaign and the show.

Check out our Official Facebook Event: http://www.facebook.com/events/141529459352264/

Come see the show!

MAY 30 @ 8PM

MAY 31 @ 8PM

JUNE 1 @ 8PM

At The

Black Box Theatre 

URBN Center Annex

3401 Filbert Street

Philadelphia PA 19104

story:
Hello, my name is Nicole Goodwin and I am raising a campaign for travel, food and lodging funds in order to travel to the 2012 Split This Rock Poetry Festival. My goal is to participate in the festival with my project "In Search of Glory: How Vets Heal Through Writing."
 
Description:  This is a group reading of veteran writers who utilize the exercise of writing as a therapeutic resource, as well as a way to become self-empowered through the act of self-expression and inform the public at large about the issues that face many veterans, especially returning veterans of the Afghanistan and Iraq era.  The reading hopes to encourage the reshaping of the image of veterans, allowing the public to view them as people who although have experienced a great deal but who can still contribute to society in a positive and constructive manner.
 
My goal here is to show American society how to utilize the arts in order to help veterans heal themselves and cope with the aftermath of war and the development of such disorders as Post Traumatic Stress Disorder, Traumatic Brain Injury and Military Sexual Trauma.


Here is the Price List rundown:

Split This Rock Trip Estimate

Chinatown Bus (Roundtrip): $17.50 per trip = 17.50*2= $35

DC Transit: Metrobus 7-Day pass= $15

                    Metrorail 7-Day pass=$47

Room & Board (Hostel): $29-$45per person/per night= $45*5= $225

Food: $30-$40 per night= $40*5= $200

Estimated cost of trip $522.00 + $100 (emergency funds)= $622.00


It may seem like you are only funding a trip, but you are not you are funding a revolution that may help save thousands of veterans lives.  Your contribution would be greatly appreciated but so would the contribution of your friends, relatives, co-workers, etc. So please spread the word, and don't be afraid to contact me with organizations wishing to sponsor this empowering endeavor.

story:
Short Summary

The media may have moved on to other topics, but the need for Hurricane Sandy relief is still very real. The Pennsylvania Burlesque Festival has pledged to donate a portion of ticket proceeds to Habitat for Humanity's Disaster Relief fund.

The PA Burlesque Festival delivers two world-class shows at Plays and Players Theatre, Delancey Place, Philadelphia on March 8 and 9. Friday March 8 is "FRIDAY NIGHT DELIGHT," headlined by Deanna Danger (Richmond) with a special appearance by Penny Starr, Sr. (Philadelphia.) Saturday March 9 is "THE BIG REVEAL" wherein 16 performers from across the USA and Europe compete for the Crystal Corset Award and $2300.00 in cash prizes.

Over the past 3 years, our producer, Brooke Au Buchon, (AKA show hostess Madame Corsetiere,) has donated nearly $10,000.00 to non-profit charities from the proceeds of ticket sales. It is her wish, and the wish of our cast, to use the PA Burlesque Festival to help Habitat for Humanity get Sandy-ravaged families back into their homes and back on their feet. 

What We Need & What You Get

We are asking our fans and friends to help us meet our expenses so that we can donate a substantial portion of our ticket sales to Habitat for Humanity's Disaster Relief Fund.
 
Our performers travel hundreds, sometimes thousands of miles to entertain our fans, so we provide them with nice lodgings during their stay with us. We are asking that you help us meet our hotel expense of $3,000.00 so that we, in turn, can donate the same amount, if not more, to Habitat for Humanity.
 
In addition to donating funds for Hurricane Sandy relief, we are also collecting non-perishable food items at both shows, to be given to the NJ FoodBank. Habitat for Humanity and the NJ FoodBank are both working selflessly to sustain Hurricane Sandy victims through these bitter winter months. Together, we can help them continue their good works.
 

What do you get? Aside from the good feeling that comes from making a difference, perks for donating to our campaign include:

  • Autographed PABF posters
  • FaceBook and Twitter mentions about our donors and/or their businesses
  • Advertising and "Special Thanks" on www.paburlesque.com
  • Tickets to the PABF shows!
 
Our campaign funds are delivered regardless of whether or not we meet our $3,000.00 goal. We hope to exceed $3,000.00 so that we can donate more of our proceeds to Habitat for Humanity.

The Impact

The PA Burlesque Festival receives wonderful media coverage. It is our wish to use this attention to help spread awareness of the ongoing need in NY and NJ presented by the aftermath of Hurricane Sandy. Every mention helps, and it is our pledge to donate ticket proceeds equal to the amount this campaign earns. You can help Habitat for Humanity make sure that home is where the heart is.

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you are not in a position to donate to this campaign, you can still make a big difference. For donors and supporters alike, please help us spread the word by:
  • Sharing the web URL for this campaign on your Twitter, FaceBook, with your email contacts, and with a link on your website.
  • Follow us on Twitter @PABurlesque
  • Like our fan page at www.facebook.com/PABurlesque
  • Share our webpage www.PABurlesque.com
  • Join our FaceBook event at https://www.facebook.com/events/332668423514337/
  • Know anyone who writes content for the media or a blog? Tell them what we're doing, and have them contact us at info@paburlesque.com for the scoop.
  • Join us for the shows by getting your tickets at www.paburlesque.com and bring a non-perishable food item.

The PA Burlesque Festival is an event full of love and excitement, and we want to share our spotlight with this important cause. Thank you so much for your support and kindness.

story:
Hello world! We are Bess Welden, Ann Tracy, Julia Langham and Karen Ball - an informal collective of Portland, Maine theater artists working together to co-produce the world premiere of Bess’ new one-act play, MADELEINES. As part of Portland Stage’s Studio Series, the show will run November 18-22. For performance dates/times and ticket info: http://www.portlandstage.org/studio-series/.

We’re super excited about the creative team for the project, which includes Portland-area professionals: Karen Ball & Julia Langham (actors), Ann Tracy (director), Meg Anderson (set), Chris Fitze (sound), Michaela Denoncourt (lights), Jewels Murphy (props), and Andrew Hesselbart (stage manager).

MADELEINES is about family recipes, sibling rivalry, and unexpected revelations. Think of it as a short story for the stage. Debra has returned to her childhood home to care for her declining mother Rose, an exacting baker who supported her daughters with a successful cookie business. When Jennifer, Debra's older sister, arrives for Rose's funeral, shared memories and old sibling grievances boil to the surface. As the sisters confront their loss, a startling secret about their mother’s favorite Passover recipe emerges, changing everything they thought they knew about themselves, each other, and their family. 

(all photos courtesy of Snowlion Repertory Company)

Early audiences have called the play “moving” and “powerful.” One fan wrote: “You truly captured the mixture of guilt and anger and love that siblings often carry for each other, especially when it comes to caring for aging parents.  Your sisters were real, and honest, and believable, both in their struggles with each other and in…themselves.”

We need to raise $2,500 to reach our overall budget of $4,000. The great news is that Portland Stage is providing performance space, box office services, and help with marketing, so our overall production costs are very low. Business sponsorships from Dean’s Sweets, Maine Home Connection, Churchill Events, Artisan Hair Salon, and in-kind support from Running with Scissors Artists Studios  plus ticket sales will get us partway to our goal, but we still need your help. With just six weeks before Opening Night, we are turning to you to ask for contributions to honor our commitment to pay artists for their work. All Indiegogo funds will directly support modest stipends for the nine artists involved in the project.

In exchange for your contribution, you’ll have the satisfaction of knowing you helped bring a brand new play to life - especially one written, directed and performed by women. You’ll also get a fun perk or two. We promise to bake your reward cookies with as much flavor and care as the play’s characters would demand.

Other Ways to Help

Once you’ve made a contribution (thank you!) you can help us a few other ways:

1)  Send a link to this campaign to other people you know who love to support new plays or might connect with the themes of the show.

2)  Come to a performance and see how your generous contribution helped make it happen. Call 207-774-0465 or order online http://www.portlandstage.org/studio-series/

3)  If you aren’t anywhere near Portland, Maine but want to see the show, contact us with theaters or one-act play festivals in your area where we can submit the script for consideration.
story_txt:
Hello world!
We are Bess Welden, Ann Tracy, Julia Langham and Karen Ball - an informal
collective of Portland, Maine theater artists working together to co-produce
the world premiere of Bess’ new one-act play, MADELEINES. As part of Portland Stage’s Studio Series,
the show will run November 18-22. For performance
dates/times and ticket info: http://www.portlandstage.org/studio-series/.

We’re super
excited about the creative team for the project, which includes Portland-area
professionals: Karen Ball & Julia Langham (actors), Ann Tracy (director), Meg
Anderson (set), Chris Fitze (sound), Michaela Denoncourt (lights), Jewels
Murphy (props), and Andrew Hesselbart (stage manager).
MADELEINES is about
family recipes, sibling rivalry, and unexpected revelations. Think of it as
a short story for the stage. Debra has returned to her childhood
home to care for her declining mother Rose, an exacting baker who supported her
daughters with a successful cookie business. When Jennifer, Debra's older
sister, arrives for Rose's funeral, shared memories and old sibling grievances
boil to the surface. As the sisters confront their loss, a startling secret about
their mother’s favorite Passover recipe emerges, changing everything they
thought they knew about themselves, each other, and their family.  (all photos courtesy of Snowlion Repertory Company)Early
audiences have called the play “moving” and “powerful.” One fan wrote: “You truly captured the mixture of guilt and anger and
love that siblings often carry for each other, especially when it comes to
caring for aging parents.  Your sisters were real, and honest, and
believable, both in their struggles with each other and in…themselves.”
We need to
raise $2,500 to reach
our overall budget of $4,000. The great news is that Portland Stage is providing
performance space, box office services, and help with marketing, so our overall

characters would demand.

made a contribution (thank you!) you can help us a few other ways:

Send
a link to this campaign to other people you know who love to support new plays
or might connect with the themes of the show. 
2) 
Come
to a performance and see how your generous contribution helped make it happen. Call
207-774-0465 or order online http://www.portlandstage.org/studio-series/

story:
Who is Laurel Hostak?

  • You know, with the pink hair?
  • For the past few years, I've been your apprentice, your assistant, or your supporter--now I'm creating something of my own, and I can't wait to share it with you.
  • I bet you didn't know I have a Bachelor of Science in Playwriting. I bet you didn't know Playwriting was a science.

What is Kingfisher?

  • Kingfisher is an original solo piece currently being developed for the 2015 SoLow Fest. The piece will run June 27-28.
  • It's an evening of ritual and mythology about the creation of the universe, loss of innocence, stormy weather, and Paul McCartney. With songs. And drinks.
  • It's also going to be performed in a BLANKET FORT.
  • Yup, just like when you were a kid (or last week in your apartment), you can join me in an awesome comfy fort and we'll go back in time together.

What We Need

SoLow Fest is the coolest because it promotes low/no budget art by up-and-coming artists. That said, we need a coupla bucks to give this piece its best go. Here's where your donation will go:

  • Materials to build a massive blanket fort and get COZY
  • Art supplies and books -- for the piece, I'll be creating a lot of weird and wonderful props from recycled paper and book pages
  • The ingredients for a signature Dark & Stormy cocktail (for audience members 21+)
  • Some thank-you dollars for our amazing hosts

What You Get

  • There are a few levels of giving and various perks to show my love and gratitude!
  • Kingfisher is a text-based performance, and higher-level donors will receive handwritten thank-you cards that include a passage of language from the show
  • Give $100 or more and receive a handmade paper prop from the show along with your thank-you card

Other Ways You Can Help

Maybe you don't have change to spare, but here are other ways you can help:

  • If you have old or unwanted books lying around, I will take them off your hands, destroy them, then turn them into something beautifulish. Contact me privately if you have books you'd like to donate!
  • Share this campaign on Facebook, Twitter, Instagram, Ello, Tumblr, paint the link on your belly at the naked bike ride, whatever your social network is, it helps get the word out!
  • Come see the show! June 27-28

story:
Nuestra Historia / Our Story

"Gertrude, una supérheroina con nombre peculiar"  es una obra de teatro musical escrita por Marianella Pantoja y Carla Valdivia. Dos amigas que se juntaron para hacer lo que más les gusta: TEATRO.  

Nos tomó varios días, meses, y por último dos años en tener la última versión de nuestra obra, entre lecturas con amigos que nos ayudaban a mejorar las ideas, salidas a cafés a la medianoche, y horas de horas creando e imaginando este mundo que es la Ciudad 8, sus personajes y las canciones que hemos creado. Lo presentamos a varios teatros de nuestra ciudad: Lima, y a los meses recibimos una llamada del MALI (Museo de Arte de Lima) avisándonos que el proyecto había sido escogido y que nos daban el espacio para una temporada. ¡Qué emoción! ¿Y ahora qué?

------------------

It took us days, months, and two years to have the last version of our play. We had many reading with friends who helped us and gave us feedback, we went to coffee places at midnight to get inspired, hours and hours working and creating this imaginary world: CITY 8 (CIUDAD 8), and its characters and songs that we also wrote. Once it was finishes, we presented it to many theatres, until one of them called MALI (Museum of Art of Lima) telling us that our play had been selected! We were so excited! Now what? How do we get the money for this?

-------------------------


Para hacer realidad este sueño de ver la Ciudad 8 y sus superhéroes en acción, necesitamos de soñadores como ustedes que nos ayuden a hacerlo realidad. 

To make this dream come true of seeing Ciudad 8 come to life and the superheroes we created in action, we need dreamers like you who can help us.

--------------------------

Con tu ayuda podremos pagar todo lo que se necesita para hacer Teatro: la música original que se está componiendo, la escenografía hermosa de la Ciudad 8, el vestuario de cada uno de estos nuevos súperheroes y villanos que la habitan, los micrófonos que debemos alquilar para que ustedes disfruten de las canciones en vivo, al fotógrafo, al sonidista, a los asistentes, en fin, todo lo que involucra hacer una obra creativa y de calidad como la que queremos hacer.

With your help we can pay all that is needed to put on a play: music that is being created, sceneries of Ciudad 8, costumes of our superheroes and villains, microphones that we have to rent to they can sing our fun songs, the photographer, technicians, assistants, many many things needed to create a quality play like we want to do.

-------------------------------

Por suerte, nuestro elenco es el mejor y perfectos para cada personaje de la Ciudad 8. GERTRUDE (Gina Yangali), TAKA (Tatiana Espinoza), LEO/OLÉ (Martín Abrisqueta), AGATHA (Alicia Mercado), ARTRO (Jorge Black), LIZZY (Salomé Reyes), LUCIUS (Manuel Díaz).

Our team is the best there is and they are perfect for each one of our characters of Ciudad 8. GERTRUDE (Gina Yangali), TAKA (Tatiana Espinoza), LEO/OLÉ (Martín Abrisqueta), AGATHA (Alicia Mercado), ARTRO (Jorge Black), LIZZY (Salomé Reyes), LUCIUS (Manuel Díaz).

------------------------------

Si ustedes son de Lima, de Bogotá, de Santiago, Buenos Aires, de Rio, de Estados Unidos, de Asia, estén donde estén pueden apoyarnos no sólo con dinero, sino compartiendo y difundiendo nuestra campaña. ¡Los esperamos!

If you are from Lima, Bogotá, Santiago, Buenos Aires, Rio, United States, Asia, etc, no matter where you are, you can support us not only with money, but sharing this campaign to your friends and spreading the news. ¡A superhero thank you!

Lo que necesitamos / What we need

  • $1,500 dólares (5,000 soles) For Design and Making of Sceneries / Para el Diseño y Realización de la escenografía.
  • $600 dólares (2,000 soles) For Design and Making of Costumes for 7 actors / Para el Diseño y Confección de Vestuario para 7 actores.
  • $600 dólares (2,000 soles) To create the soundtrack of the play / Para la musicalización de la obra.
  • $750 dólares (2,500 soles) To rent microphones for each actor during the shows (from September to November) /Para alquilar micrófonos durante toda la temporada.
  • Todo lo recibido se utilizará para nuestra obra de Teatro. Toda contribución ayuda. / Everything will be used for the play. Everything counts.
  • SI APOYAS ESTE PROYECTO / IF YOU SUPPORT THIS PROJECT:

Contribuirás a promover la cultura en Lima, Perú / You will contribute to promote Lima's Cultural activities.

Nos ayudarás a hacer realidad la Ciudad 8 y sus súperheroes / You will help us create Ciudad 8 and make our dream come true.

Nos ayudarás a llevar un lindo mensaje a los niños y a toda la familia. Sobre la unión familiar y el de reconocer los talentos que cada niño y adulto tiene. / You will bring a beautiful message to the children and the whole family, About family union and empowering kids to discover their own superpowers.

Tendrás nuestro agradecimiento eterno / We will be eternally grateful. 

Otras formas en las que puedes ayudar / Other ways to help

Recuerda que puedes ayudar de distintas formas: / Remember you can help in different ways:

- Pasando la voz sobre la obra que estrena el 24 de Setiembre en el Museo de Arte de Lima. / Spreading the word about this play that premieres September 24th at MALI (Museo de Arte de Lima)

- Asistir a la obra con toda tu familia. / Go see the show with your family.

- Difundir esta campaña para que más personas se enteren de este lindo proyecto. / Share this campaign so that more people get to know this beautiful project.

¡GRACIAS TOTALES! / A SUPERHERO THANK YOU!

Marianella & Carla

Asociación Cultural Art Connection

story: The entry fee raised through this will mean 10 months of training for me in order to swim, cycle and run over 100kms in Mallorca in May 2015 IRONMAN. Once I have my entry I will personally raise £2000 for Theatre Works an affordable theatre school run by my two best friends in the local community so they can buy tech equipment and take the students on a once in a life time theatre trip they wouldn't normally be able to afford :) touching over 100 aspiring actors.

story:
In order to help Vanara on its journey to the West End, we are asking you to help us raise £100,000.

This money will allow us to stage a second workshop, building on the incredible work we have done so far which you can see in our video.

Vanara has enjoyed an overwhelming response on social media, with over 10,000 fans becoming entranced by the music and mystery of of our new musical. You can learn more about us over on our Facebook Page.

During the recording of our concept album, which is now available for preorder, we have collaborated with Tony Award winning music director Ted Sperling, along with international musical theatre stars Carrie Hope Fletcher, Frances Ruffelle, Madalena Alberto and Eva Noblezada.

Some of our perks include copies of the upcoming Vanara concept album, tickets to future workshops, merchandise and more.

Combining music, holographic special effects, contemporary dance and classic storytelling, we believe that Vanara will be a truly unique addition to London’s theatreland. With your support, we can make this dream happen.

You can learn more about us over on our Facebook Page.During the recording of our concept album, which is now available for preorder, we have collaborated with Tony Award winning music director Ted Sperling, along with international musical theatre stars Carrie Hope Fletcher, Frances Ruffelle, Madalena Alberto and Eva Noblezada.Some of our perks include copies of the upcoming Vanara concept album, tickets to future workshops, merchandise and more.Combining music, holographic special effects, contemporary dance and classic storytelling, we believe that Vanara will be a truly unique addition to London’s theatreland. With your support, we can make this dream happen.

story:
Destination Dance: a site-specific dance tour through downtown Reno

Site-specific dance is work that is created in response to a particular place or site, inspired by its architecture, design, history, or current use. Destination Dance will feature the work of local choreographers who have been commissioned to create unique performances juxtaposed against iconic downtown fixtures, taking traditional and contemporary dance off of the stage and into a new environment.

What We Need & What You Get

  • We are raising $4,200.00 to supplement the pay for the 28 local dancers who will be performing in the event. While we do have funds set aside for them it is not nearly at a rate appropriate for the amount of time and dedication the event requires.
  • For your contributions, we have a few awesome perks, including Destination Dance Buttons, autographed flyers, and VIP access to dress rehearsals.
  • If we don't reach the entire goal, the funds will still be divided up amongst the performers.

Reshaping the Conventional Notions of Performance

Eve Allen, founder of Downtown Dance Collective in Reno, NV, has been commissioned by Artown to execute Destination Dance during the July 2015 festival.  Allen, alongside local choreographers Rosie Trump, Cari Cunningham, Katie Jean Dahlaw, and Rebecca Bone, will create new works that reshape the conventional notions of performance. 

  • Destination Dance was commissioned by Artown (the month-long city-wide arts festival) in celebration of it's 20th year. Artown admires innovation and proudly stands behind local projects that amplify the local community. The project aims to embrace the avant-garde ethos of the July festival, demonstrate the talent of our local emerging artists, and attract an audience that is not accustomed to viewing dance.

  • On Thursday, July 23, tour guides will lead groups departing from the Lear Theatre at 6:00pm, 6:20pm, 6:40pm, and 7:00pm. They will be equipped to discuss the history behind the various sites and the inspiration behind each artist’s choreographic decisions.

  • The event is free to the public, and people will be welcome to join the tour for as many stops as they choose.
  • Featuring urban and natural sites located in the Riverwalk District in downtown Reno, this walking-distance dance tour will allow audience members to engage with dance in a whole new way and view some of Reno’s most treasured locations in a new and invigorating light. Utilizing signature monuments in the heart of Reno such as the Ross Manor’s garden, the Truckee River Whitewater Park, Wild River Grille in the historic Riverside Hotel, the steps of the Washoe County Courthouse, and the porch of the Lake Mansion, Destination Dance will celebrate our city’s unique sense of place through movement.

The Dancers

While we will pay all of our performers, it is not commensurate with the talent and time spent on this project.  Your contribution will ensure that our local artists are compensated for their hard work and performances at a more realistic and professional rate. 

Event Details

Even if you can't contribute, we hope to see you at the event! It's a free and family friendly 1.5 mile loop through downtown Reno, where you'll experience our unique city, new contemporary choreography, and wonderful performances buy local dancers.

  • Please join the tour on Thursday, July 23rd to experience Reno in a whole new light! Four guided tours depart the Lear Theater (on Riverside Dr.) at 6:00pm, 6:20pm, 6:40pm, or 7:00pm.
  • Don't forget to use the Indiegogo share tools, share our Facebook event page, and enjoy the 20th anniversary of Artown this summer!

story:
What is our project?

The Smooving Project is a culminating street performance piece exploring connections between people, memory, and dreams developed by a team of alumni and graduate students of California State University, Long Beach.  We are a highly diverse team of theatre practitioners - all of us coming from different backgrounds; be it in our career paths or our birth countries, we have a multitude of perspectives and a wealth of stories to tell.  

This group of individuals were seeking to tell their personal stories in a way that moves past the boundaries of cultural constructs, language, and the academic institution; and we have sought artistic refuge in the open forum provided the SpaceLab program of the Prague Quadrennial Design Exhibition. 

 Fortunately for us, we've been invited to perform!   

Help us dive into our dreams, literally and figuratively, by helping us take our work to Prague.


What is Prague Quadrennial?

Prague Quadrennial is the largest theatrical design event in the world, showcasing the latest trends in theatrical design and architectural design of event spaces.  Held every four years, Prague Quadrennial 2015 will be in its 13th edition, continuing a tradition of highly artistic endeavor that brings together over 5,000 theatre and design practitioners from all over the globe and attracts over 50,000 visitors.  

To be selected as an exhibitor is an honor and privilege that is highly exclusive -

The Smooving Project is one of only 30 performances chosen among 400+ applicants for the SpaceLab and only one of five schools from the United States to be featured in this amazing program!

For the more information, visit the Prague Quadrennial Website.


Who is involved?

Our core group of creative artists consists of six designers and one actor, from varied design theatrical and design backgrounds:

 Narges Noroozi (Scenic Designer)

 Toranj Noroozi (Lighting Designer)

 Benjamin Weinert-Lishner (Scenic Designer)

 Brittany Blouch (Scenic Designer)

 Elena Flores (Costume Designer)

 Yuheng Dai (Costume Designer)

 Ben Durham (Actor)

There are so many others involved in the process though!  We have been developing this piece for 9 months and have used the creative minds and administrative genius of many in our department, with support coming from all arenas.  Thanks to our advisors, other faculty and staff at CSULB theatre arts department, and the support of our fellow graduate students, we've been able to really create a one-of-kind piece of performance art.


What are the challenges?

Putting together an original performance is challenge enough, many performers spend years in development, rehearsing and creating full-time to craft their work.  We don't have that luxury.  The Smooving Project has been in development for nine months, but many of us are also full-time graduate students in different programs; finding time to schedule and rehearse properly between seven wildly different calendars has been intense!  But we are dedicated to creating and are enthusiastic about this project, so we made time in between designing shows, outside gigs, writing and defending theses, teaching and full course-loads of graduate work to spend time with each other to create magic.

Brittany and Yuheng in rehearsal.

The show is meant to be performed abroad, on the street.  The logistical challenge of creating a show that can be moved is quite large; therefore we have taken on the task of using only the basics; things that can be found in any metropolitan area and our own bodies.  We are prepared to arrive with nothing and still be able to perform our show.


How can you help?

Being invited to perform internationally is huge honor, but it takes a lot of logistical and monetary support!  Despite our best efforts and research, we as a group of people who are (mostly) recently graduated but are also not a formal theatre company or individual performance artists disqualify for many of the artistic and travel grants afforded to others who take their work abroad.  

Thus, we are turning to you for help!  

Your donations will go a long way towards supplementing what we have already self-funded in order to take this show international.  There are five of us who will be travelling and performing this piece at the Quadrennial, here are the breakdown of expenses:

$1500/person - Average roundtrip flight from Los Angeles to Prague

$300/week - Group housing in Prague per person

$250/week - Average food costs in Prague per person

$110/person - Average costs of international travel documentation 

$20/week - Cost of public transport within Prague per person

$40/person - Registration and accreditation with the Prague Quadrennial administrative team 

$200 - Approximate cost of supplies needed for the performance (sketchpads, markers, paint, tape, cardboard, etc)

Total Expenses:  $11,300


Why $7,015?

This number has special meaning to us!  We know that asking for $11,000 is asking a lot of your kindness, so we wanted to make a more attainable goal in order to maximize our return from IndieGoGo.  There are 7 of us, which how we came up with the initial number, and then we wanted to commemorate the Quadrennial by adding the '15 to the end. 

What we are asking for in donations is only a fraction of what our actual costs are, as we stand behind the project and have already paid out of our own pockets many of the expenses listed.  We only ask that you help us recoup some of the losses of paying for a large international trip like this, which has taken a toll on us poor students!  Any and all donations are welcomed with sincere love from all of us.

THANK YOU FOR YOUR KINDNESS AND SUPPORT!
The Smooving Project

story:
A little bit about Tanisha Gibbons

I am a dancer and dance tutor who specializes in Latin and Modern dance. I am also the founder and Artistic Director of Gentle Steps Arts Academy and holder of an Associate Degree in Dance  (Barbados Community College). I am currently pursuing my Associate with the internationally accredited Imperial Society of Teachers of Dance , England.  I love working with children an now that I am the mother of two this is even more important to me. For the past 4 years I have successfully coordinated a summer arts camp which culminates with a major public production.  It is my main goal to provide an opportunity for children some of whom would otherwise never experience the Arts. 

 

What is the Memories Project?

Last year Gentle Steps Arts Academy won the Bank of Nova Scotia Award for Best Depiction of Caribbean history and heritage at the National Independence Festival of Creative Arts (NIFCA). “The Memories Project” builds on the award winning dance “The Migrants” workers who left Barbados to work on the Panama Canal.

The award winning "The Migrants" by Gentle Steps Arts Academy

"The Memories Project” is a work conceptualized by Yvonne Weekes and Artistic Director Tanisha Gibbons. It is a historical and fictionalized account of the lives of individuals who have helped to shape the course of Caribbean identity, history, politics, culture and arts. Ultimately, the production provides students (ages 6 to 18) with the opportunity to learn aspect of their own culture that is normally not presented within our current school syllabi.

  1. De Great Carew, Barbadian Calypsonian
  2. Dame Eugenia Charles, Prime Minister of the Commonwealth of Dominica
  3. Mary Secole, a Jamaican nurse who fought in the Crimea
  4. Nanny Gregg of Barbados who fought next to our national Hero Bussa
  5. A Barbadian male in Panama who leaves Barbados to work on the Panama Canal (The Migrants)
  6. Pregnant Barbadian Woman of the 37 riots
  7. Miss Edna of Grenada  – A Gairy Supporter
  8. Rihanna – Barbadian pop icon/singer

Where Will the Funds Go?

This is the fifth year of the camp and in the last four camps Gentle Steps Arts Academy I used personal funds to ensure that we had a production. As you know, funding is very hard to come by in Barbados. I am therefore seeking your assistance with the following:

Venue

We have outgrown our venue at the Performance Studio at the Barbados Community College. We are therefore seeking your assistance in affording us the opportunity to rent the Combermere School as well as pay our public liability insurance.

Technical Team

Over the last four years we have depended on our technical and design team foregoing payments in sound, lighting, set design and stage management. Long hours of technical and dress rehearsals are required for this one-hour length show. This year we would like to honour their skills, talents and training by offering their fees. Most of them are either Barbados Community College or Errol Barrow Centre for Creative Imagination (UWI) graduates whose work is outstanding. It would also be nice to provide our campers with food and drinks especially during those times.

Lighting Equipment.

Fortunately, our partner – Parhelion 120 Stage Lighting Inc. has most of the equipment we need. However, we would like to rent some specialist equipment for The Memories Project.

Costumes

As you can imagine to provide costumes for a historical and dance project is going to be quite expensive. So I am going to have to make costumes for my cast of 25 children in their seven dances.

 

Camp Begins 10th July

Rehearsals 24th July

Technical Rehearsal 11th and 12th August

Dress Rehearsal 13th August

Show 14th and 15th August

 

Other Ways You Can Help?

Can you donate your cooking skills for our large cast?

Can you offer to sew costumes?

Or maybe you can create an original calypso for one of our dances?

Or even just buy tickets for our shows for your employees or family?

You may even be able to offer us free promotion to a specific value.

Or maybe you can share this with your own social media?

 

If you have any thoughts please don’t hesitate to contact me at ta.nishanedd@live.com  

Thanks for your time and your donation.

 

Love and light

 

Tanisha Gibbons

story:
tanzBAR

Tanzgruppe tenDidancers

Wir laden ein in die tanzBAR ... seien Sie Gast in unserer Hotelbar und lassen Sie sich von unserer Tanzshow mitreißen. Mit unserer Show wollen wir uns einen langen Traum verwirklichen und unsere vielen Choreographien als komplettes Programm aufführen.

Die Vorstellungen laufen am 28. und 29. Januar 2017 im UT Connewitz in Leipzig,

Wer wir sind? Wir tanzen in unserer Freizeit als Show-Tanzgruppe im Leipziger Studio tendance. Seit vielen Jahren nehmen wir uns einmal pro Woche Zeit, um gemeinsam zu trainieren. Mit unserem Programm wollen wir unseren langjährigen Wegbegleitern mit einer tollen Show danken und zugleich alle tanzinteressierte Menschen ermutigen, eigene Ziele und Wünsche zu verwirklichen – denn mit Tanzen kann man bestens Stress und Sorgen aus dem Alltag vergessen.

Wozu wird das Geld verwendet? Wir werden davon Bühnenbild, Kostüme, Saalmiete und Technik bezahlen.

https://www.facebook.com/tenDidancers

http://www.tanzstudio-tendance.de/

story:
I graduated from the University of Northumbria in 2006 with first class honours in Ba(hons) Dance:Choreography and have been creating and performing dance and performance art at a professional level ever since.

As a choreographer I love to explore unusual performance spaces. When I was studying for my A-level in dance back in 2000 I was introduced to Trisha Brown's works "Walking on the Wall" and "Man Walking Down the Side of a Building" and was totally fascinated. In both works the dance floor is shifted from the ground to the wall with the dancers suspended at 90 degrees perpendicular to the floor. This challenged the notion of traditional dance spaces, what is possible in terms of the use of gravity, what the dancer's base of support is, what is possible when your dance surface is changed.  As a person and an artist I aim to push myself to continually develop and grow. The purpose of this project is to marry my passion for exploring unusual performance spaces and my desire to move outside of my comfort zone as an artist inspired by the notions raised in Brown's work over 40 years ago. By exploring the potential of and creating dance within a unique environment with no fixed  ground, namely a giant bubble floating on a pool of water I hope to push the boundaries of what is possible in modern dance.

The funds raised will pay for the equipment I need to begin this research and development project - a water walking ball, a portable pool, an air pump and hose, pay for rehearsal space and produce video footage.

This will be an entirely new experience for me. I have danced on a studio floor thousands of times and I've done some aerial work, I have done fire manipulation and stilt walking but I have never tried to dance on what pretty much amounts to an entirely unstable surface inside of a continually moving ball. It will be a big challenge but one I look forward to with much relish and excitement!

If you can't give or chose that you don't want to donate to my fund I would really appreciate it if you would help me to raise awareness of my campaign by sharing it on your social media pages.

Thank you so much for reading and for your support.

story:
Short Summary

*Prevod na srpskom se nalazi dole!*

Belgrade English Language Theatre, Riverhouse Barn and Esher High have been working on a collaborative youth project centered on the rivers that breathe life into their communities: The Danube, Sava and Thames.   

The collaborative piece of the project will take place in two parts.  

The first will be located in Belgrade, Serbia.  Students from the UK will join students from Belgrade from April 3rd-7th to begin workshopping their performance together, using existing ideas and performance models that each group has worked on separately in their home countries.  During this time, the students from the UK will also enjoy a tour of the city, helping them to explore Serbian culture and the cultural significance of the two rivers.

In the second part of the project, the groups will meet again, from April 29 to May 4, this time in Walton-on-Thames in England.  Serbian students will be hosted by those in the UK and enjoy tours of both Walton-on-Thames and London, while participating in final performance workshops. These activities will culminate in a live performance of the groups at the theatre there.

What We Need & What You Get

In the coming weeks, we will be doing everything we can to raise any money to help fund visas, travel, tours and funds for production values (props, costumes and more!)  While our goal is set at $500, anything above and beyond that will only help to further the students' experience of the cities.

The Impact

This project is an incredible opportunity for the students involved not only to meet people from a different culture, but to experience different teaching styles, explore a new and exciting setting, and finally to collaborate and develop a performance piece that is uniquely their own.  

Belgrade English Language Theatre has previously led successful youth theatre trips to Croatia, England, Italy the Czech Republic. These trips have provided students with invaluable skills and opportunities.  They have been able to work with diverse international theatre artists, perform to new audiences, and see exciting performances.  These experiences are priceless, but would have been unattainable without the generosity and fundraising efforts of members and friends.

Risks & Challenges

While organizing any trip abroad is a complex process, organizing a trip to the UK is particularly complicated and expensive. Unlike all other European countries, the UK and Ireland still require people from Serbia to secure a visa for short visits (even creative and educational ones!), which in itself costs 90 pounds (with no guarantee of it being awarded). But we are determined that despite the financial and  bureaucratic challenges we will make this opportunity a reality.

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you cannot support this project financially, please share our campaign!  Use your social media network to broaden our scope, because every bit matters!  Thanks so much!

Prevod na Srpskom

Belgrade English Language Theatre, Riverhouse Barn i Esher High rade na zajednickom projketu za mlade koji  se bavi tematikom reka, Dunav, Sava, Temza, i kako one doprinose gradu. 

Ovaj zajednicki projekat ce biti izveden iz dva dela:

Prvi deo ce biti odrzan u Beogradu, Srbiji. Mladi iz Engleske ce doci prvo u Beograd 03.04. 2017. do 07.04.2017. gde ce zajedno sa mladima iz Beograda raditi na zajednickoj predstavi koristeci postojece ideje na kojima su radili odvojeno. Tokom ovog vremena mladi iz Engleske ce takodje uzivati u razgledanju grada radi istrazivanja srpske kulture i uticaja ove dve reke na grad.

U drugom delu projekta grupa ce se sastaviti opet 29.04.2017. do  04.05.2017, ali ovog puta u gradu Valton na Temzi u Engleskoj Mladi iz Srbije ce biti smesteni kod mladih iz Engleske radi zajednickog  razgledanja Temze i Londona gde ce zajednicki raditi na  izvodjenju njihove premijere, koju ce izvesti u Engleskoj. 

Vas doprinos bi pomogao da se ova sardnja ostvari, ukoliko zelite, uplatite koliko mozete  na ovom sajtu tako sto cete kliknuti na znak "Back It."

Hvala!

Belgrade English Language Theatre, Riverhouse Barn i Esher High rade na zajednickom projketu za mlade koji  se bavi tematikom reka, Dunav, Sava, Temza, i kako one doprinose gradu. 
Ovaj zajednicki projekat ce biti izveden iz dva dela:
Prvi deo ce biti odrzan u Beogradu, Srbiji. Mladi iz Engleske ce doci prvo u Beograd 03.04. 2017. do 07.04.2017. gde ce zajedno sa mladima iz Beograda raditi na zajednickoj predstavi koristeci postojece ideje na kojima su radili odvojeno. Tokom ovog vremena mladi iz Engleske ce takodje uzivati u razgledanju grada radi istrazivanja srpske kulture i uticaja ove dve reke na grad.
U drugom delu projekta grupa ce se sastaviti opet 29.04.2017. do  04.05.2017, ali ovog puta u gradu Valton na Temzi u Engleskoj Mladi iz Srbije ce biti smesteni kod mladih iz Engleske radi zajednickog  razgledanja Temze i Londona gde ce zajednicki raditi na  izvodjenju njihove premijere, koju ce izvesti u Engleskoj. 
Vas doprinos bi pomogao da se ova sardnja ostvari, ukoliko zelite, uplatite koliko mozete  na ovom sajtu tako sto cete kliknuti na znak "Back It."
Hvala!

story:
In our new production of The Missing Element, there is love, betrayal and war. With your help you can see this elemental world become a reality in the Oscar G. Brockett Theatre at the University of Texas at Austin on April 14 through 17th.

A short synopsis of our play:

In a world where there is an unequal distribution of power and the elements on the periodic table have been shoved into tiny boxes of separation, class, characterization, and identification, unrest stirs amongst Groups 1 & 2 to rebel against the Nobles! The missing element is an explosive artistic endeavor which infuses the art of storytelling and education with exploratory design and performance. Through the means of steam-punk meets Victorian style costuming, robotic lighting, graphic projections, originally composed electronic music, and modern meets capoeira dance, artistic elements mirror the reactions and relationships between chemical elements. As the fundamental laws of chemistry are defined, denied, and destroyed, this genre of scientific fantasy attempts to explain and interpret basic patterns and trends of Dmitri Mendeleev's periodic table. In a fight for freedom and equality, love and loss is found as the age-old adage of opposites attract cannot be denied! 

Costumes:

Our costume designer has come up with some wonderful and exciting costumes for our characters, the elements.

For example:

Lighting:

Our lighting designer also has grand plans. She plans to use a total of 21 intelligent lighting fixtures to create a lightscape similar to that of space and the stars. With the use of haze, she can achieve things like this.

Projections:

Our projection designer is aiming to emulate the elements and explain complex scientific research through the use of video and still imagery.

All in all, our show promises to entertain and educate in a way that hasn't been seen before. Perhaps we can encourage the young and not so young to pursue a life of intellectual adventure and artistic creation. So please, join us in April as the age old tale of love and loss showcases the undeniable fact that opposites do in fact attract.
