story:
Hello everybody,

I'm Morgan "Bud" Edwards, and I'd like to tell you about Lily, Casually – a new rock n' roll musical that I wrote. The show is going to be awesome, but I need a bit of help to make it truly come to life. In exchange for your help, I'm willing to trade a bunch of really cool things, just check out the list to the right.

Below is an interview I had with myself to let you know as much as I could about this new production.

WHAT IS LILY, CASUALLY?

Lily, Casually is a rock n' roll musical about modern romance, financial struggle, and a woman named Lily White, who kills a ton of despicable men. It will be performed by some of the most talented musical theater actors in New York, accompanied by an amazing live rock band (Rocket & the Ghost). If you like rock n' roll, strong female characters, and having a ridiculously good time, then Lily, Casually will definitely be one of the greatest things you've ever seen.

WHAT IS IT ABOUT?

Lily and Jimmy White are a young married couple trying to make ends meet in the metropolitan Northeast. Lily works as a secretary and Jimmy scams the unemployment system. Eventually, Jimmy's illegitimate income catches up with him, and he lands himself in prison.

Lily finds herself lonely, angry, and unable to pay all of the bills she split with Jimmy. Deciding to get her mind off things, she delves into the world of online dating. When a date ends in homicide (albeit, self-defense), Lily White starts to become the monster the world has been begging her to be.

And now, to entice without spoiling, a list of awesome things this play has:

  • righteous murder
  • seedy internet love
  • Off Track Betting
  • guitar solos
  • a hunky detective
  • scandalous love
  • a Greek chorus
  • unconventional salvation
  • men in mysterious hats
  • babes with weapons
  • harmless cannibalism
  • religious gambling addicts
  • amazing music
  • etc.
Lily, Casually touches on some pretty serious themes, including religion, feminism, and socio-economic immobility. That said, it's still an over the top comedic, glam-rock thriller, so even if you don't care about themes and meaning, you'll still have an amazing time (see list above). And that, for me, is the most important function of music and art – to make people actually experience something. 

WHERE IS IT HAPPENING?

The premier run of Lily, Casually is going to take place during the Thespis Theater Festival at the Hudson Guild Theatre in Manhattan, NY. The show dates are:

  • July 28 @ 6:15pm
  • August 1 @ 8:30pm
  • August 2 @ 1:00pm

After these dates, we will continue to produce the show with our sights set on an Off-Broadway run. All of the donations we receive will go towards continuing the show as long as possible. We're just getting started... 

WHAT IS THE MONEY FOR?

I've already spent a considerable amount of my money on this endeavor, and will continue to because I truly believe in it. However, I can't do it all on my own. Every penny raised during this campaign will help make the show even more awesome. Here's a breakdown of the budget:

  • Cast & Crew = $2400
  • Costumes = $650
  • Make-Up = $300
  • Props = $675
  • Marketing = $750
  • Lights & Sound = $1000
  • Technical Equipment = $1800
  • Administrative Fees = $500
  • TOTAL = $8575
And now, a pie chart:


WHY AM I DOING THIS?

I learned at a very early age that if you have a story to tell, the best way to tell it is with a rock n' roll musical.

I remember going to the public library as a child, looking for a scary movie to rent. As I scanned the modest collection of VHS tapes, I spotted a black cover with nothing more than letters made of blood spelling out the title. It was perfect; it had the word "horror" right in the title.

What I had rented that day at the library was Richard O'Brien's masterpiece, "Rocky Horror Picture Show." So I didn't end up watching a scary movie that night. But what I did watch changed my entire life. It was the greatest thing I had ever seen – it had rock n' roll, fake blood, motorcycles, and people having an awesome time by any means necessary. It exposed me to sexual liberation, gender ambiguity and Meatloaf, and I questioned none of it. The impression that film left on me can be summed up in the chorus of it's penultimate song, "don't dream it, be it."

As I got older, my love affair with rock n' roll and theatrics continued to grow. Leaving undergrad with a degree in finance, I made the prudent decision to go across the Atlantic and play in an English rock band. After a stint of being a quasi-homeless ex-pat, I returned to New York, went to law school, got a job, and then walked away from it because what I really had to do was write this rock n' roll musical.

The two main things my experiences have taught me are how to work hard, and how to put on a great show. I plan to do both with Lily, Casually, and I'd like to share it with the world.

story:
My name is Spencer Pond, and I am the founder and artistic director of
The Now Unboxing Project. (NUP)


The Now Unboxing Project is a new dance experience on a mission to find self-true dance vocabulary, explore methods of performance and define / defy the limits we put on ourselves as creators and dancers. I decided that all the excuses I had been allowing to hold me back from creating dance were no longer going to stop me. In the past, I’d been too afraid to even start the creation process, and when I did get the chance to choreograph, I was overly concerned with doing it “right” or adhering too closely to a specific style. But now is the time for me to push my dance project
further by unboxing myself and my dancers from these limits in order to create beautiful, genuine pieces.

Our current repertory, although small, truly reflects the diversity and innovation of the project. Being able to go to a show and see both old-school Vaudeville-based jazz and experimental contemporary, to watch dances both theatrical and rigorously technical, and to hear all styles of music in the same billing is rare, which
creates a unique experience for our audience.

In order to expand our repertory and to take the company to new heights, we will be doing our first residency at The Dirt Salon, a beautiful gallery space in Hartford, this summer. During the residency, my dancers and myself will create work that will culminate in a gallery showing. The pieces can then be produced into a larger stage show, submitted to festivals and translated into films.

This is where you come in! Any donation is appreciated and will help us pay for the space, dancers, lighting and costumes. If you can’t give monetarily, one of the easiest ways to help us out is by sharing the fundraiser with family and friends. If you specialize in web design, costume designing, lighting designer or anything theatrically-leaning, we would also be more than happy to have your help.


What We Need & What You Get

All of the $3120 goal will go to:

  • Paying Dancers / Choreographers $2,000.00
  • Space - $200.00 (Some money already raised from Film Release)
  • Costumes - $800.00
  • Indiegogo Fee - $120.00
The Now Unboxing Project is very lucky to have many extra hands volunteering their time and effort. Dance is an expensive art form, and without these wonderful people, and your help, the NUP wouldn't be possible. Thank you for all your support.

story:
Emergence- SFU Dance Grad Show

Each spring, the graduating class of SFU Dancers produces, creates, and performs their own production showcasing the choreographic, performance, and design work that we have been learning throughout our four years at SFU. This year, our show is called Emergence, in recognition of the fact that we are emerging young artists in the Vancouver dance community.  Emergence is made up of three pieces choreographed by Desi Rekrut and Mahaila Patterson O'Brien, Clara Chow, and Lily Cryan. 

Emergence will be performed May 1st and 2nd at 8pm at SFU Woodwards in Studio D.  Check out the Facebook event for more information! https://www.facebook.com/events/1579555328928845/

Our big ask!

We have done much of our fundraising already through throwing after parties for SFU Dance productions, selling SFU Dance logo clothing, and applying for and receiving a grant from the Simon Fraser Student Society.  However, we are still about $250.00 short of our budget for the show.  Our budget consists of the following:

Technical supervisor- $30.50/hour for 26 hours- total $793
Front of House - $94/show for 2 shows- total $188
Cashier- $50/show for 2 shows- total $100
Lighting Designer honorarium- $200 - 2 designers- total $400
Stage Manager honorarium- $200 - 1 stage manager- total $200
Assistant Stage Manager honorarium- $100 - 1 ASM - total $100
Technical Director - $200 - 1 TD - total $200
Musicians/Composer honorarium - $100 - 3 musicians - $300
Costumes - $20 - 10 dancers- $200
Posters/programs printing- $100 - total $100
Total expenses- $2,581

We have raised over $2000.00 but we need your help to be able to pay our lighting designers, stage manager, and technical director in order to make this show a reality! Any little bit helps!

We do have some lovely perks as a thank you for your donation, see the perks section for details!

Where your contribution goes

Our show is our launch into the Vancouver and International dance community.  It is our opportunity to stage our own work and invite important industry professionals to see what we can do.  We are also documenting the show for further granting and project applications as many applications require footage of past work in order to be considered.  Your donation helps support the next generation of young dancers, choreographers, and artists break into the field with a bang!

Other Ways You Can Help

If you cannot donate to our cause, we thank you for viewing our campaign! If you can spread the word about the show to your friends we would be much obliged.  A robust audience helps make our work come alive and we would love to share all that we have been doing with you! See our Facebook event for more information about the show and thank you for your interest in our work!

https://www.facebook.com/events/1579555328928845/

story:
Hello!

We are Cosmic Biscuit Theatre, an all women ensemble dedicated to telling stores in the most sincere (and hilarious) way possible. 
We are three women, all trained at Saint Mary's University College, Twickenham.
Our company aim is not only to amuse, but to make people think. Even though we are a comic group, we always want to ensure that there is meaning within our stories.
We also plan to carry out workshops to young people, teaching them the art of clown and that comedy can be the best medicine. Also, teaching young actors how to set up their own company themselves.
This summer we are taking our debut show, 'Simply the West' to the Edinburgh Fringe Festival. Our story focuses on a family living in East Berlin just as the wall is going up, and we explore how their everyday lives changed forever.

What We Need & What You Get

This £500 pounds will help us in many ways:

  • £100 pounds will allow us to buy our costumes.
  • £50 pounds will allow us to buy materials for our puppet in our Fringe show.
  • £150 pounds will cover our fuel costs for Edinburgh Fringe Festival.
  • £100 pounds will cover the expense of our poster design.
  • £100 pounds will allow us to buy props and materials to carry out our school workshops.
If you give to us, we will all be entirely grateful!
  • If you give between £10-£50, you will receive a beautiful email of thanks from all of the Biscuits, saying how much we love and appreciate you.
  • If you give £50-£100, you will receive a hand written letter and a poem from all of the Biscuits, saying how much we appreciate you.
  • If you give £100-£200, you will receive a hand written letter PLUS a you tube link to a personal video of thanks saying how much we love and appreciate you.
  • If you give over £200, you will receive all of the above PLUS a free ticket to any of our shows in the future.
Also, anyone who contributes anything towards us will become a 'friend of Cosmic Biscuit' and your name will be included on our website, coming soon.

If you would like more information on Cosmic Biscuit Theatre, please dont hesitate to email us on thecosmicbiscuit@gmail.com


Every penny matters and it would give us the boost our company needs! Thank you all so much!

story:
What's the deal with the Freshman Musical?

We are a student group dedicated to producing, designing, and performing (and everything in between!) a musical for the Northwestern and Evanston communities, all done exclusively by members of the freshman class. It’s a chance for us to show off what we’re capable of after just one year here.

What's the show about?

The Mystery of Edwin Drood is an engaging theatrical rumpus based on Charles Dickens's incomplete novel by the same title. This play-within-a-play explores first the journey of young Edwin Drood and the many characters who wish him dead, and second the journey of the boisterous and motley gang of music hall performers who self-consciously tell our story. Because Dickens never finished the novel, we invite our audience itself to vote upon three essential questions regarding the resolution of our play––including the central question of who truly killed our protagonist––and enact their chosen outcome each night. So what is the mystery of Edwin Drood? That's for you to decide. -Ryan Martin, Director

The Mystery of Edwin Drood goes up May 22-24 in the Jones Great Room at Northwestern University.

Where is my money going?

The Mystery of Edwin Drood and the Freshman Musical organization are entirely non-profit and student-produced. On top of that, we receive absolutely no funding from the university. As a donor to the show, your money will help fund various aspects of our production. A donation from you may help us build our set, or it may help us acquire costumes, or it may help us fill the performance space with beautiful lights and props. Our cast and team are working incredibly hard to create a beautiful piece of theatre, and every dollar donated will help us realize this vision. 

Who's working on this project?

Our cast features...

  • Chris Paul as Chairman
  • Jessie Jennison as Edwin Drood
  • Justin Tepper as John Jasper
  • Samantha Baran as Rosa Bud

Behind the scenes, you can find...

  • Co-Producers: Rob Cassie & Solveig Herzum

  • Assistant Producer: Tessa Dettman

How else can I help?

If you are unable to donate, or if you just want to keep helping, here are some other ways to support our show:

  • Come and see the show! 
  • Spread the word! Share this campaign on Facebook and Twitter, and tell your friends and family about the show!

Thank you so much!
story_txt:
What's the deal with the Freshman Musical? We are a student group dedicated to producing, designing, and performing (and everything in between!) a musical for the Northwestern and Evanston communities, all done exclusively by members of the freshman class. It’s a chance for us to show off what we’re capable of after just one year here.
What's the show about?The Mystery of Edwin Drood is an engaging theatrical rumpus based on Charles Dickens's incomplete novel by the same title. This play-within-a-play explores first the journey of young Edwin Drood and the many characters who wish him dead, and second the journey of the boisterous and motley gang of music hall performers who self-consciously tell our story. Because Dickens never finished the novel, we invite our audience itself to vote upon three essential questions regarding the resolution of our play––including the central question of who truly killed our protagonist––and enact their chosen outcome each night. So what is the mystery of Edwin Drood? That's for you to decide. -Ryan Martin, DirectorThe Mystery of Edwin Drood goes up May 22-24 in the Jones Great Room at Northwestern University.Where is my money going?The Mystery of Edwin Drood and the Freshman Musical organization are entirely non-profit and student-produced. On top of that, we receive absolutely no funding from the university. As a donor to the show, your money will help fund various aspects of our production. A donation from you may help us build our set, or it may help us acquire costumes, or it may help us fill the performance space with beautiful lights and props. Our cast and team are working incredibly hard to create a beautiful piece of theatre, and every dollar donated will help us realize this vision. Who's working on this project?Our cast features...
Chris Paul as Chairman

Jessie Jennison as Edwin Drood

Justin Tepper as John Jasper

story:
Presented by Columbia University School of the Arts


What is 1989? 

1989 follows the life of two young Argentine newlyweds at the start their lives together during one of Argentina's most politically tense and economically challenging times. Accompanied by a live rock band, the story unravels alongside the music of Sumo, Seru Giran, Soda Stereo, Virus, Abuelos de la Nada and other 80s rock. Issues of young adulthood, love, home, and family come together in 1989 as a blend of live concert, storytelling, and choreography.

“1989” se basa en la vida de dos jóvenes argentinos, recién casados, que comienzan su vida juntos en uno de los momentos de mayor tensión política y dificultad económica de la Argentina. La historia aborda preguntas sobre el significado de la familia, el amor, el hogar, y el comienzo de la vida adulta. Una banda de rock en vivo musicaliza la obra con temas de  Sumo, Seru Giran, Soda Stereo, Virus, Abuelos de la Nada, Fito Paez, y Luis Alberto Spinetta. En “1989” la música en vivo se ensambla de manera armónica e ingeniosa con la narración y la coreografía. 


Where Your Donation Will Go? 

  • Space Rental—rehearsal studio rental for our amazing rock band.
  • Marketing & Publicity—Without an audience, there’d be no play.
  • Set, costumes, props—Turn our incredible designers’ design into reality.


Our Team

PRODUCTION / PRODUCCIÓN

Director: Tatiana Pandiani
Producer: Yue Liu
Stage Management: Mariana Vallejo
Set design: Feli Lamenca
Lighting design: Chris Cancel
Costume design: Jessica Posteraro

CAST / ELENCO

Stefania Bulbarella 
Mauricio Pita 
Tina Wang 
Inaki Baldasarre

MUSIC / MÚSICA

Musical Direction / vocals: Juana Aquerreta 
Guitar: Jacinta Clusellas 
Drums: Daniel Montoya
Bass: Santiago Herrera
Trumpet: Michael Sarian
Keyboard: Santiago Leibenson

story:
About Stephanie Peña

My name is Stephanie Peña. I am an aspiring choreographer from New York City.  My practice derives from contemporary dance techniques, which focuses on dramatic expressions.

I am graduating in May of 2014 from the City University of New York at Hunter College with a Bachelors of Arts degree in Dance.

Through my studies and practice, I have become a passionate choreographer, performer and teaching artist. During the winter of 2014, my dancers and I were welcomed to perform at both the Baltimore Dance Invitational and The 10th Amalgamate Artist Series. As a dancer, I have had the opportunity to perform at the 2013 American College Dance Festival and in many performances at Hunter College and Movement Research. As a teaching artist, I have taught salsa with Salsa New York, and at the Positively 8th Street Festival, a festival dedicated to bringing positivity to the community. Additionally, I have taught private belly dance lessons and worked as an assistant dance educator at the Harkness Dance Center at the 92nd Street Y. I truly believe dance is a form of art to be expressed amongst people of all ages, sizes, and colors.

The Opportunity

My dancers and I were invited to showcase my dance piece titled, “What Am I Doing Here?” in Ticino, Switzerland.  At the festival my dancers and I will have the opportunity to showcase the piece at a formal showing during the week and at the Ticino in Danza Gala. During the day we will be taking dance classes, participating in workshops and partaking in the community outreach. 

Why Ticino in Danza Festival at Switzerland?

According to the Ticino in Danza website, “Ticino in Danza Festival creates an international platform for professional choreographers and dancers to show their work and expand their network abroad as well as connect with other artists, exchange ideas and interact.”  Their goal is for dancers/choreographers to share their personal art and culture, but most of all have the ability to teach their style abroad. This will be an amazing opportunity to dance with choreographers from other countries and share a choreographic experience of professionalism, culture and enrichment of dance. It will provide us the opportunity to see how people from around the world understand dance and how dance shapes their perspective.  We will be connecting with mature artists within the international professional dance scene to become more inspired with new perspectives, ideas, and goals.

What Do We Need?

This incredible experience to Ticino, Switzerland will not happen without your support. As an emerging artist, I don’t have the funds for this project. Therefore, I am asking for your kindness and support to make this project a reality. Any donation, whether small or large, will be a big help. Our hearts are committed and we are set and ready to participate in this amazing project. All we need is your help to make this dream come true.

The Ticino in Danza Festival will only provide about 45% of the cost for the workshops and dance classes. My four dancers and I will need funds for traveling expenses, food, hotel accommodation, and the other 55% of the festival expenses.

The grand total will be $18,215

If you all help us fund this project, you will receive

·  Personal shout out on my Facebook , Instagram, Pinterest, Tumblr, Twitter & a hug

·  I will keep you updated on the process leading up to the festival, the workshops at the festival, and my choreographic process even afterwards

·  Postcard from Switzerland

·  2 Free tickets to any performance I showcase my choreography

·  A signed dance photo of my dancers and I

· A dinner with the myself and my dancers

I will also create a dance piece about my experience in Switzerland, for you and the community to enjoy. This piece will be made out of gratitude in honor for your kindness and support.

story:
Who is Planta Genista Productions?

Although we are a young company, we are by no means inexperienced, having mounted a very successful production of Richard III at the Secret Rose Theatre in North Hollywood, hailed in the press as "A brilliant and visionary mounting." ( Entertainment Today ) and "An impressive achievement." ( LA Weekly ).  We also produced an afternoon of highlights from great plays, presented as a medley, called "Making a Scene," ( see photos below and in our gallery )  at the Victory Theatre in Burbank. It is now our goal to bring Victor Hugo's timeless story of forgiveness, redemption and courage to life in a production meant not only to entertain, but to uplift, inspire and encourage all who see it to embrace the ideals the story embodies.

Production photo from PGP's production of "Richard III." L - R: Mary Dryden, George Almond.

That's great, but what have you done recently?

In our mission to bring this exciting and unique piece of theatre to life, we ran a previous Indie Go-Go campaign which brought us a long way toward our goal. Never idle, We hosted a staged reading of the play at the Complex Theatre Center in West Hollywood this past December, and followed that by staging a fundraiser just this August, which we called, "Making a Scene," at the Victory Theatre in Burbank. It was an afternoon of highlights from various great plays, featuring a cast from LA's own "Classical Theatre Lab" ( www.classicaltheatrelab.org ), which brought in additional funds to our mission, so we are already halfway toward our goal!

Top to bottom: the cast of our staged reading of "Victor Hugo's Les Miserables" ; Megan Green delivering a monologue as Titania in a scene from Shakespeare's "A Midsummer Night's Dream from  our August 2014 fundraiser, "Making a Scene."


Is this the musical?

No! This is a gritty, minimalist drama, adapted by Jonathan Holloway, founder and Artistic Director of the Red Shift Theatre Company in London England. It played there to great success, and spawned an equally successful  production in Hong Kong.

From the press notices for the original production: 

"Forget the musical - this was the production that brought Hugo's weighty tome to life ... A performance that illuminated a great text in all its depth, stimulated its audience and also entertained it richly." 
---Julian Guyer, Highbury and Islington Express
 

"Victor Hugo's Les Miserables is a world away from big musicals, as a cast of six concentrate on just telling the story." 
---Ian Shuttleworth, The Financial Times

The play is presented with a minimal set and a cast of only eight, most of whom double and re-double in a kind of whirling, living kaleidoscope, making up the entire rich population of characters in Hugo's sweeping epic. Told in a modern, presentational, Brechtian style and set in the Great Depression, the characters often speak directly to the audience, involving them in a deeply personal and intimate theatrical experience. 

But I've never seen the musical, any of the movies or read the book. What's the story?

"Les Miserables" tells the story of ex-convict Jean Valjean, and his struggle to redeem his life. Along the way he touches the lives of many, including the tragic prostitute Fantine, and her daughter Cosette, whom Valjean adopts and comes to love as his own child. All the while he is relentlessly pursued by an obsessed policeman, Inspector Javert,  whose rigid devotion to his Draconian vision of the law compels him to drive Valjean from place to place

It is one of the greatest stories of all time, and  has inspired numerous film adaptations, the musical which has been seen by over 40 million people worldwide, as well as inspiring several television shows ranging from The Fugitive to Kung-Fu to The Incredible Hulk.

Why are we asking for money, and how is it going to be used?

Because we are a young company, we lack the capital to cover the whole of our adventure. Planta Genista Productions is having to be incredibly creative to find the funding ( by simply asking for it! ) So, Monseigneur, how is your silver to be spent?

There are a number of areas that will need to be covered:

-Royalties to the author of the adaptation

-Venue Hire

-Publicity

-Printing of posters, programs, etc.

-Set construction 

- Lighting Design 

-Stage  Management 

How can you get all that for just $8, 000?

Planta Genista Productions is pleased to announce that it has already secured half of our total projected budget through our previously mentioned efforts. We have also confirmed the venue and gathered all of the physical properties we need. We just need you to give us the final boost over fence, into the promised land of production! If you are looking for a winner to back, this is it!

No donation is too small, and will be a great help to us, your grateful beneficiaries. More than this, by funding us and enabling us to bring this piece to life, you will be a significant part of a rare and noble enterprise that has the potential to reap the myriad educational rewards and cultural awakenings that the arts bring to audiences and communities night after night, performance after performance. You will also proving to aspiring and ambitious companies, directors, producers and actors that anything is possible!

Risks and challenges

Once funded, there is absolutely no chance of this project falling through--the show will go on! The venue has been selected and the production team and cast are among the most dedicated people around.

However, there are some difficulties that may occur, but none that cannot be overcome. For example, if a cast member becomes ill or cannot perform for any reason, the cast have doubled-up on roles and are prepared to step in at any moment. Other than this, nothing will stop the curtain from rising!

( We are not liable for "Acts of God"-- e.g. a California earthquake causes the ground to open and swallow the theatre and all inside, never to be heard from again ).
